149610957.review:
I bought this game when it came out in 2012, started it several times, abandoned each time, and finally finished it in 2022 ! I have no idea why it took so long, because it's a good game ! It has aged, though, so someone looking to play it now should probably look at its "Re-Reckoning" version.

What drew me into the game was its artistic direction. I thought the movements, visual effects and character designs looked very, very cool and unique. I chose my class and weapons based solely on how they looked. That said, KoAR offers much more than that.

Combat does looks cool and flows nicely, you very quickly get how your weapons and combos work, and it is a pleasure to play. I recommend the normal difficulty, as the lowest one really trivializes some encounters to an absurd degree. (But obviously you know what's best for you.)

KoAR is also a very complete RPG with a lot of freedom. You can completely change your class at any time, mix diferent classes, and also change your utility abilities ! (Things like crafting, lockpicking...) There are several questlines that you can follow in any order (up to a point of no return), you can resolve quests in a number of ways... You are told narratively that you have choices, and the gameplay truly delivers on that.

The story starts as a generic Chosen One plot, but with the twist that you're special only because you died and were resurrected. And as you progress the story and learn more, you realise that all is not what it seems, and several assumptions that were made about you may be slightly off or completely wrong. So in the end, while the plot is nothing extraordinary, it is not as bland as it might seem.

There are LOTS of areas to explore, all beautiful and different, and while a lot of NPC are generic, there is originality in the quests you get, the people you meet, and the world itself. It did not feel like just another fantasy world, a lot of research and creativity went into it. The fact that you learn about the lore by listening to lorestones rather than read about it was also a smart choice.

There are issues with the game, but most are due to its age. There are some bugs that can prevent quest progression, but you can find ways to avoid them on the internet. The DLC aren't really tied to the main story but they're very enjoyable as standalone stories.

So all in all it was a good game, and it deserved more attention than what I gave it. I really encourage you to play its remastered version if you're interested. I'm tempted to buy it myself and play the game properly this time.

[b] > Be me, excited gamer ready for epic fantasy adventure
> Hear about "Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning"
> Think, "This is gonna be like Skyrim, but with more color!"
> Start the game, create my epic character with weirdly customizable everything
> Spend an hour making the most beautiful orc mage the world has ever seen
> Enter the game world, get smacked in the head by an asteroid and die
> Wait, what? That's not how fantasy adventures start!
> Respawn in some dank basement, greeted by an angry gnome scientist
> Gnome's like, "Hey, you were supposed to stay dead!"
> Now I'm stuck in a magical resurrection experiment gone wrong
> Realize I'm basically a video game zombie - great, I guess?
> Venture into the game world, feel like a never-ending cup of coffee
> Everyone talks like they're on a fantasy-themed game show
> Quests are everywhere, like free samples at the mall food court
> Get sidetracked by side quests, forget what main quest even is
> Kill wolves, steal random stuff, somehow end up a part-time alchemist
> Combat is like a dance-off with magic and swords
> Equip the coolest armor, look like a medieval Power Ranger
> Game's difficulty is a rollercoaster - I'm a demigod one moment, but then a goblin one-shots me
> "No, you can't die; you're an experiment!" - everyone and their grandma
> Storyline goes all over the place, like a cat on a caffeine high
> Meet a thousand different characters, but can't remember any of their names
> Randomly decide to become a blacksmith because why not?
> Forge epic weapons that can kill dragons or chop a radish
> Start using the magic "Fateshift" ability - basically become a walking blender
> Mages shoot lasers from their eyes, bosses explode into loot piñatas
> Dragons become fire-breathing BBQ grills
> Finally get back to the main quest - defeating an evil overlord
> This dude's like, "I'm super powerful!" - proceeds to get stomped like a goomba
> Game doesn't know if it's a serious fantasy epic or a Looney Tunes episode
> Finish the game, but not sure if I'm a hero or just an overpowered immortal lab rat
> Decide to continue side quests, because who needs closure?
> Realize I've spent 100 hours on this game, loving every second
> "Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning" is like a mixed bag of Skittles
> Sometimes it's sweet, sometimes it's sour, but always colorful and full of surprises
> 10/10 would respawn as a science experiment again. [/b]

148430057.review:
Starting Amalur in 2023. The last newcomer I bet. 

I posted this originally in discussion and realized this was the place for my humble words.

I recently found this game in my steam library having forgotten it's purchase ~5 years ago. 

With over 100 days in wow characters, this is such a fun find! And this post, just a silly, heartfelt shout of appreciation into the void beyond the cycle.

I read "things I wish I knew" - kind of guides a bit before i got started; I wish I had not. 

Letting the world and systems unfold themselves in the game has been rewarding. You can't make mistakes, just happy accidents.

"Read. Listen, Explore" has been my approach. The world is rich, story-laden and well told. Combat is enough to provide danger in most fights while also letting the power of a solid build come through (lvl 9 now starting Glendara / Haxhi). There's something about it that reminds me of BioMutant.

Just fun to play. Well done!

did not care for this game so I will place here a recipe for huckleberry pancakes instead.

Huckleberry pancakes.

1 3/4 cups all purpose white flour
4 tablespoons sugar
1 tablespoon baking powder
1/4 teaspoon salt
1 1/2 cups of buttermilk
5 tablespoon butter, melted
2 large eggs
1/2 cup Huckleberries
In medium bowl combine flour, sugar, baking powder and salt, set aside. In small bowl combine buttermilk, butter and eggs. Add buttermilk mixture to the flour mixture, combine until mixed do not over mix (I prefer to use a whisk it does the best job). Fry at 400 degrees. Pour about 1/4 cup of batter on the griddle and sprinkle with the huckleberries.

Cook on first side about 3 minutes until bubbles appear along the edge of the pancake. Flip and cook for 2 minutes more and golden brown. Serve with a big pat of butter, and some pure maple syrup ( get the real stuff it is worth it).

142588971.review:
A Majestic Journey into the Realm of Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning 

Step right up, brave gamers, for a once-in-a-lifetime adventure into the enchanting Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning! Prepare yourself to be astounded, for this game will take your breath away, leaving you hungry for more with its immersive world and captivating gameplay.

From the moment I set foot in Amalur, I knew I was in for a grand experience. The sheer brilliance of the universe crafted by the imaginative minds behind this game is awe-inspiring. Diverse landscapes painted with vibrant colors and intricate details engulf you, pulling you into a world filled with mystical creatures, treacherous quests, and ancient secrets waiting to be unearthed.

The gameplay is a true masterpiece, blending hack-and-slash combat with role-playing elements in the most seamless way imaginable. The combat mechanics grant you the freedom to experiment with various play styles, whether you prefer the brute strength of a warrior, the nimble finesse of a rogue, or the arcane fury of a mage. Every blow you strike feels impactful and satisfying, making battles an exhilarating dance of skill and strategy.

But what truly makes Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning stand head and shoulders above the rest is its exceptional storytelling. Every corner of this marvelous realm is littered with rich lore and compelling characters who will leave an indelible mark on your journey. Each quest you undertake feels like a small saga within the larger tapestry, leaving you emotionally invested in the outcomes and consequences.

More than a game, Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is an experience that rewards exploration and curiosity. Hidden treasures, forgotten ruins, and captivating narratives await those willing to wander off the beaten path. It's a world where your choices matter, shaping the destiny of not just your character, but the whole realm itself.

Oh, did I mention the musical score? Prepare to have your ears serenaded by a symphony of harmonious melodies that effortlessly capture the essence of the game's epic undertones. From hauntingly beautiful ballads to adrenaline-pumping orchestrations, the music adds a layer of enchantment that enchants your senses and elevates the whole immersive experience.

In conclusion, Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a shining gem in the vast sea of video games. It combines breathtaking visuals, exhilarating gameplay, captivating storytelling, and a mesmerizing score to create an unforgettable adventure. Prepare to lose yourself in the mesmerizing realm of Amalur and emerge forever changed. Go ahead, fellow gamers, and embark on this majestic journey that will leave you enthralled and yearning for more.

140792256.review:
Recomiendo el juego, sin embargo:

El entorno del juego deja que desear, tanto visualmente como en cantidad. La calidad es parecido al de un MMO, por ejemplo, una zona boscosa es amplia y grande con poco detalle y las proporciones y estilo de los enemigos también recuerdan a los de un MMO.

La variedad de enemigos y recursos es pequeña, encontraras las mismas plantas y enemigos ya estés en el bosque o en el desierto. Con pequeñas excepciones como hongos apareciendo en cuevas. En mi opinión, esto acaba por afectar tu deseo de explorar mediante las misiones secundarias más simples. 

Hablando de ellas, la historia principal y sus misiones son buenas, así como las historias secundarias y sus misiones que siempre son interesantes de hacer y divertidas. Sin embargo, las misiones con la categoría de tareas se acaban por hacer arduas. Deje de hacerlas tras llegar a la tercera zona del juego, la simplicidad del entorno y los repetitivos enemigos le quitan la gracia a estas misiones/tareas ya que no sienten que estés encontrando nuevos desafíos o descubriendo algo nuevo. 

Por otro lado, la jugabilidad es muy divertida con combinaciones de ataques que requieren de habilidad y de escoger el momento justo, sin embargo, incluso en la mayor dificultad que te deja escoger el juego se hace excesivamente fácil. No quita esto el placer del combate ya que aunque no haga ninguna falta que tengas finura alguna al combatir, es muy satisfactorio matar a un grupo de enemigos con los golpes justos, habiendo bloqueado todos los ataques hacia tu persona.

En definitiva, merece la pena. La historia principal y el mundo creado son interesantes aunque no de la calidad de otros juegos como Dragon Age, pero desde luego le he sacado las pesetas al juego con 62 horas de juego habiendo completado la historia principal y todas las secundarias que me he encontrado con gusto. Aunque ya al final no me quedaban muchas ganas de seguir echando horas al juego.

Por ultimo, si el juego te acaba absorbiendo más que a mi, estoy seguro que le podrás sacar muchas más horas que yo.

140739035.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is an action RPG game developed by Big Huge Games and 38 Studios, and published by Electronic Arts. It was released in 2012 for PC, Xbox 360, and PS3. The game takes place in the fictional world of Amalur and follows the story of a character known as "the Fateless One."

The game features an open-world environment that players can explore, along with a variety of side quests and activities to complete. The combat system is based on different fighting styles and allows players to customize their character's abilities and weapons. The game also has a crafting system that allows players to create new items and gear.

One of the most impressive aspects of Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is its world-building. The game is set in a unique and detailed universe, filled with various races, factions, and lore. The story is well-written and engaging, with a strong emphasis on player choice and consequence. The game also features a memorable cast of characters, each with their own backstory and motivations.

The combat in Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is fast-paced and exciting, with a variety of moves and abilities to master. The game offers several different classes to choose from, including warrior, mage, and rogue, each with its own unique playstyle. Players can also mix and match abilities from different classes, allowing for a high degree of customization.

The graphics and art style in Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning are impressive, with a colorful and detailed world that is a pleasure to explore. The game's soundtrack is also excellent, with a sweeping orchestral score that complements the game's epic story and setting.

Overall, Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a highly enjoyable and well-crafted RPG game that offers hours of engaging gameplay and exploration. Its strong world-building, memorable characters, and fast-paced combat make it a must-play for fans of the genre.

137256243.review:
GRAPHICS AND SOUND:
KOA goes for a very World of Warcraft type of visual aesthetic which I dig. The weapons and armour variety is insane, and you will often catch yourself play digital dress up. Battles and powers are flashy with a lot of colours and effects jumping out of the screen in a vibrant glorious mess. The audio is passable, nothing that really sets its apart. Music does a good job at suspending your awe or making you feel like God amongst mortal, as the situation demands.

PLOT AND WORLD BUILDING:
The very name of the game gives hints about what you can expect from the game: needless padding. The main story itself is serviceable but the game tries to pull a James Cameron and over-saturate itself with characters and plot threads that end abruptly. There are plenty of times you will be paying attention to a lore dump given by the NPC, thinking it will be important but its importance just ends after the side quest is over. There are so many characters and "heroes" that pop up with their own expositions (which are long and windy) but then disappear completely off the face of the map after you finish whatever quest was associated with it. The game tries very hard to provide a deep lore but does absolutely nothing to sustain the legacy of its own characters and events. So the game becomes an exercise in jumping from one exposition to another collecting names that will never turn up again. 

To be fair, they made an honest go at the world building. It is a shame that they chose quantity over quality. If someone picks up this IP again, I hope they cut off the fat because I see great potential.

GAMEPLAY:
After the first few hours you will begin to realise that most of your abilities and combos are very, very lacklustre. This problem exacerbates itself as you gain levels and your abilities don't seem to change much (except of course the bigger damage numbers). It is frustrating to see enemy minions having cooler powers than your over levelled self. Many of the big spells you have turns you into a turret that can shoot in a linear line, and that ice beam you threw has a high chance of missing the enemy because the enemy was just a head above or below you. Yes...many of your spells cannot be aimed along the y axis. Oh..and your character cannot jump.

LEVEL DESIGN/MAP:
Just like its story and lore, the map of KOA:Reckoning is quite expansive with plenty of side quests and collectables spread all across. But the game play itself is so lacking that the map becomes a jogging simulator. There is absolutely nothing to do except go from one quest marker to another. Exploration results in no reward except for maybe some cool screen shots (there are quite a few cool looking locations). To its credit, there are a lot of different biomes in the game that look very different from each other. But they all play the same way. And remember my little comment on how you couldn't jump in this game? Yeah....that will come back to bite you in the ass multiple times. You see, this game doesn't let you fall off  the edge unless you are in a specific spot and press a button prompt, where your character will proceed to superhero land down to the lower level. So imagine the frutration when you need to go to a lower level but your character won't fall off the 3 foot drop unless you trek all the way towards the "jump off point". Did you imagine it? Good....now imagine you dropping off to the lower level but then realising you left a cool weapon on the upper level you jumped off from. There is no jump button so all the way around the "cliff" you go. It is hilarious to see your character, a spell slinging bad ass who gets bested by a knee high fence or a tree root.

OVERALL:
Although this game does have its moments, they are often lost in the long grind that will absolutely exhaust you. I can understand why there are quite a few fans of this game who sing praises for it, but in my humble opinion...this game isn't really worth your time and effort. Maybe pick it up when it is dirt cheap. Otherwise, don't bother.

136419097.review:
I love this game honestly. It is a cool single player ARPG with World of Warcraft level of graphics. It has plenty of customization for your character and playstyles along with a pretty large map to cover different environments so it doesn't feel stagnant after hours of playing.

But what stop me playing after 37 hrs of gaming was the game-breaking bug of "run-stutter" where you start having issues of your character freeze every 2-3 seconds or a few steps. As if you are lagging badly on a online MMO and you see your character stop moving every few seconds. I scour online for ways to fix this but no joy. Only solution is to restart from an earlier save and play back from there. I checked my last "playable" save file was done 8 hours ago and after like so many hours of lost gameplay....I gave up and probaby will stop playing this game.

If only I knew of this bug earlier and I would have make multiple saves every hour instead of saving over those 2-3 save slots that I have an habit of doing.

If you see this review of mine, please do go ahead and buy this game but make sure you save often and in different save slots before you eventually get the bug.

Linear game world, but incredibly large and varied landscapes. Great class customization and well designed skill trees. Fantastic visuals and interesting characters. Ever growing paths of story line to be fulfilled at your pace. And very engaging combat. If you like an adventure game with action combat and an enthralling atmosphere, KoAR is a great game to fill that desire. I hesitate to make a direct comparison to Fable and WoW because I think it degrades the unique style of this game, but I say it with great respect for all 3 titles. 132222159.review:
Garbage time-consuming walking simulator.

Boring quests and uninspired story.
Questing is VERY overwhelming in this game. You get quest, on quest, on quest, on quest.
If you've ever played an MMORPG you probably have experience with the kinds of quest you get in this game.

The world is empty and unfinished.
90% of enemies/zones/quest structures/character models are recycled.
It feels like playing an old MMORPG that's long since died and you're the only person still playing it, giving you a profound sense of loneliness while doing so.
You will be killing the same damned monsters from the beginning of the game to the end of the game, it's absolutely ridicoulous, there are like 6/7 types of monsters so let's repeat the killing again and again and again.

They don't put much effort into getting you interested in the story, which is needed in this game since you get so many story side-quests. 
Sometimes you end up doing a quest and out nowhere find out it was apparently a huge part to the main story, but unless you're really reading and listening to every single NPC on the way you won't get anything from it.

Garbage map design.
Maps are made for the purpose of wasting you time.
They are very unintuitive, confusing and irrational.

Garbage graphics.
Everything is not appealing and most of the times blurry.

Garbage sound.
Some of them probably recorded in a bathroom or in a local sewerage.

Garbage controls and clunky movement.
Most of the time you can't even target an enemy, because you have to look straight forward on him with you camera.

Garbage camera.
One of the worst angles in gaming history.
Rotates like a rusty faucet.

No interesting/memorable characters.
Not a single NPC will attract your attention.
Everyone feels copy-pasted, just with a different texture/model.

Atrocious inventory and items system.
The amount of trash equipment you get makes it a chore to find anything. 
You spend more time going through trash than you do comparing which weapon to use.

Typical console garbage.

131057190.review:
KoA: Reckoning was certainly one of the RPGs of all time.

Did it have combat? Sure.
Did it have crafting? Yep.
Did it have quests? Technically.
Was there a plot? Uh-huh.
Was it a finished game on release? Basically.

Did it do anything poorly? By no means.
Did it do anything particularly well? Not really.

In retrospect, one might view KoA: Reckoning as a trend-chaser and not a trend-setter. If it were not for sharing the same release window as SKYRIM, which did everything above exponentially better, it might have stood a chance. But instead, as it stands KoA: Reckoning faded into oblivion for its meh mechanics, meh story, and meh reception.

It's not bad, but its not necessarily good either. Try it on sale if you're bored.

125321025.review:
This review is for the original Kingdoms of Amalur, not the remastered. The amount of lore, world building, and quests that went into this game is borderline absurd. You can't run anywhere without running into a sidequest and the books/notes are very well fleshed out. But that kind of creates a problem within the gameplay because, by the time I was only about 25% through, I had already stopped listening to the characters and was skipping through the dialogue because there was so much of it and it was very time consuming. And because there are so many quests, and the DLC's for this game, my character was level-capped by the time I hit the mid-point. And that was almost a good thing because I simply ran the last half of the game. Literally. I explored each territory without fighting as best I could unless it was quest required. And it saved me so much time and effort. If I had tried to entirely clear the territories, the game probably would have taken an additional 20+ hours to complete.

This is a very, very, big RPG. And it was fun until it level capped me so soon and killed my drive to explore the game beyond what I needed to beat it.

I basically grew up with this game. My dad let me play it at quite a young age and it never really left my mind since then.
I finished it once i was older and holy sh*t was it amazing. 
I loved every second of it. Probably more because of nostalgia, but even the atmosphere and how the world is designed just makes me so happy.
I especially loved the elf village, it looked amazing. Everything looked so green and fresh, I was so mesmerized by it when i first saw it when i was really young.
I also liked, that you are able to mix up your classes. There are 3 classes (knight, thief, mage) and you can either go with only one class as full expert, or you can mix up two, or even all three classes.
If you don't like the way you played before, you can reset your fate (class) and you can concentrate on a different way to play your character.
The only downside i noticed tho, was once you reach the other world map, the story line gets really rushed.
But even then it was quite fun. Just, you know, faster than the previous half.
I can heavily recommend it, the graphics are really nice and the story is quite nice. The gameplay is also really really fun.

124357991.review:
[h1] Fateless? Story? [/h1]
Basic premise/Story

As a fan of RPG games. Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning didn’t come onto my radar until I had done extensive research on what it is. A huge open world, with multiple classes beyond three base classes. Dozens of sidequests, faction quests, and with a complete storyline. Lots of loot to discover and you can even rob NPCs as well. The game pretty much checks off everything I want in an open-world RPG game. And yet as the end credits roll I’m left with a sense of dissatisfaction at the end. Although, I still retained an equal amount of satisfaction. There’s a lot the game does well. But the game suffers from its ambitions as well. Let’s break it down. 

[h1]A Reckoning of Issues [/h1]
Unique Gameplay

First, the story is decent. It's nothing earth-shattering. But as the main character the Fateless one. You go off into the world of the Firelands. Resurrected against your will and with no knowledge of your past life. Surely this would be a massive incentive to know who you are? Well no. The main character becomes embroiled in the world’s affairs. Where the Tuatha Deohn is waging an all-out war on all the other mortal races. You become the unwilling(but willingly) recipient/punching bag/errand guy/gal to do the bidding of other individuals. Case in point. You gotta do other people favors before you can get your own sh** together and find out what happened to you. And most importantly why?

As you can see it's not a strong selling point to take the main character with amnesia neck deep into a large sprawling fantasy world who needs your services. Which can make you completely forget your background and wonder why the Tuatha Deohn is such a threat to all other inhabitants in the Faelands. Granted one could argue that there isn’t a strong story because the world and its inhabitants serve as a conduit for the main character to live and partake in. And it is the world itself that is so fascinating… At least to an extent.

The world of the Faelands is ginormous and filled with enemies, fantasy creatures, dungeons, sidequests, living towns/cities with NPCs with routines, shops, and more. The game is packed full of content and is quite an impressive achievement from a studio I’ve never heard about. Which can be compared to large worlds such as Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion. However, this also serves as the game’s weakest strength. The world can be filled to the brim. As long as it's with purpose. And I mean meaningful purpose. 

For starters, the game has too many sidequests which can be in the category of killing ‘x’ enemy/s finding ‘x’ and bringing back ‘y’, etc. Some are more important than others and serve as an excellent way to enhance worldbuilding. But there are far too many and while it's easy to ignore and not do. It quickly becomes apparent some side quests such as Faction quests stand out a bit more than the average quests. 

Movement is a pain in the world. Since you can only run and fast travel to locations you’ve been to. There is no mount available. So you have to run from one place to the next which can take some time and you can’t take shortcuts since the main character cannot jump. Except in certain spots in the overworld. 

The camera can also be kinda wonky when you’re running where the field of view can switch abnormally from a far point of view to a somewhat respectable distance away from your main character. This is prevalent many times as I was running past enemies to get to my destination due to how large the overworld is. I do not need to face enemies and yet the camera thinks I want to fight. No lock-on feature as well. So you’ll have to manually control the camera when fighting enemies. This becomes especially troublesome for many moments I want to dodge but inadvertently dodge in the wrong way due to the camera not being in sync with me. 

I did have a couple of instances where my character would lock up in place while I was not in combat and just running. Had to reload the game to fix it. But having the troublesome bug occur again later on. It is weird. 

The enemy design needs more variety and uniqueness. Found them to be predictable and copy-paste too much for my liking. If I’ve seen them in the overworld. I don’t need to see them again in another part of the map. Or in a main quest or side quest again. When it's not suited for the enemy. To the point, I would guess what enemy awaited me in the dungeon and I could guess it right 9 times out of ten. Yikes. 

I don’t like inventory limits. The game fills your inventory with miscellaneous items, weapons, armor, consumables, etc. Only had about 90 inventory spaces. But I was filled to the brim up to 79. And I’ve already taken the liberty of cleaning out space full of non-essentials. Carrying only what I would use. And still, it’s not enough to carry more. Especially for materials to upgrade/craft my own armor/weapon and more. The limitation is especially egregious since I’m not a hoarder, and yet I was stoked at every turn of the game to clean my inventory. Granted there is a nifty feature to turn such items into junk and destroy it. But I'm going to have to use it every 5-10 min. Then I believe there is a problem with the inventory limit. 

And yet, all these issues aside. Did I at least have fun with the game? Well…

[h1] Amalur’s Double-Edged Sword [/h1]
Final thoughts/Ruminations

I did. Despite the issues, I stated above. The game is still fun to play because there is so much content to do. I dived super deep into the sidequests and faction quests forgetting about the main story quest entirely. It wasn’t until I had accrued over 60 quests did I start to wonder. “Oh wait, I still have the main quests to do.” I had fun making conversation with individuals and convincing them successfully with my persuasion skill or failing would lead to some interesting outcomes(usually fights). Helped the folks around who needed a helping hand like a goody-two-shoes. Decided to be for one day and started robbing shopkeepers' chests. And accidentally choosing more rude conversation responses than the opposite ones… Oops… 

Running to new places can be a pain especially if they’re far away. But at least there is fast travel to help me go back to previously known areas. Helps immensely for backtracking. 

Technically issues didn’t impact me in a major way throughout my playthrough. There were some moments when I was free of any bugs.

The enemy design variety could be improved to not reuse the same formula. But as long as you take breaks it is not a major pain in the butt. 

The world is so dense helps in such a way you can easily get lost and since there are plenty of side quests you can easily do them to pass the time. 

Inventory issue aside. If you don’t loot everything you see then the limited inventory space isn’t an issue. That is if you don’t mind potentially missing out on something valuable because you didn’t take the time to check it… Anyways…

Suffice it to say, Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a mixed bag for me. But ultimately a good mixed bag. I enjoyed the incredibly huge world and lore surrounding it. Combat is pretty satisfying. The ability to change your classes into other professions makes the gameplay fresh and exciting. And changing classes was painless and easy. While I could do without the issues I've already mentioned above. The game still hits decently well for players who are looking for a big open-world RPG to sink their hours into. Just don’t go into this looking for an epic story. the world and the inhabitants are the main stars of the game. 

Total Times Beaten: 1
Score: 7/10

124073963.review: Yes. Still very good after all these years. I LOVE the combat and ability to mix up magic/melee/range and do cool combs. Very satisfying.

124062493.review:
If you don't know the whole story that went into this game and the company behind it I'd really recommend looking up a vid on youtube somewhere as it's a really interesting story.

With that said I'd give the game a 9/10. It's not very difficult but the sheer size of a project like this is really impressive. I would've liked it to play less like a quest grinding rpg. Anything that wasn't a main story quest or a faction quest was just a kill or gather kind of quest. It is kind of a shame because it makes a lot of the zones less interesting than they appear visually, there just ends up not being new things to do in the new zones you go to. I had a lot of fun with the main story and all the fae house questlines and I know there are plenty of quests that I probably missed as well as a whole other faction questline that I didn't even do. You'll absolutely get your money's worth in terms of the content you get from the game, the main story questline alone is probably enough for 30+ hours of play.

There's so much more that can be said about the game and the story behind it, but really I'd just say play it for yourself. It's a really unique experience due to it's whole production process and it's worth it for that alone.

This game deserves so much more love, in my opinion.
Yes, it is an open world RPG. No, it's not a Skyrim imitation. (No matter what critics say.)
If anything, I get immense Fable vibes in the music, graphics and combat style.
If you love Questing, then this is a great game. KOA has a massive amount of Sidequests, that can be overwhelming. Positive on all the Quests is, that you get to know more about the situation in Amalur and how it impacts the people in it.
Another good point in this story is that as the protagonist, you realize and get to experience how you upset the balance of the world. Just because you shouldn't exist anymore.

The most negative point are for me, that the controls are a bit wacky until you get the hang of it and you can't really zoom in and out.
A little bit of a con for me is the missing tracking of your achievement status. But that's not really relevant. (And it was fixes in Re-Reckoning)

Btw. please don't let the voiceacting in the prologue drive you away. It will get better after that part is over.

119384897.review:
This game is actually great fun and done well but I have to give it a thumbs down because it plateaus out and gets boring due to a lack of meaningful content and a lack of diversity in locations/enemies/gameplay.  

The Irish/Celtic setting is a neat idea since you dont really see tons of content in the Fey universe in fantasy games but it needs a lot more content though.  Give me radically different settings here!  Not flat green hills, to rolling hills to moutains. I mean give me like Diablo 2 where you go from Transylvania woodlands to Egyptian sand dunes to the fires of Hell in just 3 levels.  Now thats diversity!!

This is a LONG game and it gets really boring fighting similar enemies with similar attacks over and over.  The quests get boring and repetitive.  The loot is all the same.  The only plus is that you can respec often to change up the gameplay.  I highly suggest you change class every 8 hours of playtime or so to keep it interesting or else you are going to get really bored doing the same attacks over and over. 

The lack of bosses is also a huge negative.  They could have easily thrown in a bunch of big boss encounters to spice up the gameplay and make it less boring.  Yes there are a few bosses here and there, but not nearly enough and the memorable ones are few and far between.   No a reskinned mob with double HP doesnt count as a boss, I'm talking scripted unique content here. 

Anyways if you really wnat to try this game get the improved edition, and try to change class often.  Its actually a pretty fun game.  Just dont expect the game to change as you progress.  Its only more of the same.

[b]Re-reckoning review below:[/b]
Contrary to what people might tell you, there's nothing wrong with the re-reckoning edition of this game. I've actually spent more hours on that than this version (didn't buy on Steam) and had a blast just like in the original. However, if you own this version, save your money and pass up re-reckoning. Everything you need is already here. If you didn't buy any of the dlc before they were removed from the store, you're not missing out on much. I'd say only The Legend of Dead Kel was worth playing, but only if you like the idea of owning an island.
The new Fatesworn dlc they hyped up as the main selling point of re-reckoning is also nothing but terrible fetch quests, and it's chaos system only serves to interrupt combat. I'd say the only positive is that it's a nice looking location, adds 2 new backpacks, and extends the level cap from 40 to 50, though this is all overkill really. Unfortunately the fetch questing became so absurd that I just abandoned Fatesworn entirely. I didn't want to find 5 armor pieces, each locked behind a chaos portal dungeon, which were each locked behind their own large dungeons.

108517570.review:
I originally played this on the PS3. Playing it now with all of the DLC is still amazing. The only changes in the new version are improvements on the graphics, a new harder difficulty setting, a new separate DLC (which a lot of people seem to hate, just check it's reviews) and how tough enemies spawn in when entering an area (which is the biggest difference of all of these, so I will elaborate on that further) but if none of that is a deal breaker to you, just buy this version unless you can somehow get the newer one for the same price or cheaper.

[spoiler]
To further describe how the new version changes enemy spawns, first you have to learn that all areas have a level range. The level range is the range of possible levels used by the game to determine the difficulty of enemies in a given area. The level of your enemies also determines how much experience you earn when you beat them. The range of levels varies between areas (and can vary based on your difficulty settings, if I recall correctly).
When you enter an area for the first time, your character's level at that moment is saved into that area in your save file permanently for that character. If your current level is less than the minimum or greater than the maximum, then the game instead will save the minimum or maximum level respectively. Afterwards, any time you come back to that area, no matter what level you are, it will still spawn in enemies at whatever level is saved to your file for that area.
This means if you run around aimlessly at the start of the game, or are simply excited to explore the big open world, you could easily end up permanently locking large chunks of the game to their minimum levels and end up having to grind for experience points in the early sections, which can be rather tedious. Additionally this can cause some difficulty spikes in the early game if you ran through a few areas of the game early, did most of the quests and dungeons in those areas, and then went on to a new area.
As an example, if you went to every area in the first section of the game (Dalentarth), you could easily end up fighting off level 3 enemies for the entirety of the first 8 areas of the game and then, when you decide to move on to a new location roughly 6-16 hours later after you've done all of the quests in those areas, you could then suddenly be facing level 13 enemies.
This has caused some players to feel like they are forced to do all quests and dungeons in an area before moving on to the next and to be overly careful not to go into new areas, for fear of the above situation. That said though, the game is not very grind-y, experience points do come fairly easily, and even if the difficulty does spike in such a situation, it is technically spiking up to your current level and shouldn't be anything you can't handle since the game is fairly balanced.
In the new version, whenever you enter an area, the game doesn't save your level to it. It just makes enemy calculations based on your level in the level range whenever you entered the area. If you stay and level up, it will still be based on the level you entered; However, If you leave and come back, It will then take your new current level for calculations instead. This way an area will never be too easy or too hard unless you are above or below the area's level range.
[/spoiler]

TL;DR, In this version, each area will save the level you first entered it at. That level will forever be used to determine the difficulty of enemies in that area. If you explore too much too early, this can cause some problems for the early game, but they are negligible because of the game's balance. In the new version, the game simply recalculates enemy difficulty every time you enter an area, effectively removing any of these possible problems.

This genuinely changes gameplay as now you can freely move between more areas doing whatever quests in them in whatever order without the fear of making things too easy or, worse, making some players feel like you have to do every little thing in one area when you first reach it or else when you come back, it will give you little to no XP.

The graphics may be higher resolution, but the game has a very distinct style of its' own that many feel isn't that impacted by resolution changes (I played this on a 50 inch TV on PS3 in 2012 and a 60 inch TV now. It still holds up). The harder difficulty will not change the way you play, at least not that much from playing on just hard mode. And as I said before, the new DLC is not well liked by many in the community.

106086742.review:
So I finally finished Kingdoms of Amalur. Prompted by the release of the remaster "Rereckoning", I started playing in January. I have beaten 5 other games on the side while trying to make my way to the end of this game. It isn't even the longest single playthrough I've clocked in a game, with Skyrim somehow coming out to 90 hours and KoA clocking in at 75, but it somehow felt so much longer than it really was. At the end of this epic journey, I am a little torn. The game is so close to greatness in its genre mash-up open world style, but still so frustratingly far away.

The Tuatha are at war with the people of Amalur. A sect of a race of immortals known as Fae, the Tuatha have been leading a crusade against mortal-kind and others of their kind, lead by a Fae known as Gadflow. The mortal races have held their own for decades, but while the mortals losses are irreplaceable, the Tuatha simply resurrect their forces and begin the war anew. In a desperate attempt to reverse the inevitable tide of the war, a gnome works to replicate Fae immortality but is met with only failure until you defy fate and rise from the dead.

KoA could best be described as a sort of weird fusion between World of Warcraft (Art Style), Skyrim (Persistent Open World, numerous skill systems), Darksiders (Combat), and an ARPG like Torchlight (Paperdoll Loot System, all quests available for all builds). On the whole these different elements fuse together quite nicely and make KoA really feel like its own thing.

The game also has an excellent classless (or more like Class-Fluid) RPG system that deftly balances its three Warrior/Mage/Rogue archetypes to allow players to go all in on one class, create hybrid classes or even go full universalist (my personal favorite). Depending on the number of points you have in any of the three skill trees, you unlock "fates" which are basically class specializations that provide bonuses depending on your point distribution among the three trees. For example, put points into Warrior and Mage and unlock the "Battlemage" specialization, put points across the Warrior/Mage/Rogue trees equally and unlock the "Polymath" fate. So on and so on.

This makes for extremely entertaining arcade/actiony gameplay that is fast and fun and really lets you spec out your character as you see fit. Light armor and daggers for sneak attacks, supplemented by berserker rage when things go south? Sure. Want to do a sword and board paladin that does the parry/strike thing with healing potential? Sure. You want to go all out mage and have access to the beefiest spells in the game? Sure.

Of course, to supplement this system are your standard assortment of skills: smithing, Gem crafting, Alchemy, stealth, etc...

The downside of such a broad system is, as you might have guessed, the game is absurdly easy as it wants to encourage diverse builds and as such never really puts anything in your way that makes any permutation of your build non-viable. Enemies die quick, no quests are gated behind skills or ability or speech checks, and if you ever go down the blacksmith and crafting paths, you're character will quickly outgrow enemies even several levels above you.

The game also lacks some of Skyrim's emergent gameplay. Yes, there are a lot of game systems at work, people have wake/sleep cycles, etc, but its all superficial, none of these systems interact with each other to create weird/novel occurrences that add to the charm of the game. There is no "use poison on apple, wait till victim eats it an dies" sort of stuff here.

Lastly, the game starts out fast with a host of options and paths to take your PC down but then bogs down significantly in the middle portion of the game as you're reasonably invested in a build and the game sort of runs out of new things to show you and the gameplay loop starts to get stale. The back end of the game gets interesting on account of the story really picking up pace, two fun boss fights to really shake things up, and way more interactions with the antagonist and more "grey" factions. Its unfortunate that by that point most players will be 40-50 hours into the game and ready to just beeline it to the ending.

When all is said and done, I did enjoy my time with Kingdoms of Amalur. The game is easy on the eyes, fun and fast paced, has excellent production values in its narrative, story, and the voice acting is superb. Its just too much. I would have much four 20 hour playthroughs, than one monster 80 hour playthrough and maybe some day developers will cater to an audience like me.

Given the remaster was launched and the property was purchased by THQ, i hope there is some sort of sequel in the planning stages out there. With some refinement, KoA can have it all. All the elements are there for true greatness, they just need to gel together a bit more.

Seriously--get this game, you won't be disappointed.

100408960.review:
Note that I am talking all from the experience of playing a warrior with only might attributes.

I actually like everything about this game except the combat. And combat takes up 90% of the game...so...that's a lot.

Firstly, I'd like to say, this is the first game that I've seen that actually encourages spending skill points in the three skill trees (might, finesse, sorcery). As such the customization is rather extensive. That goes for creating the look of your character as well.

There are plenty of weapon types and armor/accessories that can help you further customize to create a play style that works for you.

I didn't follow the storyline, because it's one of those that presents you with a lot of text or you can sit around and wait for the voice acting to finish up. Then you are presented with multiple responses and the talking can go on and on. This is typical in longer rpg's, and I never pay attention for I find it boring.

Now anyway, back to the combat. As I said, I played as a warrior type and swung around a big heavy hammer. This made the game feel Souls-Like, but at the same time the gameplay was hack'n'slash/dungeon crawler as well. And it did not mix well.

In order to not get hit, the game would prefer you to do one attack, dodge, and repeat this as many times as needed. But each hit in a combo does substantially more damage than the last, so you want to get those big hits, so risking getting hit was worth it to me. Plus it's boring the other way. This is okay for fighting a couple of enemies, but when you get to the big groups, combat can be a nightmare.

At times, the enemies can get into a rhythm that one attacks, followed by another, followed by another, so on and so forth. If you get hit, it takes 1-3 seconds to recover, so you'll get stuck like that, which is incredibly annoying.

Speaking of annoying, just about every enemy in the game can be described as such. Especially flying enemies. These buggers always float away from you, and it can be a real chore to get close enough to them to hit them with my giant hammer.

But none compare to the mages (they fly too). One by themselves is okay, but when there are three or more, you're in for a nightmarish fight. They have shields that block your skill to pull them close to you all Scorpion style, and bombard you with tornadoes and fireballs. You're too busy getting hit or shielding or dodging to ever move closer to one of them, and when you finally reach one, they teleport away. This makes me...frown.

When they want to ramp up the difficulty with "tougher" enemies, they just make them have really high armor so that your attacks do about 1/4 what they normally do. Full disclosure, this does not add to the difficulty, all it does is add to the time I have to spend playing this game, which in turn adds to my anger and annoyance.

You do get a variety of skills depending on how you spend your skill points. These can help you out in combat. For instance, the warrior gets a battle cry skill, that when fully upgraded can knock people down. "Oh cool!" I say, excited for the prospects this could have in battle. But woe is me, for the animation is so long for the move, that any enemies who got knocked over are back up before you can move again. So this tells me that fully upgrading this skill rewards you with guaranteeing you won't get hit while using it and nothing else. Thanks devs. That's mighty generous of you!

Another such skill is upgrading to potentially stun someone and doing more damage to said stunned folk.
On the extremely rare occasion something does get stunned, they are only stunned until you hit them, so whoopdeedoo, I get to do more damage for one whole attack! Those are points well spent, I tell you!

Another useless thing coming at you- almost every weapon has some type of elemental damage included. So  if my hammer does poison or fire damage, it just adds to the hurting on some enemies over time. Except it does 1-2 damage per second for like 10 seconds. You can wear gear or something to increase this damage, but the highest I saw was a 20% increase. I may have barely passed algebra but I'm pretty sure a 20% increase to 1 is 1.2. That's some saucy DOT!

The combat is very repetitive as well. I didn't mind this aspect so much, but I know a lot of people do, so I thought I'd mention it.

Otherwise, it's a nice, big world, filled with interesting races of NPC's, lots of side quests that lead you to all sorts of places and have you kill all manner of (annoying) creatures. 

Who knows, if I had gone another route entirely with my character build, I could have loved this game.

99896675.review:
It's weird...I bought this when it was new on console, so long ago I don't even remember which console it was. I never made it more than 3 hours in before putting it aside, forgetting about it, and moving on.

When it popped up on Steam, I remembered it. Bought it again. Played it, lost interest, put it down again.

Tried again a couple years later. Same thing.

5 years later, I decided to give it one more go, determined that I'd finally go deeper than 3 hours this time. From the beginning, though, this playthrough felt different. I found it far more compelling than ever before. Can't say why, because I still see lots of things that annoy me: The abundance of flowers to pluck, but most of them resulting in "No Reagents Found". The janky camera that sometimes freaks out in tight places and always, always swings too fast to center behind me. The sluggish combat controls that make blocking difficult when you've just finished an attack. The closeness of the camera to the character that makes it difficult to judge distance sometimes. The inventory screen, which is boring and tedious to navigate. The list goes on...

But for some reason, I'm enjoying it, anyway. Maybe I'm more patient now that I'm 10 years older. Who knows. In any case, Kingdoms of Amalur answers the question:

What would an MMORPG look like if you were the only person playing?

I may well lose interest somewhere along the way again, but I'm having fun playing this, finally. The world seems large, but fast-travel points are abundant, so you can move around pretty quickly.

If you haven't bought it, buy the Re-Reckoning version.

99525068.review:
KoA:R is clearly a labour of love. The setting is a pretty standard high fantasy fair, complete with different races, a medieval vibe and the usual type of monsters that you would expect to see. There's a lot of interesting designs and whatnot that are present here that give the game a fresh flavour within the parameters of a pretty standard high fantasy setting, such as the elf like Alfar, the trollish Bolgans, etc. Essentially there is fresh coat of paint over the standard dungeons and dragons type stuff you'd expect, where the archetypes are there but presented differently to fit within the game's lore, and the designs are superb (the art direction in general is awesome) 

The lore is really what makes this game shine, in my opinion. This is a world that is very very fleshed out, with lots of books and stuff to read, a rich history, towns and cities and fortresses with their own flavours, different climate zones and so on. They really did a great job in making the world feel believable and lived in, and if you are into that sort of exploring and getting immersed in the world, then I think you will get a kick out of this.

As mentioned previously, the art direction is really really nice. The graphics hold up today, despite some low res textures and stuff, but the actual designs of the characters, towns, wildlife, weapons, etc is really great. It is a somewhat cartoony style, so if you aren't into that then you might not like it, but if you are I suspect you'll find it to be quite charming. The game is also very colourful, there's always something beautiful to look at, whether that be lush grasslands, ancients forests, castles, etc. The unity of vision in the design really comes together in the finished product. 

The gameplay itself is not bad, it's super responsive and smooth so playing it does feel good. Unfortunately, it's pretty damn easy, even on hard mode and by the end, you'll be pretty well steamrolling everybody. Furthermore, the structure of how the story progresses is the same throughout. Basically you get to a hub in a new region which might be a town or an outpost of some sort, where you can buy and sell goods and get side quests. Once you do all these and proceed to the main objective its on to the next area. Because of this, 
 and the ease of the combat, I think the game sort of outstays it's welcome a bit. Although once you get to Klurikon, your progress will definitely speed up a bit.

Speaking of which, the final bit of the game seems unfinished. The final zone, Alabastra, is the only area of the game where there isn't much side quests to do. You pretty much rush through to the ending, save for a few quests here and there. There's also a few different caves and castles to go in, but there isn't much reason to explore them since there's no quest to complete and you'll have long since found your best gear by then. So to me, it seems like they sort of ran out of time/money at this point because it feels a bit empty (case in point the missing scout on the ridge... play it and you'll know what I mean). I also ran into some strange glitches around this point as well.

The ending was a bit abrupt but I think was fairly satisfying, it doesn't drag on with a long ending cinematic, but some people might find it a bit rushed. One final gripe I had is killing the final boss. You need to deal a deathblow to it, but they don't really telegraph where you need to stand in order for it to work, so it was pretty frustrating.

All in all, if you like high fantasy, want a game with decent RPG mechanics and a lush and interesting world to explore, I think it's worth checking out. It's not the best gameplay wise, and the story isn't exactly going to win any awards for originality, but it's definitely a decent game with a ton of character.

95527975.review:
Mixed feelings. The world is lush and beautiful (you can see McFarlane had a hand in that) and the attention to detail is admirable (picking herbs gets its animation as well as fatalities on different enemies). It makes you want to walk just to admire the views. The lore of the world is well planned and interesting. The side quests are quite fun to do. The dungeons are varied and look amazing. Lots of equipment with detailed elements. The sounds and music make the journey atmospheric. Change of time of the day is also a nice touch.

However, the main story is flat and uninteresting with the only revelation 5 minutes before the end of the game. The combat system doesn't promote defense and dodging. Half in the game you can practically rush or one-spell kill everyone. The dialogues are sometimes badly-recorded.

To sum up, this game could have been excellent but the main storyline is poorly staged. Only fun if you like exploring the lore and admiring the views.

Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning es un título que, a pesar de haber sido a menudo infravalorado (o, cuanto menos, desconocido por muchos), es un juego de rol de gran nivel y muy entretenido.

Tiene lugar en un universo muy atractivo que, sin ser mundo abierto, tiene grandes áreas a explorar, interconectadas unas con otras. El estilo gráfico es, en mi opinión, bastante acertado (casa perfectamente con este tipo de universo), así como la banda sonora. 

Cuenta con una trama interesante (aunque tampoco rompedora o especialmente remarcable) de duración aceptable (unas 25-30 horas de duración, solo la historia principal). 

En cuanto al combate, hay que destacar que es muy dinámico y entretenido. Además, jugablemente cuenta con un ligero toque de crafteo-artesanía.

Lamentablemente ya no está en venta (en Steam), y aquellos que lo quieran tendrán que conformarse (en Steam) con el [i]sacacuartos[/i] del Re-Reckoning, que es lo mismo, pero con más bugs y con cuatro retoques gráficos (a precio de juego nuevo, por supuesto). 94045887.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur was probably a serviceable game when it came out, but I'd say it doesn't quite hold up now.

In terms of aesthetics, the game is okay. You'll explore forests, caverns, castles, ruins, all the fantasy locations. The locations definitely look nice the first time you see them, but across the roughly 40 hour journey you're going to see it over and over.

I wasn't too invested in the lore and the story; it's just not that memorable with all these lore dumps. I feel like a month from now I'm not going to remember anything about the story or the main characters.

The combat in this game is alright, but it just takes up such a large portion of the game. You can rarely walk half a minute in any direction before being accosted and fighting for three minutes. I just 
want there to be a fair balance between combat and exploration, and it feels pretty uneven.

The part I enjoy the least about this game is the loot and level balancing. As you visit new areas, enemies will match your level, so even if you're leveling it doesn't feel like you're getting stronger. The loot also is poorly distributed, as I can loot what feels like hundreds of pieces before I find something better; it's all vendor-trash.

I put a lot of time into Amalur just to finish it, and I feel like I should've played something else.

91117699.review:
I tried to like this game. I really did. I first played the game in 2015 after it had been sitting in my backlog. When I went to play the game for the "first time" in 2021, I had completely forgotten my 15+ hours already clocked in on the game. I wondered why that was until I had gotten far enough into my 2nd run to realize why. The game feels empty.

The world map is structured exactly like an MMO except that you are by yourself and the little quirks from having tons of other people running around the same world is absent....because it's only you. Every quest is a fetch quest or a "go here and kill this" type of MMO quest. There is no quest variety whatsoever and although the game has hundreds of these quests, they barely give any XP, forcing you to primarily have to grind kills to rank up. The combat is good, but with how fast most enemies attack, slower weapons like greatswords and hammers aren't as good because you can easily get stunlocked by even low level mobs.

They clearly put a lot of effort into the world building and dialogue, which is great. The only problem is when you pair it with simplistic combat and constant fetch quests, it all kind of falls flat. After a while I just had a strong urge to skip all dialogue, which is when I realized I was done playing the game. Which is a shame, because you can tell they poured tons of effort into the game and even had top name fantasy and video game writers and developers working on it.

Most people won't see this as this review is for the delisted version of the game. However if you have this game in your backlog or are thinking of buying the remastered version and stumbled across this page, let me warn you. This game is fun for the first few hours, but if you want a deep and engaging RPG look somewhere else. Don't waste a bunch of time like I did just to test out what feels like an empty MMO.

91034557.review:
idk who will read this review/quick guide. i do hope it helps someone


[h1]Review[/h1]
Story - 6.5/10 (generous)
Music - 8.5/10
Gameplay mechanics - 8.5/10
Visuals/enviroment - 10/10 (played the game at high)

Q: Is it worth buying Re-Reckoning? 
A: No, they added glitter and Yes, if you want to play the DLC's that do not impact the main story

Q:Is it worth to pay full price for it? 
A:No, get it when there is a discount.

Q:Will your decisions impact the main story? 
A: Only impact seen was in the side/faction quests.

Q: Should I listen to every NPC and their stories/information about the place?
A: No, not really. The quests are like a straight arrow, just pay attention to the dialog. 

[b]Advice[/b]: Play the game on hard difficulty.
After the tutorial, I thought that the game seems balanced. Fast forward 10-13 levels into the game, the difficulty went from normal to easy and at the end of the game I 3 hit the last 4 bosses. (played 39str/40intel/41agi)

Other:

Best thing about this game is the fighting mechanics, where you can do all kinds of stuff and also the environment that looks good, big, making you feel that you are walking into a dungeon/cave/castle/fortress.
Main story doesn't seem that impact-full. It provides you a random reason for your death. (i haven't read all the books in the game). 
Reading books/notes, didn't help at all. Quit reading lore books/notes after 9 hours into the game. 
Same mobs, over and over and over. Except for the last 6/9(only story mode) or 20/25 hours (if you like to loot everything and do every last quest)
Unskippable cut scenes when monster suddenly appear. (fun at first, when presenting the monster. annoying afterwards)
Random bugs: got stuck between 2 chairs after talking with npc. game froze 2-3 times. unreachable loot. pixel perfect jumps/quest item loot able. quest followers resetting their place and had to backtrack.
You cannot play as a rogue.


[h1]Guide[/h1]  
At the start of your journey, you will struggle for money. Sell anything you can and do not rob, because traveler's vendors will receive your stolen/pick pocketed goods. (Invest in Mercantile Stat) 
Some items cannot be sold and will occupy your inventory.
Get your first house fast, in order for additional 155 storage space.
When creating your own character, Race/benefits are not important.

1) 
Best Money repeatable quests:
Peasants clothes will be asked in a quest at the Moon Camp, under Rathir) - best value since, requires at least lvl 10+ to get at the camp.
Iron or steel components from salvaged equipment will be asked in a quest at the Sun Camp) - second best value, requires lvl 15+ to get at the camp.

2)
Stats
-Alchemy 
Do not max it out first. materials will drop randomly either from gathering/killing/chests (never used potions on normal mode after lvl 18+) 

-Blacksmith 
Good for most of the time. Quick save before you salvage items, to get the best outcome if you want to be top tier. Crafting gets better and better (used it 3 times in the playthough) 
Repair kit is useful anytime, anywhere and cheap. 
Tip: keep the best salvaged items for end game weapon and armor

-Dispelling
Useless to max it out. 5 lvls into it and it's enough.  tip: clear 2 entire zones, then go dispelling. after getting 1 curse, go dispel it at healer. You will receive a buff that will protect you from future curses. 

-Detect Hidden  
Good stat, letting you see hidden doors/stashes; last lvl showing you Lorestones and Treasure chests. ( It DOESN'T SHOW every loot able thing. Example skeletons do not appear on the map. )

-Lockpick 
Useless at the start of the game. (Most of the Set Items are randomly dropped by chests. You cannot Salvage the Set Items(Yellow) or Purple Items.)

-Persuasion 
Useless (You have 0 impact on the actual story. It can help avoid some fights or to investigate stuff.)

-Sagecrafting 
Useless. (IF you want the best gear possible, it's useful at the end game for crafting 7 gems.)

-Stealth
Useless. (It's only helpful if you steal/lockpick/pickpocket. You cannot play as a rogue. 

Info: 
Stat Books provide you with +1 Stat. Stat books are randomly dropped. (I got 6/7 Stat books)
There are trainers for every Stat at different levels with different amounts of pay. The last trainers are only available in the last zone, after completing most of the story quest.
Tip: After getting access to visit the King in Ysa, you should be at lvl 15+ with 500 000 gold. Now go and search for every trainer and respec if you need to. (DO NOT BE CHEAP. I finished the game with 5Million gold) 

3)
Respec:
Fateweavers can help you respec. 
First respect is free, second respec at lvl 18 it cost me around 5k gold. At lvl 36 at my 6-7th respec I payed around 50k gold. 

4) 
Destinies
Play what you want, there are pros and cons to every destiny you choose.
Note: You cannot play as a proper Assassin. There are more benefits in being an Archer than a Rogue/Assassin.

5)
Weapons do not matter but I placed it anyways

A+ Faeblades are the best because you have lorestone buffs/card buffs that provide dmg when using a Faeblades.
A   Daggers/Longswords are second to best since, you have abilities in strength and agility that boosts the dmg of faeblades,daggers and longswords
B   Bow/Scepters because they are ranged and you have auto aim 
C   Chakrams good damage and speed. it takes a bit of practice to get their full potential.
D   Greatsword/Hammer they have the highest damage in the game, but the're slow

Note: I've only ranked them from the POV of buffs/card buffs/abilities. They do not reflect on the actual weapon stats.
Ex: Hammer with 20% more dmg to a certain mob can be equally good as your best faeblades. But if you use the same hammer against other mobs, it's not that efficient. This is from a personal experience

[h1] A Game to be Reckoned With [/h1]

[b] What I Liked [/b]

It's not as deep as games I would compare it with, like Skyrim.  That doesn't make it a bad thing.  I also liked that staves were a great combat option.

[b] What I Did Not Like [/b]

In the end it didn't capture me.  I have nine hours in the game since I tried it multiple times, but, couldn't get into it.

[b] Why I Stopped Playing [/b]

I just couldn't get into it.  I recommend it if you want a Skyrim-lite game to play.

[b] Disclaimer [/b]

I have been a gamer for over 30 years.  I tend to play mostly PC games.  I also bounce around between games A LOT.  I may purchase a $60 game and play it for 2 hours or spend $10 on a game and spend 50 hours on it.  Even if I played a game a short time, it does not mean it is bad.  It just means another game caught my attention.  I also complain about flaws in games a lot, even about the littlest of things.  Keep that in mind when reading my reviews.  If I do not have a complaint, then the game must be special!

88824549.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a great ARPG. I'm really happy that it has gotten more popularity lately. 

It has a huge and beautiful open world with a great variety of different locations (forest, jungle, desert, mountain, city etc.). A lot of quests are pretty generic but still a lot of fun. And there are hundreds of quests! The combat is one of the biggest features of the game. It is really fluid and offers a good variety of different styles. I especially like that you can combine different classes. And even if you don’t like it you can re-spec as often as you like. The spell and combat effects are nice to look at but not too flashy. 

The only issues I had with this game were the somewhat wonky camera mechanics and the inventory UI. You can definitely tell that the game is a console port and should be played with a controller instead of with mouse and keyboard.  

I had a lot of fun playing it!

88149614.review:
I played this game when it first came out, way back in 2012.  It was fairly entertaining, kept me amused for about 40 hours.  In the end though, I didn't find it captivating enough to actually finish. YMMV.  It has a very strong single player MMO vibe -- if that makes any sense.  In fact, I often wonder if this game was originally destined to be an MMO.

The world, it's denizens, the quests, etc, are all pretty standard RPG stuff.  Again, nothing terrible, but nothing that amazing either.  The combat is better than what you'd find in similar games.  If it's on sale and you're in the mood for a relatively workmanlike RPG, you probably can't go wrong with this title.  But, at the same time, if there's better RPGs on sale (Divinity, Baldurs Gate, etc) I'd get those instead.

In the end, I vaguely recommend this game.  It's like the quintessential 7 out of 10 game.  It's not bad at all, it just doesn't have that much to elevate it over its competitors.

87977031.review:
Recommended with some caution.

The game's remake (re-reckoning) may address some of the issues that I will mention. The review is for Reckoning (the older game).

As an RPG, it fulfills its role. You can have a sorcerer (pure magic), a warrior (pure might) or a rogue (pure finesse).  You can also be a jack of all trades (mix and match). I play pure magic (sorcerer) and expect that my review will have limitations based on this.

The game is your typical go-do this; fetch that item RPG. Many quests involve going into a dungeon/cave. Sadly, most of them have similar layouts. The story is not the best, nor is it the worst. Someone brings you back from the dead, and you have amnesia. Along your way to discover your roots, you will help people and certain factions. You can aid all factions without getting punished for it, even if they have opposite values. There is a war in Amalur that affects everyone, yourself included. This war is the main story—A+ for having a main plot and subplots, devs.  

The graphics are older. If you have a larger monitor, you will need to see what resolution works for you. It's not horrible because you're not going into this expecting out-of-this-world graphics. You can roam anywhere in the main world, which is a plus and a detriment. Below, I will tell you about things that you likely want to do first and why there are sequential issues (the story does not always bring you where it would be best for your character). Not being in the best zone/area for your level/character/questing would be fine, as I read that the zones no longer stayed at the same level that you were when you first entered them.  I have found that to be untrue with Detyre. I'm one-shotting everything, and the loot is horrible.  

Speaking of the loot, kudos on the devs for coming out with crafting and with higher-tiered gear that you can get in the wild/while questing.  The issue is that the top-tier armour (yellow) has a set of 5-6, depending on your character.  I have only ever found one full set, and my helmet was level 8 while my shoes were level 22. The more of the same type of armour you equip, the more bonuses you can get from these yellow pieces. Armour and weapons do not level with you. If you love a yellow set, do not loot any pieces until the desired level (40 is the max level). You may have to bypass areas of an earlier zone and move on to another location. To me, this is a big issue. I've only ever used this yellow armour to sell it because I never had a set that was beneficial enough to keep. Yellow armour feels mostly irrelevant other than to make some gold. If you are crafting your armour, you can make some of the best armour in the game. You will need to salvage some of the armour and weapons you looted to get components to make your armour and weapons.  Some are crappy components, while others are better. A proper balance of sold armour and salvaged armour will be required to craft while having enough money to survive. The game is fun, but there are many issues regarding the flow/progression.

Let me tell you about some annoying bugs that I encountered to help you avoid repeating my hair-pulling ''mistakes''.  1) There are pieces of armour and weapon that stay stuck in your inventory.  You cannot salvage them.  You cannot destroy them.  You cannot sell them. The house of Ballads (yellow set) is one of these.  If you put it in storage and then take it out of storage, it will stay in your inventory forever (taking inventory space).  Wear it if you like it and sell it once done with it.  If you're a magic-user, wear it for the minute you're forced to put it on, and then sell it as soon as you get out of your ''dungeon''. DO NOT PUT IT IN STORAGE.  Your storage has limited space. I wanted to clean up my storage space, and BAM, it's now stuck in my inventory. 2) The weapon Shrine and Shadow (purple tier or second-best tier) stays stuck in your inventory as well.  I forget how I got this one stuck in my inventory. I suggest Googling it when you find this weapon.  I think that I had put it into my storage and took it out to sell it. 2) There are some chests that you won't be able to loot.  This bug seems rare, but there is one chest in Detyre described as a ''larder''.  It's in one of the Motus mining camps (in the basement). 3) I spoke about this above, but I would Google the best progression route to take.  Most caves (dungeons) can be entered without reason to do so, but some quests may become bugged if you do.  Wait until you have a quest to enter the cave/dungeon.  I think that one or two dungeons do not have any quests related to them. 4) Save often and have different saves.  Having a main save before entering a main mission is likely a good idea.  It's not so much that the areas bug out.  It's that you can steal from people, and the devs messed this up by allowing you to steal items that you will need to steal for quests (without having the quest) or to loot items that you will need to loot for quests later on.  This bug renders some quests unavailable/unfinishable.  Your save can be a lifesaver if you cannot find any workaround.  I would read the bug page on the Amalur wiki page.  I found a buried body that I could loot.  I did what one does in an RPG and looted it. I had also stolen rings from people, even if I didn't know what their use was.  Then came the quest of ''find this body which will give you clues as to where these rings are...I want these rings''.  Oh great...the body becomes untargettable. Thankfully, I found a workaround (of my own as no online fixes/suggestions worked).  If you're a completionist, this game will make you scared to loot!

My advice: 
Your first house is in Canneroc (in Webwood).  You have access to your first ''stash'' in that house.  Since your inventory is minimal at first, I highly suggest going there as soon as you can and doing the mission that gives you this house as a reward.

Each time you level, you get to put points into your character's skills (might, finesse, sorcery).  You also get to put points into things such as alchemy, blacksmithing....  Put all your points in ''find hidden'' first. This skill will show you hidden items and hidden doors.  These items are extra money, and money does not come easily at first. Then, max out blacksmithing and sagecrafting.  These are the two skills that you will need to make your armour and make it as good as possible.  After that, you can put points into anything else.  Alchemy can be useful if you want to make your potions instead of buying them.  Without points spent in alchemy, you can try to loot any plant, but most will yield no result/you couldn't collect anything. The only plants that you can loot with a high success rate (without alchemy points) are those that allow you to make the minor healing potion.

Lastly, the smith of a town can repair your broken armour.  They charge a fortune, even from the start.  If you put points into blacksmithing, you can get better results from the repair kits you can buy and use to fix your armour.  They are 60g each compared to the 1300g a smith may ask to repair one item.  The item repair system is not balanced correctly.  60x6 to fix all of your armour or 16 000 from a smith?  It makes a huge difference.  You can store those repair kits in your stash.  They stack up to 10, and each stack of 10 takes one spot (in your inventory or stash).  I keep one stack of 10 on me at all times.
