87230798.review:
I just finished this game yesterday, and with the release of KoA: Re-Reckoning, let's take a quick look at the original release.

[h1]Short: 'KoA: Reckoning' is like a mix between Fable, Darksiders and World of Warcraft.[/h1] It plays like a lovechild between all three, and overall it is a great fantasy RPG that feels like an oldschool MMORPG, but you're the only player. Hooray! My childhood's wet introvert dream!

[h1]Long:[/h1] As mentioned above, this game is incredibly much like an MMORPG, but without the MMO-part: The world is vibrant, colorful, and a comic-book level of uniquely designed which is reminiscent of classic oldschool RPGs like WoW, Fable or Morrowind. The quests are so detached from one another and have such little impact on the main storyline that they feel much like from an online game - they're fun to play and some have quite interesting storylines, but the wild assortiment and generic dungeon crawling mechanics of them are just too reminiscent of 2000's MMORPGs with the same feeling. (If you enjoyed those, you will be pleased with KoA's gameplay too!) 
[b]Speaking of quests[/b], the side quests are... bountiful, to say the least. I did the grave mistake of trying to complete every single side quest before the main quest, which soon turned out to be a horrendous time eater as there are TONS of quests. Do them at your own pace, you will CERTAINLY not run out.

[b]The game's writing[/b] was done by an accomplished fantasy author, which really shows by the sheer amount of lore and names that are being dropped and the interesting plot development. (Minor spoiler:  [spoiler]The ending was too quick, sudden and super anticlimatic, but the buildup was quite nice - most notably the siege with General Tilara.[/spoiler]) The world of KoA doesn't quite have the race diversity that other franchises have (everyone is basically a glorified human or some sort of elf), but it fits neatly into the world building and the most important elven race is touched upon quite in detail, so it seems purposeful.

[b]The gameplay[/b] sports three different combat styles - Might (Warrior), Finesse (Thief), Magic - which are very distinctively different from one another, have own combo chains and are highly entertaining to explore. Overall, I found that the combat was greatly more enjoyable than in most mainstream RPGs. You even get to try out all three skill trees within one playthrough as this game allows for full redistribution of skill points at any time! (As long as you visit the right NPC.) The combat system deserves a lot of praise imo for being innovative while still being easily accessible to everyone. It's very easy to learn, especially mix-and-matching Finesse skills with either Magic or Might is very fun and makes for some fast-paced, intense combat.

[b]Also, I love crafting.[/b] I am one of those people. And KoA: Reckoning has a good, not mind-blowing but thoroughly good crafting system, most notably the armor/weapon blacksmithing. It might be the most important skill set in the game! Self-made armor and weapons are by far the strongest and can even be named to bear majestic customized titles such as "tiddy plate". Because of the power of self-made equipment crafting is super satisfying and yes, I got a ton of enjoyment out of it.

Now, an important aspect of this game is the amount of [b]dungeon crawling[/b] - which I have honestly never been the biggest fan of, so this is also KoA's biggest shortcoming imo. Basically every single quest in this game requires you to enter a generic-looking dungeon at some point, and the amount of backtracing can be frustrating. Transportation takes a while as the maps are vast and you have no means of traveling besides on foot or per fast travel (which, naturally, does not work in dungeons). I could have done with better-placed shortcuts and dungeon exits or the existence of at least one mount, to be honest. I sorely missed these aspects as the maps sometimes seemed excessively vast. (The amount of walking time is not in a good ratio with the amount of cities/key places.)

[b]All in all,[/b] KoA: Reckoning masters all the core gameplay mechanics in fantasy RPG that will satisfy and keep you entertained if you like fantasy RPGs even just a little, and it is a wonderful game in total. It's not another run-off-the-mill, bleak and dark high fantasy clone of Lord Of The Rings (aherm, Skyrim, aherm) but instead  charms with an explosively colorful, unique world design that is reminiscent of the three classics mentioned above: Fable and Darksiders in terms of gameplay and "tone", WoW in terms of quests and art style. It really brought me back to the RPG era of the mid-2000's and early 2010's, but in the best way. While it has its little faults in terms of story wrapping and dungeon crawling, you can still feel what an ambitious project it was at its time of development. It held up amazingly well. Don't bother going out of your way to get KoA: Re-Reckoning if you already own this base game; it is fantastic as is and needs more love.

86689465.review:
This game was truly a wonderful release that was sadly largely overshadowed by competing titles. With R. A. Salvatore writing much of the lore, you know it will be rich and in depth. The gameplay was solid, and there's hundreds of hours of playtime to be had for anybody wanting a modest, down to earth fantasy RPG.

Sadly the original developers went broke and out of busdiness, and with THQ Nordic at the helm of the "Re-Reckoning" I think we can finally lay this title to rest after all this years, as this new company will never be able to recreate or properly evolve the work of art that was KoA:R.

I leave this review with the bittersweet knowledge that this game will never be available in its original form again. I cannot recommend the new release, and thus I'm forced to recommend the game you can't buy.

I suppose at the end, that's what all of this was about. We tried to buy the past. It didn't work. If any of the original Devs ever see this review, I just want you to know this game was special to me in a way most games will never be. It got me through a lot of bad times, and made many good times better. Thank you again. Much love and respect, sorry things ended up this way.

And of course, should somehow the impossible happen, and you get the chance, PLAY THIS GAME! Its worth it! Find all of the secrets, all of the story books, and do every quest! I promise you its all worth it!

This game has a bit a sad story to tell. The baseball pitcher Curt Shilling, who owned Studio 38(developers of this game) put all his money into it, 33 million dollars. But it was the time, skyrim was released so this jewel did not get the attention, it deserved and studio 38 went bancrupt, it was sold 1,5 million times but needed 3 million sells to just cover its costs.
Its a jewel, if you like rpg-action with lots of lore and a great atmosphere, this is for you. A dev said, with all sidequests you need 200 hours to play, that huge it is. A gossip from the community stated after 80 hours its over. I needed around 110 hours, doing all sidequests but often (shame on me) clicked away the dialogues, because i'm not that much into lore in games(oh yes mylord, shame on me).
Fighting is really fun, you can customize your char nearly as you like. The graphics is close to wow graphics, if you don't like that, its a disadvantage..but the game has such a unique style and character, i forgot pretty quick about its graphical style.
It is not in 1st view, instead you see your character big in front of you, which is annoying for the most people, but a little tool named "widescreen fixer" helps with that, do yourself a favor and install it right away.
1 or 2 situations can happen, that you enter a cave and game crashes, i just closed widescreen fixer and all was well again.
So a big recommendation from me, i actually finished it and i'm a bit sad because all is over now, and this happens really rarely to me, so have fun !

84797218.review:
Haven't finished the game yet, but I bought this game many years ago. At the time, it had some innovative features and seemed fairly unique. 

Let me start off by saying this game is HUGE. It has a WoW vibe to the aesthetic, and the environments are very nice to look at and explore. Combat is simple, you can use abilities that you unlock over time, and you can unlock a few combos for every type of weapon in the game, which provides some diversity. It's not the most intricate combat system, but it does the job well enough. On another note, it is VERY easy to get lost in all the side quests. There are hundreds! It was the main reason why I stopped playing this game (started to get a bit mundane) and play other games in my library. 

After a couple years I got back into the game to finish it. You can respec your characters as many times as you want, which is nice, because I had no idea what build I was going for. Don't attempt to clear every single quest. It will drive you mad. Stick to the main and faction quests, and get side quests that are along your way, otherwise you may find youself over-levelled later on. 

At the time of writing this, I hear they are re-releasing this game. Seems like its just a graphical update. If you've never played this and want a simple RPG thats not too complicated, I recommend this. Will it hold up to modern classics (Witcher 3, etc.)? Probably not but the game is enjoyable regardless. Definite buy on sale.

Even though this version of the game is no longer available, I would seriously recommend it if you can find it.  To me, the 'Re-Reckoning' version isn't really worth the money if you already have the original, but it might be a nice time if you're new to the game.  All-in-all, this is a pretty cool game to get your hands on.  One of the things I loved was the Fate cards and how you can mix-n-match for a unique background, instead of being forced into one particular path, even though your play-style includes other abilities (a Warrior's skill with a sword, coupled with a Thief's stealth and a Wizard's defense magic, etc.)

There are some downsides, of course, like going on tiresome side-quests and the usual grinding, but overall it's a really fun game.  I highly recommend it for an afternoon or twelve of just sitting back and vegging out.

In The Legend of Dead Kel one of the missions has an necessary NPC get stuck behind a wall of fallen boulders and become inaccessible. This NPC is supposed to return you to town, and in the place where you are when this bug occurs, fast travel is disabled. The game saves right at the start of the dungeon, which you cannot exit, and inevitably leads to the bug therefore ruining your save file. If you do buy this game ---> MAKE A SEPERATE SAVE FILE BEFORE DOING ANY DLC CONTENT <----. I spent 37 hours on this game only to not be able to finish due to this bug hardlocking my game.

84010018.review:
TLDR; 2 out of 5.  the only thing fun about the game is the combat, when you actually run into enemies. 

Longer review:
Full Disclosure, I didn't finish the game and there is a reason why.  

The only thing about this game that doesn't suck is the combat, though it can be frustrating at times, especially when trying to defend when surrounded by multiple enemies.

The world while very colorful feels empty, especially when you're running across the map on basically every quest.  The quests in this game are very generic and almost follow the identical path. example, "step 1: Go here to this location and meet Person.  Step 2: Person tells you to go to another location across the map to meet this Person. Step 3: meet that person, they tell you to go here to help them clear out an area of enemies and come back. Step 4: Clear out enemies/help with problem, come back to person. they are shocked you aren't affected by the Fates and tell you to go to see this new person." Rinse Repeat. 

The quest that made me quit the game literally had me running across a huge map to touch "windstones" there were FOUR of them total and each on one on a corner of the HUGE map and the only way to get to them was to run across the DAMN map.  took me about 10 minutes of running and fighting mobs to get to each one.  so 40 minutes total just to unlock a god damned door!

as for the story, it's a Generic Fantasy with Generic Fantasy races, and I'm pretty sure their main story line was taken straight from Lord of the RIngs. the part about the Age of Elves and Immortals coming to an end, and the age of Man beginning. Along with a Dark power rising to the East attempting to take over the world. 
And not a single character in this game is memorable at all.  As much as they were mentioned I could not tell you the name of the Enemy "race" or the Evil Leader of this race. and they name dropped both of them almost every sentence. 

I can see why this game bombed so hard when it first released.  In my honest opinion, this game is not worth anyone's time. Definitely don't recommend spending any money on it. There are better games out there!!

82589502.review:
This is one of my favorite games ever. I love the world and story its set in, along with the gorgeous music and art. It's not very difficult, which doesn't bother me, but could be a bother for others. It's one of the coolest looking games I've ever played, enough that I've never been able to get into Skyrim, because I keep comparing the visuals to this one. It's fun to take your time with this game, and see all of it, rather than only doing the main quest line. I played it on my brother's account for years before I bought for myself, so I think I've spent roughly 500-600 hours on it overall (across at least 8 characters) since 2012.

If I could change anything, I would add more options to the character customization, as some hairstyles are only available for certain backgrounds of characters, and the female customization options have a weird kind of permanent eyeshadow above and below the eyes. That can be counteracted by adding a light colored eyeshadow at medium opacity, however. (Also props to this game for having proper women's armor).

Look out for: There's a sidequest, in the Plains of Erathell, that involves taking and cleansing a cursed staff a bandit stole. The location you are supposed to go to to cleanse it has a secret door that is supposed to block the exit until you leave, but it glitched for me and wouldn't open, leaving my character unable to leave the location, and unable to continue the game. I had to start a new character instead. I recommend not taking this sidequest. It won't mess anything up if you don't take it.
Also, grinding through levels isn't worth it- you'll gain more experience than you need simply by completing a minor amount of sidequests. Each region in the game locks difficulty to the level you first enter it at, and the game isn't frustrating enough to make being over-leveled necessary.

81743556.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is fantastic action RPG.

KOAR has a reputation of being an average, Skyrim / Fable knock off, and although it might share similar inspirations as those games - it's an all together different experience.

The game is full to the brim with intriguing lore, a wealth of content and characters and a superb and fluid combat system, that is both satisfying and challenging in equal measure. Combine that with a host of great weapons, magic and characters build options, there's not a lot to dislike here.... Apart from the FOV (which I believe has been addressed in the recent and somewhat sub par remaster).

For fans of fantasy role playing and fast paced combat, KOAR absolutely does not disappoint.

81367370.review:
Right, so, where to start with Kingdoms of Amalur? Well first off I want to say this is a game that deserves way more praise then it has been given, rather then being scrubbed from the face of history in games, people should remember it as a beautiful, atmospheric and brilliant roleplay game. Its a shame it was overshadowed by so many games, Skyrim being the first of many but we can see why due to how great it was...but this game is great as well in my opinion. I have a lot of things to say about this game so lets get into them.

[h1] [u] The good [/u] [/h1]

[list]
[*]Probably one of the most prettiest games I have ever played
[*]Combat and and roleplaying capability is hugely varied meaning you can have multiple playthroughs and not get bored
[*]The story is pretty good and well done
[*]Genius level up system
[*]Every area in the game is unique in its own way
[*]DLC is fun and unique (Although I recommend playing it after the main game as it will help with the problem of not getting bored late game through its max level as I have listed in the bad section)
[/list]

However, I do have some bad points but its not really the developers or the games fault for having them. If more people showed more interest and found the game earlier then this game could have been turned into something masterful and perhaps into a series like it deserves to be. Even though there are quite a few problems and bad points, its still worth playing and you will have fun if you do play it.

[h1] [u] The bad [/u] [/h1]

[list]
[*]As the game goes on, there will be more and more glitches (although in the remastered version there will be considerably less)
[*]If you dont take breaks from it from time to time you can get bored of it (Although this is just me)
[*]Voice acting for characters is a little bit over the top (but do remember it is an old game ;) )
[*]Despite the leveling up system being genius, there is a max level to balance things out which I think makes the game pretty boring since you have nothing to grow as the game goes on and its a very long game if you want to explore everything. Personally I think they should have just increased the enemies level and difficulty and not put a cap on things.
[/list]

A slight note also, I am playing the first version of the game, not the remastered version which looks even more prettier and has a lot less glitches and problems, however you need a good PC to play it and also its a bit more expensive then the old game (plus the old game has been taken down so you cant buy it anymore for obvious reasons). These points I have made still apply to the remastered version and even though the remastered version is getting torn apart by fans. I still think people should play it since its exactly the same as the game im playing, just with better graphics and less problems.

I hope this review is helpful and overall, Kingdoms of Amalur is a brilliant game with awesome mechanics but with some small issues and it deserves more recognition then it has gotten. Please give it a shot if you love roleplaying and open world games, I promise you wont regret it

People compare some of the gameplay to WoW, but I tend to avoid mmo's so this gives me something comparable but on my own time. The combat is enjoyable. And I really liked their choice to style much of the world after Celtic mythology, as well as the Greco aspect of Teeth of Naros DLC. The only downside to that is they made the Tuatha into a force of evil (it's not the same Tuatha De Danan; they just took the name. But it still irks me a tiny bit).

In any case, the world feels very old and relatable to the things that inspired the original fantasy genre, without being too much of a D&D clone. As I went back and started playing Skyrim again, there's something else I noticed: everything looks roughly the same, with its snowscapes, dank tombs, and stone cities; definitely a change from earlier TES games. Comparably, I would say Amalur beats Skyrim on that count; there is decent variety in the landscapes and locations.

Its flaws lie in some of the dull dialogue, and perhaps the overwhelming amount there is to do. Some things get repetitive, and certain quests are not very original or innovative. But that does not prevent it from being an enjoyable, underrated game.

79001567.review:
That took way too long. Way, way too long. But I've completed KoA:R with all of the achievements and all of the side quests and all of the DLCs, so I can finally put it to rest.

I know that I'm making it sound like a chore, and it isn't, but KoA:R is just a massive, massive game, and even though the gameplay is good, I like the story to be better told in whatever RPG I'm playing. And frankly, I couldn't tell you what the game is about, because I click-clicked my way through all of the dialog because it's so boring. There's no felicity of style, and that's a shame, because everything else about the game is so good.

KoA:R is almost the opposite of Dragon Age: Origins; in DA:O, very few of the game mechanics function as they should, but the story and characters are so interesting. The crafting is rudimentary, and many of the armours make you look stupid. In KoA:R, the combat is great, and the missions are great, and the crafting is great, and the armour is great, but I just don't care about any of the characters or the story.

The remastering of the game baffles me, because even though the game came out in 2012, it still looks and sounds good. The visuals were never the problem. It was always that the voice-acting is awful, and the way the dialog is laid out is boring as hell.

After a lot of false starts, I finally got to the end of the game as a Universalist, because I wanted to try everything. But I didn't feel underpowered at any point. I didn't struggle. Every build is valid, and every combination works. There's no magic combo that'll make it possible to win the game. It's so well-balanced and fun. And if there's a fight you can't beat, or don't feel like doing? Go into Fate mode (or drink a potion of Fate in case the bar isn't full) and beat the encounter that way.

But honestly, KoA:R is almost too big. There are just too many sidequests (and many, many tasks that are endlessly repeatable), and the game could have done with trimming the fat just a bit. Aside from that, this is highly recommended. If you have an older machine, skip the remaster.

78548320.review:
Ok, so this game, imo is pretty awesome.  It is mostly a sandbox type game with a few limitations.
1) You can't jump off cliffs and such unless there is a spot designated (noted by an arrow).
2) At times you can get stuck on terrain, but it's not permanent.

As far as others saying it's not a good game, they obviously are not this type of game player.
There is an abundance of quests:  fetch, collect, kill and such.
But most games have some form of similar quests.
The dialogues with NPC's are pretty good.  I have not encountered any that seemed out of place or spoken badly.
And there is a lot of dialogue (this is a good thing).
Each person you interact with has something to say (and yes it's repeated at times and on a closely related npc nearby).  But that doesn't detract from the game.

Fight mechanics are pretty damn good.
There are many types to choose from:
    Rogue / Assassin types,  mage type and warrior type.
There is a lot of gear choices and you can even craft your own.  The crafting system takes some getting used to (with no guidance in game), but you get the feel for it as you go.
There isn't much in the way of hand holding and I quite enjoy the options in some dialogues to just say no or be a shit (LOL).
You can actually kill anyone (if you so choose), but you will mostly likely end up in jail (for friendly type kills).

I see there is a Re Reckoning for sale, but I have yet to finish this game, there is literally 100 or more hours of play time.
I don't feel the need to spend more money on a game that according to most of the bad reviews is flawed.
I personally have only had a couple issues that were easily solved, one due to me alt-tabbing in and out a few times.
I have not had any crashes, nor lock ups.  The game is pretty polished (not like all the new crap content that has paywalls and loot boxes and forced monetary payments for more content and such).

If you like games such as Skyrim or Dragons Dogma: Dark Arisen, then this game will keep you entertained and offer tons of enjoyment.  It will also frustrate you at times (LOL) some fights can be very overwhelming.

I suggest if you can get your hands on the original version then do so.  I certainly won't be spending more money on a game that seems more a money grab than anything.  This new trend of wanting to get more money for a game that is old by so-called remastering (I am looking at you Bethesda - Skyrim) is a scourge on the game industry and shows a lack of motivation to create new and exciting games.  I wish game studios would stop trying to suck every last penny from customers with rehashed garbage on a game that had great merits on its own and just make new games.

I also love that this is one of the better solo play (single player) games out there as I don't care nor enjoy playing online games with other players.  Too often multi-player games have a hateful and childish player base that either cries about the game or wants to just grief others out of their fun.

I say keep up the single player games as that is more meaningful to mature players that want to enjoy content at their leisure and not have to log on to some damn track me - try to sell to me platform.

Overall, I give this game a 9.5/10.

78256345.review:
So, have you ever played a PC or console game made by a major league baseball player?  No?  Well here's your chance!

"38 Studios, owned by former baseball pitcher Curt Schilling, originally began developing the Amalur universe with a 10,000 year history created by R.A. Salvatore for use in a massively multiplayer online role-playing game (MMORPG) codenamed Copernicus." from wikipedia

This was, and still is, a gem of a game with some heavy hitters (yes pun intended) behind it, like author R.A. Salvatore, Spawn creator Todd McFarlane, and Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion lead designer Ken Rolston to finally create a single player game named Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning.
This was the first and last game made by 38 Studios having filed bankruptcy shortly after release.

My first time playing the game was shortly after release on the Xbox.  I couldn't get enough of the game, as playing hours just melted away like minutes instead,  it's that good.  The visuals, story, combat, all packaged to make a very good RPG game.

With the recent release of KoA: Re-Reckoning, I decided to pull out my PC version from my pile of steam games to play it again.  Afterwards, I just might have to buy the re-release and play that one through.

So, yes, totally worth getting if you love RPGs, and chasing quests with interesting storylines and characters.

OK, so it's been years since I finished about 4/5 of the game but then got tired of the endless killing spree and inventory management. I thought I's finish it just for kicks and yes, the endless killing spree is no less tedious, but, especially for its time, it's a very decent game, with good voice acting, fun crafting and may well thought NPCs.

For me, the cons were:

1. Inventory space: if you are going to have so much unique collectable loot, simply have an option to upgrade space with ever greater cost. I mean, personally I ended up with almost 4,000,000 gold wit literally nothing to spend it on.

2. Level cap at 40, along with crafting results etc. Very few unique crafting recipes. Seems like a waste.

77420402.review:
I've played way more than this indicates, because I owned it on another platform before I bought it on steam. I didn't have the DLC then, so those are making a nice change. 

I love Amalur. It's pretty, and it's fun. The combat is slick and smooth and easy, and I find it very intuitive. It's easy to respec into a different build, and you can mix and match without being mechanically penalized. There's a ton to do, and the minimap and quest markers make it easy to find. The scenery is gorgeous and interesting. Fast travel is pretty painless. It's very moreish, generally--oh, I'll just do this quest over here, and then there's another quest just over that hill, and so on. Quicksave and quickload are fast and painless[strike], making it easy to savescum persuasion checks, or dispelling chests[/strike]. The lockpicking feature is simple and quick.

Drawbacks, just for the record: There are a fair few common actions that don't have keybinds so you have to mouse to the right place and/or click through a small menu over and over. The graphics are obviously dated. There is not much scope for roleplaying. No romance, even with the Maid of Windemere who wants you to rule at her side. If you go back to earlier areas, they won't recognize new titles you've earned. Clearly designed centering straight men, because women hit on the PC all the time, and men never do--this is a plus for me, as a lesbian playing a female character, but it is pretty obvious, and so are the male-gaze costumes on characters like Alyn Shir. (Oh my god please put on some actual clothes, that collection of belts cannot be comfortable.) It is [i]incredibly[\i] easy to overlevel, especially if you're at all a completionist. As far as I can tell, unique items are locked to the level where you were when you got them, so if you get them too early they're rubbish forever. No armor cosmetics, my clothes are so tragically ugly. Dispelling curses is, for me at least, impossibly difficult and I just have to savescum autoattempts. The lore holds no real surprises if you've consumed any fantasy rpgs in the past twenty years.

I realize that drawbacks paragraph is longer than the positives one, but that's just because I'm being specific and picky! Most of these things don't actually bother me much, I just strive to be informative when I leave reviews. I still love this game.

I can't afford Re-Reckoning, nor can I justify it when I already own Amalur, so I can't compare the two. 

I wish Amalur had gotten a sequel like they wanted.

77099538.review:
Overall a decent game. Feels like a combination of Elder Scrolls and Witcher series games but with 10% of the budget of either games. Character customization is pretty good. There are 3 skill trees and a set of skills to develop as you level, very classic RPG things. The combat is fluid enough and there are plenty of ways to handle enemy and boss encounters. Difficulty is a joke, even on hard, most enemies simply do not hit very much. 

- The Good -

Every single character and quest is voice acted with most of it being varied with competent enough actors. There are not a ton of different actors so many characters will sound similar, but it's a nice touch and it did add to the immersion. The game world is varied and enjoyable to look at with pleasant graphics and a unique enough aesthetic. There are 5 main regions to explore with smaller sub regions filled with dungeons and quests to keep you busy throughout the game. The combat is engaging and satisfying, it won't be difficult to pick up and be proficient at within long. Story is good enough, not a lot of depth but it holds together well enough.

- The Bad -

I won't complain toooooooooooo much but there are a few key annoyances that might make you not want to play this game. A full play through, doing every quest and dungeon is around 100 hours. After about 5 hours you will have seen every monster and seen every type of dungeon. The last 95 hours is XP grinding the same looking things until you max you character level and win the game. Every single attack an enemy can do will stagger you character, making you unable to move or attack for about 0.8 seconds. Every enemy attack is also homing, even most melee attacks so you HAVE to roll/blink or block everything unless you are behind cover or our of range, simply moving to avoid won't cut it. There are 2 mage types in the ENTIRE game. The first is the spammer with 3 different types of spammy attacks and a summoner type which can summon a couple monsters depending on what the lore tells them to. Summoners are so rare I think I saw less than 10 in the whole game. Speaking of lack of variety, there are maybe 8 different types of monsters to fight in the game and every boss except 2 or 3 is a re-skin of a regular monster. I like the music in this game, but there are so few tracks that i'm totally sick of them after a couple hours if there is any music playing at all, most of it is a short jingle when you enter an area. The game can also bug out at any point and brick you from completing the main quest line. That did not happen to me luckily but be warned, its a game from a studio that went under right after release so its not perfect by any means. The DLC is also not available anymore so good luck getting the 11 DLC achievements. The achievements suck anyways, not a good reflection of game completion nor achievement so don't bother too much with them.

- Conclusion -

I may sound like I didn't like the game but I personally did. It's a depthless, simple player MMO that requires no thought that you can steamroll to your pleasure. The combat is either with you or against you but it won't defeat you so whatever, just pop relentless assault and say fuck it and destroy everything in your path.

There is one thing that I found sums up the game perfectly. There is an ability where you can bash with your shield to 'open up' enemies for an attack. Well, there is only 1 monster that blocks you in the entire game and shield bash will in fact NOT open him up for at attack. Thought that was funny as shit. 

Anyway, if you see the game for a few bucks its worth a play despite my criticisms, you do not have to do everything but you might want to anyways. 7/10

75873835.review:
What is Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning ?

Recently this game got a pretty lazy remaster but that same remaster has managed to make it receive some noticeable attention since its release, I had it sitting on my library for a while and now sadly they took the original version away from the store for a kind of  crappy remaster but Ill still review it as the page is still up even tho people cant buy it anymore and this review will probably will not be seen by most, I review pretty much every game I play so lets go anyway.

I cant comment much about the remaster since the version I played was the original which is this one and Im not giving the so called "remaster" a chance because why should I ? I missed this game during its release but got it on steam a while ago and only managed to try it now cuz to be honest, I totally forgot about this game like most people did, its the type of a game that isnt really bad at all but has been forgotten because..... its very mediocre, forgettable and just average, I wanted to like this because I do enjoy some fantasy settings, even tho Im not really into Fantasy RPGs today as I was like a decade ago, I can still enjoy a game of this genre, I just need to be impressed and Amalur didnt do anything to impress me, I spent almost 5 hours playing it till I had to put the game down as I had no interest to continue due to boredom and just lack of motivation, the game refused to impress me on the story aspect because the plot and everything that is going on is so static and devoid of any emotion, every single character feel like a NPC from some soulless MMORPG, they are just here to give very formulaic quests and this is exactly how the game feels like, an offline MMORPG, I think people would enjoy it much more if coop was available but its just a chore to play as a singleplayer game, the soundtrack is good and the combat is kinda fun altho the game is ridiculously easy as you progress which trivializes the whole character build system and makes the game even more boring since theres no challenge at all.

The quest design, the way the maps were designed, the story, characters and even the flow of the game is so formulaic and just bland, emotionless and boring, yeah the combat is fine but fighting the same enemy for no reason for the tenth time because I had to drop some item from him or entering a cave to get some loot or just talk to some characters here and there then tescort a NPC to the nearby village, sell your loot rinse and repeat while nothing interesting happens, theres so much I can take of this repetitive boredom before I lose interest and this is a problem that plagues tons of other games, amalur brings nothing to make things more interesting or even unique, they could try at least giving us an interesting story but even for that they failed, all you do in this game is MMO Tier-level busywork, it all follows the same cake recipe that has been done to death in the most generic way possible and for that reason this game got forgotten over time and as any game that manage to make me drop it before I even get halfway through it makes it an automatic no-recommendation from me, the only thing that could have saved this "offline mmorpg" was if it had some sort of coop or even multiplayer function, if you could play this with the presence of another person then I would say that the experience would have been at least bearable I guess but sadly it simply isnt.

75806954.review:
I bought this game on sale a few months ago because of the glowing recommendation it'd received by a YouTube channel I watch (hello, Oxtra). I got the game when it was on sale, and a few months before the Re-Reckoning announcement, so I can't speak to the quality of the remaster, though if half of what I've read is true, then they are not all that dissimilar and you can apply this review to the remaster as well.

As for the game itself:

PROS:

Combat - Extremely customizable and fluid. There are built-in systems so that you don't have to worry about pigeonholing yourself into a single class or category only to regret it later on in the game.

Size - The map, story, and game in general is just immense. As of the time of this review, I've sunk over 100 hours in and I've only scratched the surface of the game.

Story - It's a refreshing take on "the chosen one" trope that feels fresh and really draws you in.

Style - The colors of the world are amazing, very much styled after an MMORPG akin to WoW or - to make perhaps a lesser known reference - Rift. That is to say, everything is bright and fanciful in a very story-book kind of way that you don't often get with other fantasy open world RPGs.

CONS:

Characterization - The NPCs in KoA are not exactly memorable in the way that the NPCs in a game like Skyrim are. I think this has a lot to do with the fact that the game is so similar to an MMO, the NPC's never really feel very fleshed out. This is something that an MMO can generally get away with, since there are other real people in the world to interact with, but when it's a single player RPG, there's less wiggle room there. As I played the game, I found that I really didn't care about the characters, and so I never felt invested in any of the side quests, and there are sooo many side quests.

Character customization - This is a small issue, but it bothered me all the same. I played as a human male my first time through, and when I was customizing my character, I was disappointed at the lack of options. I spent quite a long time in the character creator, and I found that no matter which options I tried, each time it felt like the end result was a barely-altered version of a preset mold. Again, this is something you come to expect from an MMORPG, but in a single player game I expected there to be more options and I couldn't help but feel a bit disappointed.

Staleness - I've mentioned already that there are so, so many side quests in this game. In fact, the vast majority of the hours I've spent in Amalur thus far have nearly all been completing side quests, which for me is great - I love getting into the world and doing all the little things in a game, especially an RPG. However, it did not take long for me to realize that there was definitely a formula at work behind the scenes, and soon all the quests started to feel like slightly varied versions of themselves. KoA relies heavily on the "X needs help with Y > Travel to dungeon > Clear dungeon > Do Y > Return to X > Collect reward" format. Now, I know that a lot of RPGs have this same problem - The Witcher III comes to mind - but this issue is usually dealt with by utilizing intriguing characters that keep you invested and grinding because you generally care about the outcome, and as I've already said, KoA doesn't fair very well in the characterization department.

Travel - I've mentioned this in the "PROS" list above, but it's worth saying again; the map is massive. I've not explored a fourth of it yet, and I'm over a hundred hours in. Now, that's not to say you couldn't blast through and explore the whole thing in half that time or less, but that's not how I play and I like to investigate all the nooks and corners of a world because I'm me. That being said, there is no horse or mount that I've seen or heard of in the game, and while there are several places you can fast-travel to, you still end up walking quite far distances in-game, covering large areas that you've already explored just to get from point A to point B, and well, that's a bit annoying but not a huge deal.

You can't jump - This is another small thing, but it bears mentioning I think because it's a mechanic that does ultimately affect game play and traversal. There have been several times when I've needed to get to point A, which was just on the other side of a waist-high wall or outcropping, but since I couldn't jump, I had to go on a hike around and through mountain passes and dozens of enemies just to talk to some gnome of fae that had previously been a stone's throw from where I was standing. It's extremely bad when a quest has you going back to the same spot more than once, and having to go through the same enemies and around the ridiculous path when you could just jump and have it all done in a few minutes.

CONCLUSION:

So, bearing all that in mind, do I recommend the game? At full price, sure. If you can get it on sale? Absolutely. 

For all of its quirks, it really is a solid game that can give you hours and hours of game play in a beautiful world with some pretty badass combat. 

My insight to anyone who is thinking of buying this game is this: it's a single player MMORPG. That's what this is, and if it lacks anything it's by virtue of this fact. So, if you've ever played an MMORPG and wished you could have the whole world to yourself, this is your game 100%. However, do not go into it thinking it's going to be similar to an Elder Scrolls, Witcher, Dragon Age, or the like, it is not that kind of game. Once you understand that, you can really enjoy the game, as it really is a hidden gem and deserves to be better known.

And Ellen, if you're reading this, I appreciated the recommendation and I'm glad to have played this game.

TL;DR

7/10 - It's a single player MMORPG

I heard this game was getting a remake and I played it way back in the day and remembered enjoying playing a caster, and it's been sitting in my collection for a while so I installed it and figured what the hell, let's play an olde for the good ol' days.

My good old days are dead and this port killed them.

Here's the thing; best I can tell, dodging seems utterly pointless, enemies just track you through it.  Stealth is utterly pointless, sure it's in the game but you get spotted by one or more enemies unless stealth is maxed out, I presume, so again pointless.  If you wanna play a caster or a knightly sir who's gonna tank hits anyway then sure knock yourself out but stealth gameplay is out the window for me and with it so is this game.  I refuse to pour another hour into this in the hopes I'll get to do what I wanted to.  I'm glad to have some fond memories of this but as of right now I simply can't recommend this version of the game.

Another bone to pick is; to bring it up to modern standards you'll have to use a widescreen fix 3rd party freeware, because while it gives you the option to set the game to 2k rez, it displays that in pillbox 4:3 so enjoy that if you can, if you can't, the fix works but it's annoying to mess with and you'll likely have to switch your rez around until it FINALLY kicks in.

Can't/ won't recommend and I likely won't pickup the remake, there are better RPGs out there that I might actually get some pleasure out of. 75778797.review:
KOM:R is a very solid RPG overall; I feel like it was generally under-rated or overlooked on release. It plays like a single-player MMO.

Good variety of weapon types and each one plays differently - missed opportunity, though, to have the various combinations of primary and secondary weapons have some sort of joint synergy.

Solid variety of build options, you can mix up skills from the standard warrior, rogue, and mage trees - but I wish that they had gone the route of just letting skill resets be free, trying different builds is a lot of the fun (especially when you find interesting pieces of gear that would complement one well), but it gets pricey very quickly to do the resets.

Combat is very fun and has all the pieces for a good action RPG (dodging/evasion, blocks/parries, weapon combos, etc.); the fate kills are also pretty cool - but the enemy variety is a little low.

The story of an un-fated person (spoiler: it's you) showing up in a world where everything has always been predetermined by fate is interesting and a pretty cool idea, but the story moves very very slowly. 12 hours into it, and people are pretty much still just saying, "Hey! You don't have a fate. That's weird." And there has been little more than allusions to the enemy that the opening cutscene introduces. The side quests are also pretty generic overall.

The graphics are decent. They have actually aged pretty well they are tolerable even years after release.

75466401.review:
This is a really fun game. There is a ton of Lore to take in but it isn't so deep that you need to analyze much of it too much. It is totally possible to Enjoy this game as an action adventure and much less and RPG by just mashing through the dialogue and quests. The combat isn't the best it could be but its fast and fluid. 

There are of course some downsides. There are uber beefy big enemies who make encounters kind of annoying the more of them turn up in battle. There isn't much variation to the type of enemies, however, there are a lot of enemies and higher frequencies of battles as you progress the game. Its possible to get stuck in a wall but depending on where you are, you may be able to fast travel out of there or you will unfortunately be forced to reload from a previous checkpoint. 

You get a ton of Loot. A lot of it. The issue is you have to cut adventures short only because loot is filling your pockets and and if you want more loot, you have to painfully junk and delete items or go back to your storage or sell junked items. The storage wouldn't be an issue, if you could take items apart on the go or send it to an unlimited storage box (in which the player extra storage only has 155 slots). 

Now, because of the storage limitations you will end up with millions of gold coins. You will be selling big batches of items, weapons, and armors  constantly. This puts a damper on the difficulty of the game since its real easy to stay kitted out. 

This game has a ton of content, including discontinued DLC in this version. I completed 100+ Quests before finishing the game and beating my quest took 62 hours. What I also liked about the game is the ability to make world altering decisions. I played my character as someone more spontaneous when making bigger decisions. I racked up a ton of betrayals and got rewarded for being treacherous. It was fun.

75164793.review: A dated classic of fantasy RPG. Extremely stable and well-balanced this game is excellent entertainment value and filled with ton s of quests and a thoughtful story line. It's quasi-open world meaning that you can go where you like and wind up in a place far tougher than your character can handle at that time. However, the running around is not open world. You followed predetermined pathways, you can't jump over obnvious places one could normally go but there are so many options for character development, you soon adapt to the limitations of agam,e that was designed a lifetime ago. If you're a casual gamer like me and don't have the time to invest in learning every nuance of the game, then I recommend you stick to developing one class (I chose mage) and don't split classes. Some bosses like the Thresh and the mountain troll are very challenging unless you've max'd out the qualities of one of the three attributes - finess, strength(?) or sorcery. Stiock to the single archtype and you'll have no problem completing the tons of tasks, missions and dirty deeds asked of you. If you're an "RPG'er" and if you can set aside the dated graphics and linear travel pathways I'm certain you'll love this game.

74709526.review:
At the end of the day, the game is enjoyable and has tons of content for completionists (though not all of it is interesting). However, it doesn't really bring anything special to the table. In particular, the skill/class system is much less flexible than I'd like - there are effectively 7 classes, and you almost have to spend points on skills you won't use - but if you aren't particularly invested in making every single point count this will be less of an issue.

## Story ##
+ The Fae are pretty cool and have interesting stuff going on. I wish the game let you explore that more.
+/- Many zones that are large and have lots of side quests. Some side quests are interesting/fun, others are not.
- The main plot really never sucked me in - especially because it's drip-fed across several large zones with plenty of sidequests in-between, so it's hard to remember what's going on.
## Leveling up ##
- Not all point distributions are good. There are 3 skill trees for you to put points in, but you really want to either put all your points in one, or split evenly across 2-3. 100 points in Might is good, 50 Might/50 Finesse is good, but 70 Might/30 Finesse is bad (you miss out on strong buffs/basically class features)
- Skill trees are arranged so you basically have to put points into things you won't use, which is especially annoying for cross-skill play. There are low- and high-tier weapon types (e.g. chakrams are better than staff), but the high-tier weapons are also on tier 2 of the skill tree and you basically have to put points into the low-tier ones. Especially annoying if you go Might/Finesse.
## Combat ##
+ Generally solid combat. Attack chains and dodging feel good
- Freaks out when you assign dodge or block to mouse keys; as a result I never blocked due to clunky/crowded controls. As a mage, this was fine, but it doesn't seem to work as well for melee types.

74056661.review:
Amazing action RPG: 8/10
+ Huge semi-open world where you have to explore on foot but major locations can be fast traveled to.
+ All dialogue voice acted with quite a few recognizable VA's.
+ Area monsters and loot scales to your level so you can pretty much skip anything you like. (Just keep in mind entering an area locks the level for good so I recommend doing all the quests in an area before moving on)
+ Great combat system where you can combine melee/magic/stealth with 2 weapon types at a time and combos are rewarded.
+ Reckoning "Execution" attacks are meaty and BRUTAL and are unique for every enemy type in the game. Risk a huge enemy group and get huge rewards from executing them all at once!
+ Crafting system for alchemy and gear creation. Nearly all crafting materials take up no inventory space.

- Inventory on your character starts at 75 items which seems like alot but there are SO MANY LOOT ITEMS crammed in chests and corpses and hidden in objects and behind fake walls that it fills up super fast.  There are a few inventory backpack upgrades and an unlockable stash that help but as I like to loot everything it was a constant enemy.
- Loot is adequate but due to level locking on areas and what seems to be 100% random drops you either use what you find and end up trashing most of your gear or you hit crafting hard to unlock OP crafted gear and never really use dropped gear again.  The unique gear items look awesome but often have subpar stats.

73956221.review:
[h1] View an extended review and more screenshots over at my website, [url=https://www.aythadis-reviews.com/reviews/blog-post-one-n4jge-c7ygn] Aythadis Reviews [/url] [/h1]

A small monthly gaming group I'm in picked Kingdoms of Amalur for the game of the month, back in May. Having chipped away at it an hour at a time, I've finally finished KOA to 100% completion, for the second time! Having played this game back on the PS3 AT LAUNCH, and bought all the DLC as they came out, it's one of my favorite RPGs on the last generation. Even playing it again all these years later, I still enjoyed it for the most part! I would have liked to have finished it sooner, but when life's busy with work, you do what you must. I would have loved to have finished and reviewed this sooner BEFORE they unlisted this from Steam to make way for the remaster, which I should point out I invested 40 hours into before the actual remaster was fully announced (I seem to have that luck, play a game then a remaster is announced.) It would have given some more people a chance to play the original, but hopefully the remaster will remain close to the same. 

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2190798046

KOA is an action rpg with some very frantic combat, that offers lots of choices on how you want to play. You can go warrior, rouge, mage, a mixture of 2, or even a bit of all 3! Weapons aren't locked to classes so you can always switch it up on the fly when ever you want when you start getting bored. My main was always a warrior/rouge build with 2 handed swords and daggers for the stealth kills. Using crits to kill most enemies in single hits. After I completed the main game I switch to a warrior/mage build to play more with spells just for something different. My only REAL complaints are some fights you can get horribly combo against where you can't dodge or block and just have your whole health bar melt in seconds. The worst issue though is the camera during combat. You don't get any real control, it just does what ever and can and will get stuck on things, or clip through the floor or wall and can't see what you are doing. It was always an issue at release and it's still here. I did play K&M the entire time.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2167600934

One thing that I loved KoA for is all characters are fully voiced. Most games at the time did not do this or took shortcuts. Tons and tons of lore to find in this beautiful and ginormous world to explore! Include the DLC areas, and you will be here for over 100+ hours exploring and doing quests. Now, if you sit through all the dialog and complete every quest on the way, you are looking at 200+ hours of content. Because I've beat this game previously, I've skipped 90% of the dialog, so I JUST squeezed in at 98 hour to 100% complete the entire game. I will say some quests are fairly boring and repetitive, at least in the base game. There is lots to do and you will need to do them to get the XP needed to power yourself up! I do personally like the DLCs better, as the maps are smaller and are just more memorable.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2190821417

I know I should probably try and explain better why I love this game so much, but I'm just burnt out trying to finish this game in the last 3 months, and honestly there is better reviews out there... Especially when you can't buy this version anymore. Either way, I look forward to the remaster! Guess we will find out when that shows up. I don't think I'll be playing it any time soon, at least not till this "new" content they are making it comes out. If you have the chance to check out KoA, be sure to set LOTS of spare time, cause you are going to need it!

Picked this game up after hearing Ellen on OutsideXtra talk about it, so glad I did.  It is a really enjoyable action rpg that has some great combat.  The world created and story are incredibly engaging, at a basic level and without spoilers in a world where fate is an entirely real and inescapable part of life you begin the game returned from death and without a place in the weave of fate.  Story wise not hard to see how that would make you incredibly dangerous, the only being who can truly choose their path, gameplay wise it lets you be whatever you want and combine your classes as you see fit, and change them any time you please.

Also really love the incorporation of mythologies, the Ljosalfar and Dokkalfar, the Seelie and Unseelie Fae, having the summer and winter courts not be good and evil just different aspects of life.  Plus really interesting attempts at Scottish accents abound :)

One of 3 or 4 games I have ever cared enough to get every achievement, play over and over, love it.  Mage all the way.

73693541.review:
TL;DR: It's an alright game if you're just looking for something to scratch a third-person action itch for twenty hours or so, but there's really nothing that makes it stand out as anything special.

Combat itself is entertaining enough, but there's absolutely no depth to it - you have one basic attack per weapon type that can be chained together to a limited extent, and a couple of active abilities that scale so terribly you'll hardly bother using them. And since unlocking additional weapon moves is locked in to progress down the ability trees, you spend half the game without access to the more varied attacks, meaning that most of the time you'll just be hitting your attack button and blocking/dodging occasionally.

The combat balance is almost non-existent, enemies are almost universally completely trivial other than the occasional one who is an annoying damage sponge and does hilariously disproportionate damage, and there's only about a dozen different enemies who are palette swapped and recycled throughout the course of the game. The most challenging part of the combat is dealing with the abysmal camera, which has a mind of its own and loves to zoom right in on you when you're surrounded by enemies, only stopping to clip through the scenery and get stuck under the floor occasionally.

There's a variety of non-combat skills to choose from (lockpicking, stealth, persuasion and so on) which are generally either absolutely bloody useless, or hilariously overpowered. Depending on which ones you choose you can end up completely trivialising the game without even trying, but with a little care you can max out almost all of the skills anyway which makes any sense of choice completely redundant.

The ability trees are probably the highlight of the game, there's a lot of different abilities to choose from, and thankfully you can respec your character at any time to try different things out. Depending on how you want to play, you can either go deep into one of the trees (magic, might, or finesse, which broadly correspond to the standard mage/warrior/rogue archetypes) or split your points across two or even all three trees. Putting enough points into one tree or a combination of trees unlocks "destinies" which give you added stats and bonus abilities and can make different ability builds feel very different from each other. Ultimately, however, it's still limited by the shallow nature of the combat system, and however you build your character you'll inevitably end up spamming the same basic attacks over and over again.

The real issue is with the pacing of the game. Every single town you come across is chock full of completely forgettable NPCs who will bury you up to your eyeballs in fetch quests and kill quests which give no real rewards but make you slog all over the place anyway. Either you try and do everything out of an obsessive sense of completionism, or you get bored of that by the second or third town, rush through the main quests, and realise there's really not that much game under all that padding. There are half a dozen factions with their own sidequest chains that have a bit more structure to them, but none of them really add much to the game, and aside from some minor stat boosts it makes absolutely no difference to anything whether you do them or not.

Overall it's a thoroughly mediocre experience through and through, which never manages to be amazingly good or offensively bad. If you like third-person action RPG games it ticks pretty much all of the boxes, it does everything more or less adequately without ever really impressing, it all looks nice enough and there's a whole bunch of lore if you can be bothered to pay attention to it. Pick it up in a sale and it'll give you a good thirty hours or so of moderate entertainment, but it's a mostly unremarkable experience with next to no replay value.

73679904.review:
Playing this game helps me understand what is missing in the current PC gaming medium. Action-adventure games. Kingdoms of Amalur is an action-adventure RPG, that has more customization and world traversal than we usually get today. 
This game was created back when not everything that was an action-adventure title on PC had to be a soul-like game. When this game first debuted, people called it generic. Even though it has great voice acting, stunning visuals, and political intrigue. There is also a pretty interesting plot around immortality and its use as a weapon. 
The video games industry today has made churning out bland retreaded franchise games like Assassins Creed, not just the norm, but the acclaimed. In the face of this reality of gaming's reversal for fortune, I can't help but think Kingdoms of Amalur was treated harshly because it was new IP from a new studio. 
If you are willing to play an older but innovative game, with some flaws; Kingdoms of Amalur is more than worth a try.

73470616.review:
[b]Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning[/b] is a remarkably solid open world fantasy game. The Elder Scrolls comparisons are pretty obvious, which is to be expected when Oblivion's lead designer was involved, but there is more than enough to set it apart. For a start there's no series baggage to worry about going in; it's a fresh story with no references to be missed. The combat is far better than Elder Scrolls has ever accomplished, combat feels frenetic and has a lot of variety even if movesets are tied to weapon types. Oher aspects have definitely be simplified, but not in any detrimental way that makes the title feel lacking.

Beyond a shallow Elder Scrolls comparison, Kingdoms of Amalur is an engaging title, very easy to get immersed into the world especially with some great story and dialogue. The world is gorgeous, very vibrant and detailed with a lot of that detail missable if you never take the time to look upwards. Though graphically it does show its age somewhat with its rather intense xbox 360 era bloom and short distance LoD pop-in, as well as a lot of reused assets both in terms of models but also parts of dungeons that are noticeably reused across the world, which of course isn't that surprising for the genre. At the time of this review I'm currently 60 hours into my first playthrough, I haven't even finished up the Alfaria side of the map, nevermind Fortenmar or the two DLC maps, that's testament to the sheer amount of content available. Highly recommend, though it seems you can't buy this directly from Steam anymore I believe you can still buy keys elsewhere, try to get this version instead of Re-Reckoning if you can.

Edit: If the extra 40 hours added to my playtime to finish the main game and the two DLC area's is indication of anything, it would be the fact this game has a lot of content. Anyway, since they removed the three DLC pages before I had the chance to review them, here's a brief rundown.

[b]Weapons and Armor Bundle:[/b]
Utterly pointless, even if they did scale appropriately (locked to the level you are when you enter the first area of the game), the sets have better alternatives (self-crafted or other sets) and even as early game "boosts" are quickly outclassed.

[b]Legend of Dead Kel:[/b]
Mixed feelings. Conceptually I really like the ideas they went with but I'm not sold on the implementation, particularly Gravehal and it's faction quests which end up feeling a lot like busy work than fully realised content. In other areas the DLC improves on aspects of the main game, like dungeon design.

[b]Teeth of Naros:[/b]
Pretty great overall, engaging story and some neat dungeons that feel more vertical opposed to the rather flat layouts found in the main game, Nerotelos being one of the highlights. Prefer it over the Legend of Dead Kel.

73462259.review:
Great game -- huge open world, immersive, some truly excellent dialogue and meaningful choices. Cool premise, too. You don't have to rush to complete content and can take your time exploring each area before you venture out into the world. It's really neat that leveling up certain skills makes it worthwhile to return to earlier zones to "complete" the maps, so to speak. I love the fluid pace of combat and the variety of weapons; I also like that as long as I'm willing to spend the respec gold, I can try a variety of playstyles in a single playthrough without needing to make a new character every time.

I am not the biggest fan of the UI; having to drill-down click through can make inventory management pretty tedious. The character models could use more variety; it's basically the same few presets with different colours both for player characters and NPCs. I'm hoping that both of these things are addressed in the upcoming remaster. Definitely recommended to anyone who enjoys single-player open world games.

73399432.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur Reckoning released in 2012 is a beautiful masterpiece to experience. The influences of games like World of Warcraft (2004), Dragon Age (2009), and the Legend of Zelda series are strong with this one. If you are looking for a  Dark Souls challenge, you will not find it here. Personally I enjoyed the semi-casual difficulty because I wanted a fun and semi-relaxing game that can provide hours and hours of entertainment and this game delivers. 

At the start there are three classes to choose from, Warrior, Rogue, and Mage. Unlike so many games in the genre, KoA allows for hybrid classes. Players can specialize in one skill set or be a jack of all trades, at the cost of being master of none using “talent points” or skill points (gained from level ups) increasing the power of abilities and acquiring new abilities. I chose to play as a Warrior dabbling a bit in magic.

[u]Tips for beginners[/u]:
•	Use “Fast Travel” often (once you have discovered a town or dungeon/cave simply click on the map and the location you want to instantly travel to) it is superior to portals and mounts in World of Warcraft.
•	Look for Backpacks (Bags) on vendors, each one will increase the amount you can carry by 10.
•	Through completing the right quests, a player can earn a house at three different locations, and further into the game a castle. Among other benefits, owned houses contain a special chest/stash where most inventory items can be stored providing a player much needed inventory space.
•	Set gears (yellow quality) are inferior to gears which can be crafted at a Blacksmith forge, this is especially true of “Mastercrafted” gears later on when a player has maximum Blacksmithing skill. The set gears appeared to be designed more for aesthetic uniqueness more than anything.
•	A couple of full sets can be acquired through completing quest lines for a couple of different factions. Completing the House of Ballads faction quests will net a set for casters, completing the Travelers faction quests will net a set for rogues. Completion of each faction quest line will provide bonuses to character stats.
•	If you have ever spent much time with World of Warcraft you will already understand the coloring system used to indicate the quality of items, white for junk, green for common, blue for rare, purple for epic and so on. 
•	It is not necessary to follow the storyline closely, pressing X (I used a PS3 controller) will speed up the dialogue. Only where decisions are made is a prior basic understanding of the storyline helpful to choosing your path. I made one mistake early on out of skipping the rather lengthy dialogues, price paid for impatience.  

[u]Current Stats[/u]:
•	Level 37 (only 3 away from Level cap)	
•	32/61 Achievements (15 of these less than 20.5% players have attained, 7 of them less than 10.6% of players. Must say I am surprised more players have not unlocked these achievements, I doubt it is due to difficulty, because for the most part it is not a difficult game.)
•	161 Quests completed
•	4.5 million gold
•	1,574+ screenshots
•	I stopped counting the cups of coffee at 150.

[u]Pros[/u]: 
•	Amazing graphics (2012), textures, lighting effects, etc.  
•	Average to above average soundtrack, sound effects, and voice acting.
•	Huge world to explore, provides hours of entertainment.
•	Gameplay is fun and precise with a surprising variety of moves/abilities. 

[u]Cons[/u]:
•	The bugs are not all worked out. For example, I discovered an inventory bug which applies to the House of Ballads armor set. After the items went into my inventory, I was able to add to junk (to sell) but I decided I might save the set for in case I decided to change my “fate” to a Mage (though it is not necessary to equip this particular set), so I put the armors into my stash. Later I decided I wanted to sell the set to make more stash space. Turns out after placing the gear into the stash adding it back into inventory binds it to a player making it so the gear cannot be added to junk and sold at a vendor.
•	Considering the size and length of the game world, a greater variety of enemies and environments would have been appreciated. Also I like big bosses, the kind that make you think !!! There are too few end of dungeon/cave bosses which produce feeling of intimidation and dread.
•	This has been said by other players and it only hit me about 120 hours in, but aspects do get somewhat repetitive, but this is fairly common in games designed to be time sinks.

All in all my complaints are minor and should not detract people from giving this game a chance. Honestly I am not the type of person or gamer (since the 80’s) who spends a great deal of time with any one game for hours upon hours. Few games can suck me in and hold my attention for a substantial amount of time. Two games come to mind, games I had difficulty spending only short amounts of time with, World of Warcraft and Kingdoms of Amalur Reckoning pawned me.

In conclusion, on a scale of 1-10, I give this game an 8.9, which is almost perfect, but not without minor flaws.

tldr: very fun rpg. great combat system. excellent world and lore. threatens to replace tes as one of my favorite rpgs. 9/10

I played this game on the Xbox 360 at the urging of a friend of mine who worked at GameStop a long long time ago.  And to this day I still thank him for showing it to me.  There is no division into pros and cons, because this game really has no cons to me.  

The graphics are charming.  To me, the character models, environment, weapons, and armor still hold up to this day, though I just assume the "Re-Reckoning" remaster will simply improve audio and graphics quality without taking away from the core gameplay.  I enjoy the art style.  

Character creation is not as in depth as some RPGs, but it is just enough to allow me to make multiple characters of the same race or different races and they all look unique.  

Combat is where this game really shines.  You can flow seamlessly from magic to melee weapons and back to magic with little to no trouble at all.  The developers truly mastered the ability for the player to use both forms of combat when fighting the enemy.  

Story is excellent.  There are many side missions to this game that can keep you entertained for quite a long time as well as multiple DLCs to play through after the main story is completed.  

While the world is large it's not necessarily open.  There are a lot of linear paths and dungeons.  Unlike in Skyrim, Oblivion, or ESO, you can't just take off running in a certain direction toward your objective.  You have to stick somewhat close to roads or paths in order to reach your destination.  There are a few large open areas, but they are more or less a mile or so in area.  Not miles.  

This game has many great qualities that threatens to let this game replace TESIV Oblivion as my favorite RPG.  It comes very, very close, but Oblivion was a big part of my childhood, so I can't let that happen.  All in all, I give this game a 9/10.

Absolutely fantastic game!

I recently picked up playing it again, and loved it just as much as when I first got it about a year ago. For all its age, it holds up well, the combat is satisfying, the story is engaging, and it honestly still outshines a lot of modern titles. However, this is such a fantastic game, I would definitely recommend it to all my friends, even those with older, poorer computers. Even strangers on the internet who might be reading this page! Except...
I can't.
For some reason, presumably the upcoming remaster, this game is not available ANYWHERE. This doesn't bode well, considering my friends with older rigs probably won't be able to run the new re-release, and it's effectively off the market for the next couple of months. Not a good move.

Edit: The remaster (Re-reckoning) has since come out. It contains a number of gamebreaking bugs that were not fixed from the original version, NEW gamebreaking bugs, decent visual upgrades (actually a plus) and yet, the original product remains completely unpurchasable. 72774613.review:
[b] Intro [/b]
Well, a lot has already been said about this hidden gem. I can only confirm that this is a game you should have played. Especially if you enjoyed Skyrim other similar games. There are many things that make Amalur what it is, I'll go ahead and mention those which stood out to me in particular. 

[b] Combat [/b]
To this day one of my most favourite implementations of fluid combat in an RPG. It has some aspect of a Hack'n Slash games, but you can go with the abilities of your choice. You can mix up moves mid-combat, switch weapons on the fly and you have an "ulitmate ability" for lack of better words that is just completely insane and very pleasing if you pull it off the right way. An additional bonus points: Rogues can actually hold their own in open combat. So if you screw up a stealth kill, you don't have to run for the hills and come back later. Speaking of stealth kills. Those animations, oh boy.

[b] Music [/b]: The background music is for me how gamesoundtracks should be: In the background, gentle, helps you to truely sink into the world without disturbing you or trip you up by suddendly changing. You don't realize how much it builds the atmosphere but if you would turn off the sound, a substantional part would be missing. Each situation has it's assigned, individual soundtrack, so even without seeing you can always tell where you are and what you are doing. Genuine great work!

[b] Various things [/b]
Boss battles: There aren't many sadly, but those which are present will put you to the test if you are not carefull. There are two big boss battles which will make you feel like you challenge the world, and you will feel like a badass once you won.
Looting system: This is a bit of a love-hate relationship. You can find weapons, armour etc in almost every looting container out there. Which means you can get an epic weapon (those are unique weapons with special stats and designs. Very cool!) in a puddle. Not kidding, this is how I got my greatsword which I used for a good chunk of one of my playthroughs. While this is great to get loot, it is also a good way to miss out on loot. Which will have you turn every stone in sight in fear of missing that one set piece you are missing.
Story: A neat story which actually explains why your character is overpowered. There are some surprises here and there but nothing too mind-blowing. It's not an epic tale you'd tell your friends but it helps to carry the game. While this was enough for me, others might expect more. Up to personal preference.
Class system: This is mentioned a lot. You can mix up the traditional classes of mage, rogue and warrior to create unique playstyles and offer different bonuses. You can reset them at any time, if you have enough ingame gold. Which usually isn't a problem.
Crafting: You can level up crafting and make your own equipment which is actually quite well balanced with other gear. It doesn't look that cool but if you want to go down this road, you surely can.

[b] Flaws [/b]
Welp, no game is without and Amalur definitely has some of its own. The face animations of NPCs are sometimes off which has them talking with closed lips. Graphics may be too low for some. The combat can get repetitive once you know the enemies movement pattern by heart (you can try using a new weapon to counteract that) and there isn't much enemy variety. Sure, there are upgraded versions of basic enemies. But their design is only altered slightly and the movement set is expanded a little. You don't feel like you are fighting a new enemy but an old one upgraded. Some may not be bothered by this, I was a bit. You will become overpowered if you quest a lot which I did, this dulls the late game somewhat. Speaking of, I feel like the last of the 5 regions you can visit is a bit too linear. Perhaps this is to fit the story, perhaps to fit the deadline...

[b] Conclusion [/b]
At the end, the good far outweights the bad. Amalur offers an unique approach to RPGs which deserves your attention. How much you are willing to spend is up to you but you will get around 30h gametime for sure, not counting in the DLCs. If you do a lot of quests and prefer to start a second playthrough over switching mid one, even 100h should be possible. 100 hours spent gloriously mowing down enemies in a rich and beautiful crafted world which, at the end of the day, should be the goal of any RPG.
