Since a remaster is coming, and their description seems to address none of the problems on the original, time to throw sheet on the fan \o/

This game is like someone got this amazing smoothie recipe, and then went [b]"this is soo good, I want to drink more!"[/b]
And then proceeded to water it down so hard you could call it an homeopathic smoothie.

The story is nice, side characters arcs are well written, voice overs are kinda wishy-washy but not to the point of being bad.
The combat feels nice, the "bRuTaL FaTeShIfT kIlLs" are nothing more than glorified quick time events for finishers, and there is some depth on character growth through combat and other skills. It's just on the slow side.
Nothing on this game feels really badly made. But nothing feels incredible either. And the game will feel nice at first.

Until you realize it's so unnecessarily LONG. Like, HUNDRED HOURS LONG. ON. A. SINGLE. PLAYTHROUGH.
You'll be repeating voice-overs in your head so much they'll become memes for you. And you laugh at first. Until the joke dies off. And you still have 3/4 of the game left to play
You'll be doing the same combat techs and engaging the same enemies. Over and over. And over. And over. And over.

I enjoy RPGs and actions games in general. I never skip cutscenes or text, and always do my best to follow story and pay attention to the overall story arc. This was the first game ever I went "I'm tired of this, I just wanna get home" and started skipping everything till the end. I was doing all sidequests, until I got to the last area, and noticed that the game was basically throwing another giant city with several other side-quests, IN THE MIDDLE OF A WARZONE. "Everyone that travels to those lands never come back to tell the story". Because they basically founded a city and are living quite well there. With commerce, sidequests and everything.

At that point, I straight out quit trying. "Cutscene Story Time" *skip* "Tedious walking session" *ignores enemies* "Tedious Forced Battle" *turns off brain* "Cutsc-" *skip* *skip* *skip*

And if you read the description of the remaster, you can guarantee it will ALL those things the same way again. But now they are twisting them as selling points.

72122739.review:
This unique looking RPG and its story originates through the minds of bestselling author R.A. Salvatore, Spawn creator Todd McFarlane, and The Elder Scrolls IV: Oblivion lead designer Ken Rolston. Although this game was not exactly the best result for 38 Studios, considering how they filed for bankruptcy shortly after its release, it is still a decent game with predominantly everything that you'd expect out of a "poster-cut-out" RPG. 

Essentially, you start out as a complete nobody, sadly like how many of us are in real life, until you are discovered to contain a special power or life-force of uncertain heroism, again like how many of us are NOT in real life, and as you would expect, your job to is to find out more about yourself and fulfill your destiny as the world's saviour. Although this game initially received mixed feelings when it was first released, you have got to hand it to the developers of 38 Studios that the general idea of a single man/woman being the supposed "chosen one" meant to save all of mankind and defeat the dark evils, that probably lurks just under your bed, is not a terribly overrated idea. This is considering, how many other games such as Skyrim, Greedfall, Witcher 2, Sekiro, StarWars: KOTOR, and many other similarities, have either fully adopted or partially used a strand of this primitive outline for their own storylines. I'm not saying that these games have done exactly like Kingdoms of Amalur, but rather, these games had done it better, with the exception of StarWars: KOTOR as that game is of its own supreme level and thus, might be covered by yours truly, in the future.

The gameplay, I would say feels like if the original God of War games had a baby with Dragon Age, and then in the mix came polygamy with Darksiders... then yeah, that's probably the best short description I can give you. On a real note, the gameplay wraps around a skill-based system where timing your button pressing skills would lead you to victory. Also, just like most action-based-button-pressings RPG's, this one does include a "rage mode", in or in this case, a "fate mode" where you literally wrestle with fate and use it to bash your enemy's head in. Sadly, unless you're into a full achievements Olympic track record, the replayability is not exactly there. Like Witcher 3, Kingdoms of Amalur is essentially a cakewalk after a few hours of character progression on the hardest difficulty and the only reason, that I would personally find, for going back would be the outcomes of the choices you make throughout the game.

Last but not least, the look of the game is amazing. It could be your alternate, less people-ish / less community-ish World of Warcraft game since the graphics, if you were to compare it, looks fairly similar. However, if you think that this game does not look like a Gordon Ramsay's Special Beef Wellington, then I have news for you. THQ Nordic purchased the rights for the game back in 2018 and plan to release a remastered version some time this year, 2020.

Underrated. The story is ignorable, but it's actually not all that bad if you decide to dive into it. Takes a little while to get going, and it's full of all the fantasy cliches, but it goes somewhere with it all. If I can get all pretentious about it, I'd say it's a meta-commentary on fantasy tropes. (But it probably isn't.) (But it could be.)
But screw all that you're here for the gameplay. It's got a fun, flashy, flexible combat system, interesting progression, and cool loot. (Although you'll be able to craft better weapons than most of what you'll find, if you decide to go into crafting.)  
It's got a beautiful art style that has kept it from aging too much, but I recommend a rehade mod to really make it pop. The first one you'll find on nexus mods does the trick for me. 
Also, It makes for an awesome podcast game, which is instantly a win for people like me who need to be doing multiple things at once. 
Buy this shit.

I've been putting off playing this game for a while, and I'm glad I finally got around to it. 

It plays a lot like a cross between God of War and Dragon Age, so if you're into the classic epic/power fantasy genre it's definitely something worth trying. 

While it's not got great mob diversity and many of the building layouts in a given zone feel cut/pasted, the game has excellent character/gear progression; story, side and faction quests that give you a great deal of choice, and each of the towns and cities have really well defined politics and prevailing cultural identities, making it very immersive. 

Although I don't think it's a particularly replayable game, it's absolutely worth playing. 8/10.

71529210.review: Great story, skills and custom weapons (Chakrams are my favorite by far). Lots of ways to develop your character and all builds are viable. You can be a jack of all trades or specialize. I went full magic and had a blast. The DLC story adds a way to craft custom weapons at which point it becomes a contest of how much you will overkill by due to the way damage boost stacks in this game (multipliers don't boost base damage, they boost current damage so it very quickly scales out of proportion). I killed the endgame DLC boss with a single autoattack :) Do note that if you are a minmaxer/completionist, you will need to get your Excel spreadsheet out and carefully plan things out. One annoyance is that each skill has 4 skill trainers (each can be used once) that can only be used within a specific skill point range (there are 9 skills with 10 levels each, trainers exist for levels 0-3, 0-3, 4-6, 7-9). If you assign too many skill points yourself, you miss a chance for a "free" skill point (you pay the trainer money). There are as many skill points coming from trainers overall as from leveling, so you can potentially miss out on 10s of free skill points solely due to bad planning.

71368455.review:
I haven't gotten very far into the game, but it is already giving me a lot to love. I am loving the lore that they give you throughout the game, the plot is interesting, the world is gorgeous, and the battle system is one of my favorite battle systems I've played in most any open-world rpg. While the character customization is a tid bit sparse, I am still able to create a character that looks good. One thing about the battle system that I absolutely adore (and that is present in a lot of my fave games) is the ability to use multiple weapons. It looks as though you also have the ability to combine battle styles later on into something truly unique. 

Also of note, giving me the ability to name the weapons/armor I create is dangerous. I will come up with the worst possible names for those things. That's part of the fun, though. 

There are only a few issues I have with the game that MAY have solutions that I haven't found yet? The first being that screenshots are automatically in .bmp format, which is not an ideal format for me when I wanna show off my character. I basically have to use steam's screenshot system, which isn't bad, but it's not my preference if there is a built-in screencap system already. Another thing is camera sensitivity is taking a bit of time to figure out ... but again, that's easily fixed. I'd like to be able to fix it so that the music/in-game sounds still play when I move to a different window, because as someone who streams that's kind of a nice thing to have, but I also really like that it pauses automatically during cutscenes just so I don't miss anything, so it's kind of a weird give and take there. Another thing is that there are times when you can get stuck in the terrain, and if you haven't saved recently, you might just be a bit out of luck ... especially when you're in a dungeon instance where you can't fast travel your way out of it. 

Other than that, I really don't have any real complaints about the game. I am loving it and I don't foresee me losing any love for it anytime soon.

71186465.review:
Good, but I can see how it wasn't a huge success. After learning how rough its development was, I'm amazed it's as good as it is. I give it a thumbs up, as it has been quite fun for me in spite of many drawbacks. I'm less than half way though so far, but I think I have enough time in to share my experiences.

Some specifics:
The lore is deep and could be interesting, but it still rather formulaic, and the delivery is awful. Collecting scraps of history scattered around the map feels like a chore. After awhile I stopped trying to talk to everyone I met as each additional NPC usually only added a tiny bite more information than any other. Fortunately everything that is important or involved in a quest or mission is very clearly marked with an icon, so you can just run through the story without exploring or thinking much if you want, but that in turn gives it a very linear feel.  

The inventory and crafting menus are a pain to navigate. In a game like this, having an inventory limit does not add a layer of strategy, it just makes picking up the loot dropped by enemies a chore. The nature of this game feels more like an old school, top down RPG in a 3D skin. As opposed to the weight limits in Fallout or Skyrim, it feels less like I need to plan my pack to travel light, rather that I need to make sure I unload all my loot before starting a new quest or going exploring, or I'll get punished for finding too many chests of loot.
While I love the idea of crafting my own potions, magic gems and custom equipment, it felt more like an attempt at a mini game or padding than anything useful. Early on there isn't much I can do with these skills, and by the time I progress enough to effectively use them, I've discovered  that I can usually just find better quality loot than I can craft. Maybe by the very late game stages that will change, but so far very little I've crafted has been that useful.

The combat is probably my favorite aspect so far, the concept of having your character able to twist their fate around, you are able to mock up some rather unique combat builds. All in one encounter, I can use my stealth to sneak up on a guard and assassinate them, then cut loose with with some wild magic attacks on the rest of the group, then go full ninja, darting around with my daggers or some cool boomerang/scythe weapons, then use my secondary weapon slot to break out a big azz war hammer, all without needing to even open a menu to swap out equipment. Of course I could do that too and really broaden my arsenal, which sometimes (though rarely) may be needed if an enemy is resistant to certain attacks. The diversity or weapons and spells is really nice. Essentially it's as though my one character represents what would have been a diverse party in another RPG. I have to admit I really do like the way that plays. 
Though it is not perfect here either, the camera sometimes will end up in the worst positions, making it hard to see. And the controls (on controller at least) along with the auto-targeting assist and attack animation frames means I frequently find my character lunging into spots I REALLY don't want them in at the worst times. Still, I generally find it quite enjoyable.

In short, this is a fun, less well known game. If you like these kind of games, I think it's worth picking up on sale. OR waiting for the remaster that is supposedly in the works. That my be a better, more polished version to pick up, we'll see.

71092230.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur feels like a single player MMORPG. Expansive areas, tons of dialogue, multiple quest hubs, tedious fetch and collect quests, busy-work and time-sinks. Basically everything but the presence of other players which is what gives life to MMOs. I tried very hard to like the game. I started 3 different playthroughs over the course of several years to finish it and get my money's worth but I can't bear the boredom. Judging from it's 'Very Positive' rating, many others enjoy KOA. Sadly it's not the game for me. 

PROS
+ Combat is fun and dynamic.
+ Spell and status effects are communicated well.
+ Game is not laggy. UI is quick and responsive.
+ Crafting offers varied results based on materials.

CONS
- Limited build customization. Linear and boring.
- Not challenging. I don't just mean combat.
- Not enough depth or complexity.
- Blocky/cartoony graphic style is not for me.
- Severely limited character model options.  
- 35 hours in, gear design seems samey.
- Game world feels artificial and lifeless.
- Generic story. You are the "Chosen One" yet again.
- NPCs were not interesting. They all felt the same.
- Tons of redundant, boring dialogue.

71031536.review:
I owned this game on PS3 in 2014 after playing the demo and just got all of the achievements for it on PC.
I can't recommend getting it full price because it is not fun for an extended /completionist playthrough, let alone a second playthrough.

This game has way too much padding, is way too long, and does not offer nearly as much variety as you will want. I feel like my character is a mary sue, with everyone (even your enemies) being impressed with you just following the basic main questline. Everyone tells you how amazing you are without you doing anything to earn it, even when you've completed a quest because it feels too easy/undeserved.

The dialogue is stale between how the characters deliver it, and their preset animations to go along with it. Encel in the beginning is a prime example of puffing up the character as amazing when you are a weak and easily killable level 1. I hate his stupid bewildered dialogue and it sets a perfect tone for the rest of the game.

The world is beautiful, though. Except for the dungeons and caves, dear god those suck. The game is really soft and colorful, even in Klurikon where the winter fae have scarred the land. Nothing is too sharp in this game.

The combat is meaty and satisfying, unless you're a mage for more than 10 hours. It gets stale when you hit the level 40 level cap and can no longer progress. But the leveling up system is quite fun and intuitive, while it lasts.

However, if you've never played it before, it is a ton of fun for the first several hours. But not fun after 122 hours.

If you've never played it, or want some GenCon 2013 vibes, pick it up. Just not at full price.

70957891.review:
I played this game for hours on the PS3 and all i have to say is this game is criminally underrated, if you like Fable and Skyrim check off all your boxes because this has it all. Fun and interesting story, amazing combat, fun colorful graphics and a class system that hits home to the old days of WoW with endless options to be the villain or hero you want to be.

The combat is tons of fun you can be a dual wielding rouge that stealth’s and backstabs or mix it with a mage, that blinks, drops some AOE and slashes their enemies to death. The customization and builds are fun and rewarding. Each weapon you use all has a different feel and the animations are pretty awesome to watch as you fight and dash around the screen.

Along with the neat combat system you will have something called the fate system that you can activate and use it tear your enemies a new one. You build this resource up over time from fighting and once unleashed can make even the most difficult of battles pretty easy. Definitely a power to keep in your back pocket for bosses and large groups of annoying enemies.

It’s been a while and I don’t really remember the story, but the gist, you were killed, you didn’t die and you are marked one of the ones that don’t have a fate. So now you are after some evil power to stop and thwart their plans from ending the world. Basic story but told very well with good voice acting and fun reading to keep you entertained. So if you are a story person, you should get some fun enjoyment.

Kingdoms is a vast game and promotes exploration, taking on the many side quests to level up and see all the nooks and crannies as you play, is a great way to enjoy the game. It can get repetitive and as you level and get better gear the challenge kind of falls to the way side, but the game itself is a gem that for most will stay unearthed and that’s sad.

The better news is, in August the remaster is releasing, its releasing for 39$ USD so if you have never played and started only hearing about it, I would wait out to August and get the revamped version with new combat, visuals and a few other treats. This game is highly underrated and really many others should check it out, so grab it on sale or wait for the remake, either way don’t pass this game up its another diamond in the rough.

70570364.review:
Second time giving this "underappreciate gem" a chance and, well.... I'm just going to say "mixed, but mostly bad." that's the TL; DR. 

Why, you ask? Because it's too flipping easy. Period. It just has no meaningful challenge or redeeming qualities to keep pulling you forward. Yes, it's huge, but the story is.... well, "trite" seems like an overstatement. It is a mish-mash of every single fantasy trope since tolkien. And that would be fine... but it doesn't give you a good reason to keep slogging through an endless, repetitive game. The loot is all same-y, the quests are near identical and the enemies look cool but don't require any real strategy. Yes, you can die a few times on hard mode if you aren't overly careful and don't level up blacksmithing... but it's usually from laziness.

The combat is mesmerizing and could have been truly amazing. I wish a more developed version existed for a TES or Witcher game. Those games, despite their many strengths, both really suffer when it comes to most of the combat. The combat is the shining star of this game... string together combos, dance fluidly around the enemies and crush them with awesome looking vfx.... but the 60,0000th time doing your combo on another enemy that presents no real threat, in a story that just never gets beyond "you, the chosen one must save the world!" .... well, let's just say the motivation to keep going is hard to come by. 

I didn't finish it, but can damn guarantee it was filled, to the end, with terrible accents/voice-over, cliched side plots and mediocre boss fights. I WANTED to like it so bad. Sadly the most I can say is "there was potential here, too bad."

- diff balance; no matter what, you'll get way overpowered, way too soon

- in general repetitive back-forward quests with mostly running around, simple "what to do" and unmemorable characters, eye candy with fun combat, but everything else is so incredibly average


[b]Summary: 6/10[/b] - gorgeous single player game with fun combat sadly lacking everywhere else; if it weren't for money problems and forced release, I'm sure they'd improve questing/gameplay loop. Sadly can't recommend for most people, but it can be a nice time killer after work if you won't want to think, just loot/level a bit - which Steam approval rate shows. Just don't get fooled expecting Oblivion, W3 etc. and it MIGHT surprise you

This is (in my opinion) in the top 3 best RPG games made in the 2010s. I have played it countless hours on xbox 360. PS3, Xbox one and on pc overall probably totalling 1000+ hours... I've never actually beaten the game though. All of the hours I have on pc are of one character doing all of the side quests and dialog in the first half of the game and the DLCs.

Pros: VERY LONG, Looks beautiful at times, Weapons and armor look badass, You FEEL powerful, its easy to get into character and immersed, A lot of customization on playstyle and design, plenty of weapon(even chakrams),large areas, and a fairly decent storyline, doesnt take too much space-quick loading times,

Cons: With how long it is it has possibility of being repetitive, It flips its difficulty a lot either you are an untouchable god or you are getting your shit rocked by 1 shot bosses tracking projectiles while he is immortal, Traveling takes a while the first time. names are forgettable (What's an "agarth") and finally there are 2 classes which are just leagues better than the rest which can sometimes make it hard to stray away from the usual, Oh and all the loot is completely random there are still several unique and set items I have never gotten.

This is one of my favorite games of all time and I think it is fantastic and everyone should atleast give it a try.

8.8/10 is my personal rating, while I love it I do think there are better MADE games and games with better STORIES, while this game makes you feel like the badass the story makes your character out to be it is easy and characters can be forgettable at times. It also has the problems of being occasionally glitchy. the randomized loot makes sense but also bothers me because this game has a gear set mechanic and its hard to even get 3 pieces of a 5 piece set(unless you are a mage in which case a 4 piece set)

7/10 for the dead kel dlc it simultaneously feels way too long and way too short, like the story feels rushed and weird but it also feels like the missions take forever to complete. besides that its fun, and gives you plenty of new powerful weapons, gear, and perks/buffs along the way. sadly you cant fast travel there after you beat it making 100%ing the area make it feel worthless to come back to after you do so (it also has several unremovable items that can enter your inventory)

8/10 for the teeth of narros for implementing new mechanics, a few even cooler weapons, a beautiful area, and a decent story. This one is better paced BUT a lot of the enemies hit way too hard and the final boss is a nightmare to deal with. Its pretty good and has better dungeons than dead kel but the drastic change in difficulty that happens here is too bothersome. If it wasnt for the 1 hit enemies I would have probably given it a better rating,

Overall I prefer the main game to the dlcs.

69856807.review:
[h1]ENTERTAINING, HUGE BUT REPETITIVE AFTER A POINT[/h1]

Kingdoms of Amalur is a big RPG in terms of the number of quests, map size, NPCs and a fun game when it comes to combat with it's diverse, fluid, easy to use mechanics and layout. If there's one thing that will make a decent impression on you after you complete this game is it's combat and if there's one thing that will give you a mixed feeling about the game is it's repetitiveness. Although, I must say that only completionists might feel the latter. The main quests along with the faction/guild quests really shine and will atleast make upto atleast 60 hours of quality content but when trying to complete the huge number of side quests and tasks, is where the game tends to remind you that the world of Amalur is infact not that diverse or perhaps even boring to an extent with it's not so different caves/dungeons, not so different enemies, NPCs boring the daylights out of you with their not so different voices and after you reach max level, there are no not so different anything. Though, there is a character build reset feature available through NPCs and two really good DLCs that offer some fresh air, it might not necessarily keep you hooked all the way to complete the game in its entirety. The problem with Kingdoms of Amalur is that you reach max level mid-way to completion or atleast that's what happened in my case where i maxed out around 130hrs of my 214hr playthrough. After maxing out, the game goes stale. Thinking of it, I would say that the game can really be enjoyed if you are casual about it and not particularly a completionist. After all, it's an arcadey RPG. 

A break-up on how I felt about the game:     
 
[table]
[tr]
	[td][b]Story[/b][/td]
	[td][b]8/10[/b][/td]
	[td]Never before heard story but it's you as always who is saving the world. Nice lore and immersive to an extent.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Graphics[/b][/td]
	[td][b]7/10[/b][/td]
	[td]Colourful, vibrant and kind of cartoony. Quite like Fable.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Sound[/b][/td]
	[td][b]7.5/10[/b][/td]
	[td]In-game soundtracks, environmental sounds, NPC voice-overs, Combat etc all sound pretty good.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]DLCs[/b][/td]
	[td][b]10/10[/b][/td]
	[td]The two DLCs, especially The Legend of Dead Kel offer solid content.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Gameplay[/b][/td]
	[td][b]8.5/10[/b][/td]
	[td]Cool combat with new weapons, interesting character build combinations, engaging main and faction missions, decent depth in smithing, alchemy and crafting.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Difficulty/Challenge[/b][/td]
	[td][b]5/10[/b][/td]
	[td]Hard start but gets easy as you level up.[/td]
[/tr]
[tr]
	[td][b]Controls[/b][/td]
	[td][b]9.5/10[/b][/td]
	[td]Fluid and easy to use layout. Controller preferred. [/td]
[/tr]
[/table]

Kingdoms of Amalur is a good RPG but for it's fast character level up and the lack of diversity after a point, making it a chore from a completionist's standpoint. 

[h1]MY SCORE: ★︎★︎★︎★︎★︎★︎★︎✰︎✰︎✰︎[/h1]

69764916.review:
38 Studios' issues notwithstanding, this was actually a very good game.

It's got a lot of good takes on RPG elements and for a 2012 game, actually innovated pretty well on them.

I think it's missing things modern players would expect now since they're ubiquitous at this point - more appreciable impact from dialogue choices, character romances, and robust new game plus options. That's not to say it isn't worth anyone's time though. 

Character creation is good, but it's definitely not winning the award when you consider its writing pedigree - R.A. Salvatore is a wonderful writer and is of course very familiar with the denizens of The Forgotten Realms - so I was surprised that in a game for which he was the world-builder, the player race choices aren't as varied as I'd like - in terms of silhouette, they're all pretty much the same. Still, it's not bad for what you get, it's just not as varied as someone who is familiar with Salvatore through familiarity with DnD might expect.

Character development on the other hand, is terrific and deserving of praise. It kind of parrots the better things about Fable's character development - you have distinct spheres of abilities to choose from and the "class" you get as a label for your character morphs based on what choices you're making. I was a huge fan of diving deep into the melee tree and then investing half as much into the magic tree to create a blink-stepping mage knight. You could do quite a bit - very similar to Fable with the same general spheres covered by its "Strength, Skill, and Will" system.

Combat is fun and over time you actually get upgrades that make things feel like you've progressed - in-combat maneuvers and things that would have caused you trouble early on are much easier later. I did not think it really did anything super wild with the combat - you have pretty standard functionality with block, dodge, ranged attacks, and spells. The game really wants you to engage in melee a bit even if you're playing an archer or mage, but it gets lesser over time. One thing I will touch on is that the melee combat feels appropriately chunky and the heavier weapons feel really weighty and powerful. Additionally, fighting the very large enemies is pretty interesting.

The story is good - I still think the general premise is actually relatively unique - somewhat problematic pronunciations of Celtic mythological concepts notwithstanding - and I think it does a solid job moving you along and motivating you to play through. The sidequests are relatively standard, but you do get some cool rewards through them, like unlocking your house in some places.

RPG features are hit or miss outside of the above concerning your character stats and abilities; you kind of lack agency in the story as another "chosen one" kind of character, and you don't really change much with your dialogue, but you do get some interesting things like housing and there is a good chunk of background myth, history, and plot to be discovered by simply running around reading books and encountering landmarks.

Finally, I do think the visual style is hit-or-miss with people - it's like a slightly less stylized World of Warcraft, on the whole. Characters are big, bulky, and primary-colored. Armor sets are a little less wild in the shoulders department, but there's definitely a distinctly modern high fantasy style to all of the equipment and the colors are very saturated. I like that personally, but it's definitely not a game with a realistic-slant in terms of visuals.

The only other thing I'd comment on is that it's mostly a solo endeavor and that sometimes makes the world feel a little empty - you do encounter a lot of NPCs and sometimes have combat helpers, but it doesn't feature a robust party system for managing a crew of allies.

69744108.review:
Yep, it's worth playing, BUT better take into consideration that it can take over 100h to complete (note: I had both story expansions included). Sure, you can skip all the side quests, but I wouldn't recommend that - the lore and little stories are the best this game has to offer in the plot department. The main quest and characters are so plain and cliche I doubt I'll remember any of that after a month. 

There are some side activities (crafting, lorestone collecting) and a few quests introduce some variety (e.g. there is a quest in the gnome city where you need to decipher a code), but without a doubt combat is the main activity here. And while it is satisfying, it's nothing stellar and after all this time it got rather boring. I doubt speed-running the game would help, if anything it would just rob the experience of all the other good things. I think the game would benefit from having less random encounters and being shorter.

Also, the final boss is a joke.

69391439.review:
After playing Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning, it has become one of my favorite games that I honestly find myself coming back to. A lot.
I started playing this game sometime in 2017~2018(?) through Origin. I ended up buying it on Steam, too, and thought I'd share my thoughts.

Character Creation
Now, this game has pretty decent character customization which is what I normally love and gravitate towards when looking for any Fantasy RPG. You can decide which gender to play and choose between 4 races. The hairstyles are much cooler and prettier than most hairstyles I've seen in current character creation in some games (least in my opinion and my experience). The faces and jewelry and tattoos are really awesome too, I especially love the piercings options, they're really great. So if you're someone who really loves character creation, this game has it, I gotchu.

Story
I really liked the story and all the side quests! Everything is literally and fully voice-acted and it is so nice. You'll recognize a lot of the VA's also. I've recognized many from Dragon Age among others! I love it so much because it's nice to be able to feel like you're actually there and talking to whomever you choose. Subtitles are optional as well. And the characters you meet in story and through side quests are so expressive sometimes! It's very refreshing and fun and adds so much more charm to the game. 

Gameplay
I cannot get enough of how good the combat feels. Literally, if you have been looking for a game with satisfying combat, and awesome finishers, you have found it. Hands down, it is so fun to play this game and fight enemies. You can dodge but cannot jump (except you are able to jump down from high ledges). My ONLY gripe is that the camera isn't great but I honestly got used to it and it doesn't affect my experience.
Now let me explain the class division while I'm at it.
*Classes are divided into 3 categories which have accumulated all related weapon skills(combos and awesome "Moves") and abilities within them:
-Sorcery (magic weapons+skills)
-Finesse (rogue weapons+skills)
-Might (knight weapon+skills)
It's super simple to work with and you are free to apply skill/ability points to either category based on your personal preference. You are not restricted by which category/class you choose. And you are able to later reapply all skills later sometime in-game to try the other class categories. (Which you would eventually have to decide/change from trying out all the weapons as I will explain below)
Not only that, there are nine different weapons to choose from which you are freely able to use without class restrictions. Let me break it down.
*Nine weapons, 3 per class category, are available to use and are in no way are you restricted from using them UNLESS they require a certain amount of skill points in said-class category. (Ex. a weapon requires Level 3 Sorcery). Each weapon gets their own super cool combat animations and its so GOOD.
>Might Weapons
-Longswords
-Greatswords
-Hammers
>Finesse Weapons
-Longbow
-Dual Daggers
-Faeblades (SUPER FUN DUAL DAGGERS)
>Sorcery Weapons
-Staves
-Sceptres
-Chakrams (SUPER FUN MAGIC THING)

Crafting+Inventory
The crafting in the game is super fun and easy! You can Sagecraft gems (that buff your weapons+armor), and craft armor+weapons(Blacksmith) and potions(Alchemy). Resources are literally everywhere and they drop pretty frequently from enemies and loot spots but never overshadow weapon+armor drops. It's really awesome and so satisfying. And your resources DON'T affect your inventory space for each one collected. All resources have their own pouches to keep in and makes it super awesome to freely collect resources while also looting for everything else. You also get to move whatever loot you find into your Junk space, making it easy as heck to immediately sell when shoppin'. 


TL;DR
In my opinion and from having played this game and truly loving it, I believe Kingdoms of Amalur is a really great game. I regret not buying it upon its release back in 2012.
I highly recommend Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning and I hope my review helps some of you come to a decision!
Good luck and have fun!

68829400.review:
TL;DR this game is Not not enjoyable... for the most part. But it is not skyrim. 

Before I state whether the game was bad or good (spoilers, it was pretty meh), you must first understand that 38 studios had a pretty rough experience with the birth of the game and those troubles that the studio had does contribute to the end-result of the game. (there is a mini documentary about this on youtube but i'm pretty sure you've already seen it. if not, it's worth checking out) 

It wasn't a horrible experience. After I actually started to progress through the game's story and map, it was enjoyable and fun. I remember a specific moment when I stumbled into a dark valley-like area with lots of spiderwebs and large centipede looking creatures when out of nowhere a half-woman half-spider monster appeared and scared the hell out of me. Exploration is great (albeit VERY linear), monster variety is not bad (what I wish BOTW could do better in), and the fighting mechanics are fluid and fantastic.
BUT
Very very soon it's easy to discover how repetitive the quests can be. Sure, the concepts and ideas for these quests are creative and great in theory, but the tasks themselves and what you do as the player behind the monitor does get bland because it is an unfortunate case of rinse and repeat. I also try not to focus on graphics too much when it comes to judging a game, but some of the facial animations (like with  a lot of games, let's be fair) aren't the most pretty or fluid.

Having played games like Skyrim really conditioned me into raising my expectations for fantasy/rpg/exploration games which lead me to be incredibly disappointed with this game. I really wish I could go and explore the rest of this game's world, but I know it may not be fully worth it for me. Not the best review, I'm a scatterbrain. whatever.

I want you to understand that I have a soft spot for this game, but here’s the objective truth:
I’ve played over 140 hours of this game between platforms.
I was not riveted to my seat every bit of the way, I wasn’t jumping for joy from character dialogue or gripped with intrigue as I was given another grinding task. I was not fixated by the all-powerful invincible nature of the main character.
However
I was pleasantly playing through it like one does a new book, I found myself weaving my own stories and narratives where the originals were lacking, I fantasized about how amazing the game could be if given a proper sequel. I reveled at the size, scope, and variety that the game had to offer – and chewed through to 100% my account on my XBOX and am close to 100% again here on Steam.
It’s not a perfect game, but it’s also not without charm.

If you’re fascinated with world building, good combat, the climb for getting stronger, and 100% completing a game – this game is for you.

7/10
Kingdoms Of Amalur: Reckoning is a Good game.
While it has its own innate shortcomings – there is honestly nothing like it, and I cherish the time I’ve had playing it.

Solid 8/10, ~50hr experience on average if you beat the game, more than 80 if you want to do  e v e r y t h i n g.

I like to think of it as a single player WoW in 4K with compelling world building, excellent music, and great voice acting.

There's an over-arching main quest that drives you steadily east through a forest of massively tall trees, a desert, and a swamp and these zones feature some of the best quests I've ever played. Just like WoW you design your own character with a lot of customization in looks, skills, stats, armor, weapons, and even narrative (through quest choice). Combat is fluid and fun, but becomes quite easy later on - especially if you abuse systems like smithing and crafting. 

Unfortunately, the development of the game was tumultuous and the quality of the game does suffer. What you would expect to be the second half of the game (leaving on a ship from the main city, Rathir, to fight the Big Bad Evil Army) is short and fairly unimpressive compared to the first half. Thankfully, the ending brings some decent closure. 

If you enjoy action RPGs, fantasy, World of Warcraft, or Irish/Gaelic folklore and don't mind some flaws you should buy this game, especially if it's on sale!

*Edited a bit after playing the game in its entirety.

Pros:
- In-Game cutscenes and dialog conversations (So it always shows what you're wearing).
- All the quests feel unique and not repetitive.
- Tons of fully-voiced dialog about the lore of the world.
- Laura Bailey, Liam O'Brien, Matt Mercer and many other great voice actors
- Able to make any type of build and can re-spec at pretty much any time.
--- I like how they tie this concept into the premise of the main story.
- Combat is very fluid and can allow you to create interesting combos.
- Great looking armor and weapons
- The game loads so fast (no long wait times when entering a new zone)
- Large, Open World.
- Neat art style that still looks good for a game that came out in 2012

Cons:
- I really dislike the loot tables in this game. You mage to open very hard locks or wards and it awards you with white items and basic healing potions.
- Persuasion doesn't seem to have any repercussions for failing and you don't need to invest any points in it to still have a small chance at succeeding.
- On the hardest difficulty, some bosses can just flat out one-shot you depending on the build.
I find this forces you to guzzle down dozens of potions before each fight just to be effective.
- There isn't really anything to do with all the money you collect. The game gives you tons of items so you never really need to buy anything.
- You can very easily make Fate Potions which turns any combat into an easy one-sided massacre (even on boss fights).
- Combat can be somewhat annoying. Enemy attacks will always fully interrupt you (unless you use the warrior ability), which will happen quite often with multiple enemies. Combined with the fact that most abilities have a slight charge up time and lock you into the animation, it is frustrating playing a build that doesn't involve you destroying everything with a large AoE meteor that can't be interrupted.
- Armor sets don't really mean anything. They don't scale and cannot be upgraded. You will most likely have better gear by the time you do manage to find all the pieces.

8/10

67408310.review:
The debut and swan song of the short lived 38 Studios.

KoA... has its issues. Though it is built on solid enough foundations, much of its execution is dodgy.

If you're familiar with any of the Elder Scrolls, Gothic, Risen, Two Worlds, etc. template of open world ar-pee-gee then KoA isn't going to surprise you. The only thing KoA really has going for it over its cousins is its over-the-top action combat. It's actually pretty sick the scale and special effects and animations of the combat moves you can pull off - and they only get more absurdly awesome as you level up.

The rest of the combat has problems, however. Enemy movement and attack tracks you 1:1. Because of this, the game treats dodging as little more than a vague suggestion. Dodging isn't about moving sufficient distance out of the way of an attack because the hit will track you regardless. It is more about the timing of the dodge, and even then the game is often like "LuLz naw that didn't happen."

Enemies get to doge with impunity, however, since they always move such that they're conveniently out of your range of attack. This makes the ranged weapon types and magic a dominant strategy, the cackrum especially. Even then they can spam attacks and every hit stun locks you. This can result in groups of enemies locking you into an endless attack combo gang rape that you have no hope of getting out of. For enemy attacks with follow up hits, you WILL take the subsequent hits. You, however, get to rely on the RNG gods to stun and interrupt enemies.

This all wouldn't be so bad if you could treat combat like a sort of chess match, where taking turns defending and picking the right attack for the appropriate target made combat into a tactical affair. Alas, the game uses "soft" auto targeting for attacks that is waaay too hard for the finesse that combat requires. It's sometimes so bad that spells that should place enemies well within their area of effect sail right past em.

The combat isn't utterly broken, though. It's just constantly aggravating. It can be satisfying but it can also get plenty of repetitive.

The rest of the game is pretty standard fare. Run around, complete quests, get rewards, sell junk. We've played this game before.

Enemy level is set to whatever region you're in. They don't level with the player at all. This might be considered a solid for people who criticize Elder Scroll's strict system of matching the player's level, but here it means that regions are gated by stronger enemies and areas you've been to are populated exclusively by enemies you can sneeze at and obliterate and receive no expee or relevant loot from.

The game does boast a ... "unique" presentation. Graphically its artistic style is somewhat refreshing from the norm. It's this colorful edgy fairy tale aesthetic that's a nice change from the usual gritty grimdark fantasy we're used to seeing. However, dungeon layouts are arranged like they were generated from building blocks by a logic processor with no end of reused assets. Even Skyrim's caves are more diverse than KoA's dungeons. And the overworld is this square grid of regions connected by narrow passages. It's not an organic looking world. To use my early analogy, it looks like something a logic processor assembled. Visually, however, the different areas all have their own unique aesthetic with some nifty visual touches here and there.

The story is pretty unique. It's an original enough concept penned by regarded fantasy authors including R. A. Salvatore and comes complete with its own extensive original world building. The concept and premise for Amalur is something I can get interested in. Your mileage may vary.

But there isn't much to do beyond combat and yucking it up with amalur's yokels. The dialog is awfully pedestrian and the characters largely forgetable.

Stealth is an absolute joke and it seems as though the designers only took stealth into account for select instances in certain quests. Even so you can just run all in sword point first anyway making stealth not so much a dominant strategy as a pointless waste of time. The problem is that enemies are programmed to either randomly wander or sit around waiting for you in such a way that they can always see you coming and there's never anything to hide behind.

By the end Amalur is left with some noteworthy if problematic combat and an original enough story and world to be compelling. It can't compare to the scale and sophistication of games like Skyrim, but it has enough of its own uniqueness and problems to offer.

You could either be intrigued and entertained - if slightly frustrated by combat woes - or painfully bored out of your skull playing Amalur.

For that, I wish I could give Amalur a simple middle of the road rating, but since Steam likes to keep things simple I'll give it a recommendation just for not being completely blinkered.

Before I had steam, I got this game from a gamestop. Long ago, only now am I recently finally playing it because it installed onto my steam account, which is awesome. I knew I shouldn't of expected much, in fact I expected nothing really, just a fantasy adventure rpg. The combat is the worst thing though, actually worse than most combat systems in its day with the day hitting, attacking, and lock ons work. I'm a heavy melee centric kind of person. I have a big sword, a shield, and a bow. I'm usually good to go but for some reason I feel more punished doing this over magic than anything else due to how combat is. Leveling is super slow as well and progression is very odd in this game. It's a limited free roam experience essentially iwth level zones. However instead of making sure you're a level you need to be you can enter zones far higher than your level from the looks of it. I still haven't died mind you but weapons just seemed to be tooth picks against certain creatures in the zones and nothing really gives weapon rewards.

It has fast travel so that's really nice actually, just have run everywhere to discover places form what I can tell, mind you even with 12 hours I still didn't get far (save files on different computers, putting hte game down after 2 days and picking up after a year so start overs.) My next issue are quest markers, it has them which is nice and I love it, but then you get quest markers that are "hey bring this person these things" okay where are they. "Oh we're not showing you, we're just going to stay over the dude that asked for them." Which there are a couple of quests like this, tehy don't show you but rather show you were you got the quest. Why bother with a quest marker/tracker when it's not going to work all the time? Pair this with the progression is just pretty sluggish to get through certain parts. I think my main issue is that the leveling is tied to their freeze time ability, you get it early, you stack up a special and when you activate it it freezes time essentially and lets you attack monsters. When you complete it you can do a special interaction that'll increase exp earned by 25%-100%. My issue? I save it. This feels like a clutch ability when you need it, especially since there is zero health regen in this game and no ability to heal with.

Personally, I had a bad experience. When I finally sat down and actually played this game wiht intent to finish I just can't bring myself to because I hate this combat system, I hate the quest rewards, and I hate the leveling system. Maybe if I played with a friend it would be better, joking about the elves and the horny scaling they have for humans. Another plus was the spruce mustache I got but outside of that there was nothing really saving this game for me. THere are other fantasy rpg games out there that do much better than what this game does. I'll probably just watch a playthrough so I can at least see what the story is but man, really disappointed in it even with no expectations I was let down.

A final note would be that the weapons DLC feels really waste of money. I got that when I got the game from gamestop, I think, I don't even know where I got it actually. However the armor/weapons DLC is pointless, you get a replacement for all of the stuff they give you almost immediately and you can buy better stuff right off the bat. This wouldn't of been an issue if maybe it lasted me to the 3rd zone, at least, but it's replaced so fast there's just no point in even equiping them. It's actually better to get them out fot eh starting zone city chest and sell them right away then buy better gear. It's just such a waste of actual money.

67331121.review:
KoA was one of those games I debated recommending or not for a fairly long time and had to go with no- not because it was a bad game but just because it was kinda too meh considering the options that are out there these days. Granted it's an 8 year old game at time of writing made by a developer that doesn't exist anymore so maybe its fair to say skip it?

If Diablo2 and Skyrim had a baby, it would be this game hands down. However, it lacks both the compulsive draw of Diablo and the immersive depth of Skyrim. Sound, animation, environments, abilities and UI (unless you have a large monitor) are all very good and there is nothing strikingly wrong with it but, after 18 hours of giving it a good shot, I'm super bored with the game. Maybe that’s enough for the couple bucks I bought it for on sale but I'm only in zone 3 of, like, 20-some and have no motivation to continue seeing what's next.

Combat is fine but samey, environments are pretty but lack intrigue and the story exists but is uninspired. You get easily lost in the constant string of nouns that defiantly feel like they were spit out of a fantasy name generator without thinking about player readability. I was once asked to collect some alviek root from the Geharyra cave at the far end of the Sarsanus river in the Dyssueh province and you wouldn't know which name I made up because the game throws so many in one ear, out the other words at you all the time.

The lack of readability meant I was in my quest log about as much as I was in the world trying to figure out what there was to do around me and where I actually needed to go to. Eventually I got fed up with it and just ignored quests entirely to go explore but even that was frustrating in its own right with around half the places I went to go explore into being locked until I had the appropriate quest ready to let me in…

So, in conclusion, I cant say it’s a bad buy if you get it for cheap. Sub $10 will get you at least 8-10 hours of exploration and enjoyment but don’t expect a whole lot. Also, if you have a large monitor, expect known UI bugs with the menu that the non-existent developers aren’t going to fix.

67236023.review:
For this review, I'm going to do a pro/con list then give my final thoughts/TL;DR (if you're not up for reading this long review). Most important parts of the game, particularly the cons, are bolded. some context: This is after beating the main story and doing a large portion, perhaps 70%, of the zone/side quests. Also, no DLC. 

Pros:
-Combat feels really good.  Can't quite put my finger on why specifically, for the most part. Some of the spells are quite elaborate and feel very powerful though.

-The lore itself is interesting and well made. It's presented in a natural way through mediums like item descriptions, side quests and books. The worldbuilding is probably this game's strongest aspect. It's more-or-less what kept me going for so long. 

-The devs put in quality of life features you might not find in some games. Or at least, in 2012. 

Cons:
-Gear progression is messed up. After a relatively early point in the game, you don't really find a lot of gear that's better than what you have. I've heard blacksmithing gives better gear, but you don't find much as far as drops go. Not that you really need blacksmithing to have an easy time

-Difficulty is generally not linked to rewards. This applies to both combat and skills. You could lockpick a very hard difficulty chest and get a minor healing potion. It provides very little incentive to go bother with chests after a certain point. The same applies for skippable enemies. 

-Economy is messed up. After a point, gold becomes completely irrelevant, as you have more than enough to buy whatever you need. Quest rewards also become worthless

[b]-Combat is tedious[/b]. Let me preface this by saying I'm not a huge fan of this type of combat. There is little variety in the enemies you face and most of the enemies you'll fight are just generic monsters, even in higher level zones. There's a few variations, but not enough to make a huge difference. Attacks are often easy to deal with between how few are allowed on the screen at any one time and AoE attacks.
Another issue: The block button isn't reactive enough. I think the issue is animations can't be cancelled at all. 
Third issue: There isn't enough variety of weapons and abilities for each path. Or at least, if you play on doing a pure warrior, rogue or mage.  Especially applies earlier on in the game when you can't earn your abilities (you have few spells early). You will probably respec your abilities at some point. Not because you necessarily want to, but because you'll have tried everything offered for your preferred playstyle and grow bored.


-Some quality of life issues are not present. I know I praised it in the pro section, but this can really hamper you. One of the biggest examples: Potions take up an inventory slot. This doesn't sound like a huge issue, right? Wrong. There are multiple versions of each potion and there are 25-ish types of potions. Most potions also drop from enemies or can be found in chests. Potions can easily account for 1/3 or half of your inventory space, depending on how many backpacks (increase your inventory by 10) you've bought .

-Inventory space is small. 

[b]-Main story is very disappointing[/b]. The structure  is there, but nothing else. We don't spend a terribly large amount of time with any of the characters, even the main ones. You also do not have any companions/squadmates as you would in Mass Effect or Dragon Age. What these two things mean is you don't have many opportunities to interact with the main characters and even when you do, they don't have much to say. What does this mean? It means you end up not caring. Not going to go into spoilers, but a certain choice at the end of the game doesn't have a very large impact on you as a player.

The questline is also quite short for a main quest. Wouldn't be a huge issue, but there's not many quests which tie in to the main one until the end. Ultimately, the main quest feels devoid of life, lacking that "spark" which really makes them feel immersive and special. 

-Game is very grindy. The main quest moves far quite quickly.  It feels as if the devs expected you to grind through all the zones in the process. That can add up quickly. Most of my playtime is probably just zone quests. In fact, I went around doing everything in each zone I had to go through before I just said screw it and tunnel zoned the main quest. 

[b]-Game is buggy.[/b] Not unplayable or even disruptive most of the time, but you will notice if you play enough. My main issues (off the top of my head at least):
 * My first time, I ran into a game-breaking bug where loading my save file would cause the game to freeze. Couldn't find a solution online. I rage quit and didn't pick up the game until recently. As of this writing, my account has about 102 hours logged, but you can subtract 26 of those hours because of this
* Undeletable/sellable items. There are some items in your inventory you simply cannot get rid of, even after their relevant quests. This problem is exacerbated by the fact that your inventory starts off sort of small 
* There is a horribly bugged questline I've discovered in the game. It's every quest in the red marches zone. According to the wiki, this quest can disable fast travel for the rest of the game at a certain point. Obviously, this is quite game-breaking. 

TL;DR: I've seen other people say this game is a hidden gem. I think that's very generous. The progression systems leave you with no reason to bother looting things beyond books and flavour text on epic and set items. Combat is boring and left me with no real reason to ramp up the difficulty, despite how undertuned normal difficulty was. The main story was so hollow that most of the sides questlines actually had a larger impact on me.  Amalur has the potential to be game-breakingly buggy. If it's not, you'll still notice the bugs. 

Kingdoms of Amalur starts out strong, but you eventually notice all its problems. If you have *a lot* of free time and low expectations, I'd say Amalur is a good buy. But for everyone else, this is a waste of time. Instead, check out just about any other RPG. Perhaps Jade Empire or any of the other old-bioware games.

Edit: 
I have now completed the Teeth of Naros expansion. Now THAT is what I'd call a "hidden gem" in this dunghill of a game. It doesn't solve any of Amalur's problems. But the story was well written, the characters were enjoyable to interact with (especially secandra) and the city of Idylla was fun to explore. If you're like me and played the base game fully first, you should be at the point where gear and levels are irrelevant. You just have to stomach the annoyance that is combat. It's about 10 hours of playtime. If you already have Amalur, I'd say the expansion is worth the time you put into it. It's worth doing.

67132439.review:
I bought it some years ago and finally I had a run where I completed this game.

Overall I would give it a positive review but there are also some aspects of the game which bothered me a bit.

PROS:
- The main story is pretty nice. It has been narrated quite well through the main quest with much lore but understandable and not too irritating.
- The possibilities regarding to the play style are plenty. You can mix the classes a bit and the skill system is pretty neat. You have to be an epic idiot to set the skills completely wrong.
- The visual style of the game is okay. Mostly a little bit too colourful for my liking but okay. Some of the greater showplaces have been designed and staged very well.
- I really liked the fighting system. If the enemies wouldn't have been complete blockheads most of the time it could have unfolded its whole potential. It's easy to learn but if you want to be more dynamic and dodge the enemy attacks with style it can be a bit challenging. Nice.

CONS:
- When you do every quest and also play the DLCs you reach the max. level of 40 quite fast. And with the right equipment and skills nothing is a challenge anymore, especially late game. It was by far too easy. On my final run I mainly specialized in magic skills with equipment which pushed my element damage to new heights and at the final area I only had to flock the enemies together to dash in a meteor or a lightning pillar to erase all of them at once, even on hard mode. Became a bit boring.
- The world is really big...a bit too big at some points. I really love huge game worlds but Amalur was just very rambling sometimes with huge areas where you can't find something interesting anyway. The exploring aspect of the game is very disappointing. There are several chests and hidden loot places but the loot mostly isn't worth the search. Exploring the small corners of the world isn't very rewarding in my opinion.
- The loot is horrible most of the times. When I open a chest after a very hard dispel I don't want to expect a single common alchemy ingredient. And that happened too often even in the late areas.
- Most of the side quests are terribly uninspired. 90% of them follow the old "Go to this place, get this thing/kill this dude, come back" - pattern without a nice backstory like straight from a subprime MMORPG. And there were too many of them.

Altogether the game is quite good. The story is nice, the skill- and fighting system is pretty exciting and it aged well in my opinion. The visual style is okay. The loot system and the side quests aren't very promising compared to other big open world games.

67002099.review:
A good rpg game of ps3/360 time with some nice features.

First the good things:

1.	In genereal, graphics are good for the time and have that "fantasy" style similar to old WoW.
2.	The "destiny" (class) system which allows you to change when you want, also can combine to play as a hybrid class.
3.	The gameplay combat is simple but fun. Two weapons, weak/strong attack and some abilities.
4.	"Pure" class are strong especially a full pure mage is extremely op with one hit skill kill and huge AoE.
5.	Some armors and weapons have cool designs.
6.	The game is easy even on hard difficulty, only a few situations that can be complicated because there is a lot of enemies.
7.	Achievements are relative easy to unlock but some are misseable. If you want to unlock it all, then is recommended to use a guide or play the game more that once.
8.	There are passive skills like persuasion, alchemy, craft that offers a bonus to the game.
9.	You can create easilly op broken weapons and armors by upgrading 2 of the passive skills.

Now the bad things:

1.	The story it starts basically with "who are you" but then is just go to place A "you are different", go to place B "what are you", go to another place and repeat.
2.	Just three races: human, white elf and blue elf.
3.	No variety in the enemies, some change of colors or with a small variation.
4.	Only one of the two dlc is fun.
5.	You can't take companions/allies with you, also no friendship or romance system.
6.	Hybrid classes doesn't have any special or exclusive ability, just different stats/bonuses.

7/10

In general is a fun rpg but don't expect features more deeper that are presents in others games of the same time (DA, ME, Skyrim).

66942554.review:
If I could forget everything about a game just so I could re-experience its magic again, this would be the one and only game that made me feel that way. This game does have some missteps, believe me. I find the pure-RNG loot system to be atrocious  for playing my character exactly how I want to as well as ruining the fashion side of things, I strongly dislike how crafted gear at mid-game is miles better than most of the 'legendary' equivalents (Unique gear and Set armor) you find in the world, and at end game makes the game downright brain dead on hard. Crafting making the game trivial is then doubled down on due to the lack of both a 'Very Hard' mode and NG+ to give the enemies a boost once your character is leveled, geared, and specced how you want them to be.

Despite all of that however, I still think this game is better than Skyrim (released a year earlier) and at least on par with Dragon's Dogma (which came out 3 months after Reckoning). One of my biggest gripes with RPGs where you create the character is that I always feel like I'm forced to play the way the Devs wanted me to, through class systems, or there's too much freedom and the only limits on a character's abilities are self-imposed. Reckoning allows you to become a Jack of all Trades, stopping you from becoming a master in all, but also giving you different bonuses based on the "class" you are.

Everytime you level up, you get three skill points you can spend in three skill trees; Might, Finesse, and Sorcery. These three skill trees of course correspond to the typical three classes Warrior, Rogue, and Wizard. However you are allowed to spend these points how you will, and your allocation of points determines your "Destiny", this game's equivalent of a class. You can play a pure finesse character, and receive bonuses related to all the weaponry, armor, and skills relating to that tree from the related Destiny. Or you could play a finesse/might character, which locks away your access to some of the highest tier skills in both trees, but allows you to take advantage of different skills and passives from both, and have a Destiny with bonuses relating to those two trees.

Combining this excellent skill system with the different weapon moves you unlock along the way allows combat to feel extremely dynamic, and rewards thinking about what order you use skills, dodges, and weapon attacks. I cannot get over how rewarding the combat in this game feels. Of course, this comes back to the main drawback; this game becomes trivial, and there aren't really any enemies who will force you to think on your toes. From the poor area leveling system which leads to you easily overleveling, to the fact that you can use healing potions and even open up your menu to chug other buffs while performing other actions or while being staggered means that if you die while playing this game, you probably weren't paying attention at all.

When you are in a leveled zone, and you are fighting relatively difficult enemies, this game can be very fun. Even without that, I think that playing with the different abilities and Destinies has quite a bit of potential. Nothing in the game really pushes you all that hard, sadly. I'm going to recommend Reckoning based on its extremely enjoyable combat and character building, but be ready to be disappointed in the lack of an NG+ to help bump the difficulty.

66756422.review:
Why doesn't Steam have a "thumbs sideways" option?  That's what I'd rate this, a solid "meh". (Sorry, Ellen.)  Going to hit thumbs-down just because the current "Very Positive" is somewhat overrated.

It's a perfectly serviceable game, but it's not pulling me in like Skyrim or Oblivion did. My complaints are mostly nit-picks, but there are a lot of them. The keyboard bindings are awkward. A controller feels much better, but is a poor choice for a mage build, as you can only have four spells mapped to buttons.  The only way to cast others is to go into the menu, map them to a button, cast, then back to the menu to return to the first mapping.  You *can* use the keyboard in conjunction with a controller and select spells that way, but it's not reliable. Any touch of the controller disables the keyboard. The next key pressed re-enables it, but that key is not taken as a command. So you have a spell in slot 5. Press '5' to activate it. But really, that only activated keyboard mode. You have to press '5' again to select the spell, then right-click to cast it. Bump the controller in between and you're back in controller mode so the right-click isn't accepted.

When combat works, it's good. Fire a spell, dodge one blow, block another, finish off the monster with your weapon. It feels cinematic and bad-ass.  When it works.  Ranged abilities are auto-targeted, and the game usually picks the nearest enemy. So you have an enemy advancing from the front that you try to shoot, but another one standing to the side is slightly closer so the auto-targeting whips around to them instead. One of the mage spells lets you mark a number of enemies then ignite all marked enemies into flame. Only marking them is a ranged ability, and you'll often end up marking the same one repeatedly because it's a little bit closer to you than the others.

You can only jump from specific platforms. You can dive head-first into the Grand Canyon, roll, and come out running if someone's put a platform on the edge.  But if there's no platform you can't jump down from a knee-high ledge. Or even step over a fallen branch. I got ambushed by some bandits on a knee-high patio and couldn't get away because the steps were on the other side of them. I was trapped and unable to drop from the dizzying height of 2 feet. Oh, if only someone had thought to put a platform there!

Side quests. Oh my god, there are side quests! Yo, dawg, I heard you like questing so I put a quest in your quest so you can quest while you quest! Kindoms of Amalur: The Side-Questening. Side quests are great, but this just seems to take them to ridiculous levels. They're like a hydra. You can't complete one side-quest without acquiring two more.

Factions. Join a faction, see the world. Or don't. Or join all the factions. Whatever. Apart from giving you more side quests, affiliation with a faction doesn't seem to have any effect on your standing with other factions or with NPCs.

NPCs tolerate straight-up murder. I was on a faction side quest where I was supposed to return a deserter to his barracks. I found him drinking in a tavern. I failed my persuasion check and he attacks. Murder-mage that I am I zap him and burn him and leave his charred, smoking corpse in the corner of the bar. No one else bats an eye at any of this. Another quest had me returning some items to the leader of a bandit gang. I acquire the items and head to his hideout. The gang members attack so I kill all of them. Get to the leader. "Thank you, adventurer! Good job! How about you come work for me?" Dude, I just murdered your ENTIRE GANG. "Welp, can't leave any witnesses, so if you won't join me, me and my gang will just kill you here."  Um, yeah, good luck with that.

It's not a *bad* game. It's a perfectly serviceable fantasy world full of perfectly serviceable fantasy tropes. But to compare it to movies, expect less [i]Lord of the Rings[/i] and more [i]Beastmaster[/i].

Coming back to this game for the first time in years, and only able to play because the FOV fix keeps me from rage-quitting from claustrophobia.

Steam says I have 49 of 61 achievements, but they are all dated 2012 or 2013, so I don't remember getting them.

Installed the game to find I had a 40 in Rathir, who hadn't started either DLC. I know I've completed that at least once, back in the day, so with the FOV fix maintaining my sanity I made it through getting the Manor built and trying to remember what the diplomacy quest is to get married (Did it at least once, back then)

Started a new character, and the DLC for "starter" gear for all three classes sure comes in handy as a source of cash for buying the first backpack. :)

Only thing having me curse and complain is the mob AI combined with the appearing-from-nowhere mobs. Sprites magically pop into an area. Spiders come up out of the ground, etc.

Having sped'd into Detect hidden, and seeing all normal enemies on the mini & full map, it is frustrating to be moving through an area that looks clear, and then a group of mobs jumps out - and I can only laugh imagining them shouting: "No One Expects the Spanish Inquisition"

Throw the mouse at the screen moments come from some of the boss fights, especially the Huntsman and the Widow - so far (I'm at L13). The Widow, in particular for throwing groups of 4 to 6 spiders at me every time I get to an open area in the tunnels & castle - and the way they rush to surround me - gets pretty frustrating. But having to try to guess the Widow's combat spells - while being surrounded by waves of spiders she keeps calling up - is just crap. 

Camera view doesn't help, either. Auto move to higher overview while I'm trying to spot the Huntsman and position myself is a pain.

As is movement caused by abilities, i.e. trying to get to a choke point so the spiders can't surround me, but Sceptre causes me to jump back, and chakram makes me step towards them.

I've got a melee character to L5, but trying to maneuver when mobbed is a pain for me, since I can't just run away and use ranged - I have to try and get the big swings off in the crowd.

66528688.review: One of my favorite RPG's. I think it was a Skyrim competitor but it doesn't really play like it. As a bonus when you run it from steam you get a cd key that you can put into Origin (the game launcher) and have it added to your account there. It's third person and the action and combat is more fluid and it's more of an action game than Skyrim, more action than exploration. I remember buying this used for Xbox 360 back in 2014 or so and it captivated me. I ran through it with that "just one more dungeon" feeling until I beat it. 66520381.review:
Absolutely fantastic fantasy RPG. Must-play for fantasy RPG fans!

The graphics are beautiful and very fitting. The resolution of the models feels quite high as well and the game is from 2012.

The controls are very intuitive after a little getting used to the combat system. And if you are not satisfied with them, you can adjust them in the seetings. The one thing that bugs me a little is that you can't jump, but this is by far not the only game that has this "issue". The combat system is simple, you have health and mana and can cast magic at the cost of mana. For those who are more the fighters, there are eight different types of weapons to choose from. Depending on your play-style, you can skill up differently, which allows you to only wear certain types of armor that fit your style.
To the story elements:
The main story line seems to have not too many quests, at least that's my feeling, but I started the game almost two years ago, so I might have forgotten how many main quest there were. However, while traveling the lands, you find an insane amount of side quests and objectives. These add so much lore into the game and apart from the quests, you have a hell lot of people to whom you can talk for even more addtional information. So great job with the quests and the lore of the game.

Apart from all the very good stuff, there is one issue, though: 
The studio that created the game doesn't exist anymore, so any bugs that are still in the game will most definitely never be fixed. The bugs are mostly cosmetic, but after a while one bug is very annoying: Items that were required for a quest that is now completed sometimes can't be removed from the inventory. So over time, you stack up items in your inventory that you can't sell. These items do NOT count towards your inventory item limit, so it basically doesn't affect the gameplay, it is just annoying. There is a way to get rid of these bugged quest items, though, that involves manually editing the save file.

So for everybody who enjoys fantasy RPGs and can ignore the few cosmetic bugs, this is definitely a brilliant game that takes up a lot of time to complete with 100%. 

Have fun ;)

66307559.review:
Not sure what it is that other people see in this game.

First off let me start by saying that my play time listed above is probably bloated as I tend to have the bad habit of leaving games open sometimes.

So, I had a few friends that, much like most of these comments; had only great things to say about this game. I think I bought this maybe a year or so ago, probably the winter sale of 2018. 

I was really eager to see what all the fuss was about. The most consistent thing I've heard about this game is that its a gem that's often overlooked or forgotten.

Well, I'm here to say that in my personal opinion, this game doesn't deserve anymore recognition than it already received.

Here's the gist of my points for the sake of brevity:

-This game is painstakingly easy. The "Learning Curve" is more like a straight line.
-Both the loot and the sidequests themselves are largely forgettable (Quantity over Quality). I found myself struggling at finding any interest in any of the main characters, the lore or the locales.
-While the freedom to shift around playstyles was a very nice idea, the lack of class balancing overall becomes very apparent the further in game you go. This is especially true if you end up Blacksmithing everything for yourself.
-The lack of variety in the brain dead AI (They almost never block)
-The art style in general is unimpressive. I know this game is dated to 2012, and had to compete within like a week or so of Skyrim, but this looks like a mashed mess of DA:O, Oblivion, and the cartoony style of WoW

I'm sure I could keep going, but I won't. Instead I'll end the review with what was, for me, the actual dealbreaker.

This game's leveling system is so pants on head stupid that it hurts. I may be forgetting a minor detail or two, but it basically functions like this:

Whenever you enter a new area for the VERY FIRST TIME the game will look at your level, then set every mob and quest to that level FOR THE REST OF THE GAME. The also extends to dungeons, but only when you go inside the actual dungeon and not the surrounding area it is part of. 

So what does that mean? Well for starters it means that enemies in the zone will eventually become gray (underleveled) even if you are not finished with the area. In turn this means that quest rewards and drops you find quickly become meaningless. It also means that you end up overpowering the last 1/2 or 1/3 of an area. It also means that area will be meaningless later in the game. So even if you wanted to come back later to finish the sidequests you skipped so you wouldnt over level, you can't.

It's so bad that there are actual guides to prevent over leveling (I kid you not, go google it)

In short, this is a very average game, and while some people may have nostalgic attachment to it, it's in my own personal opinion that it's by no means underrated, and in fact is overrated by some of the comments. 

If you wanna buy it, ONLY BUY ON SALE.
