Having tried to play through Amalur a few times now. I finally managed to play through the main story. Kingdoms of Amalur begins with a unqiue twist early at the start. However over time the main story following up to all the mystery begins to become a lot less interesting. 
  The main story itself may cast a small shadow over itself, however the lore/world side quests can sometime have a interesting enough story there. Which really helps make Amalur a more interesting world to explore. Time is another huge factor in this game.  you can easily spend over a hundred hours playing this and exploring this game if you so choose to. I personally decided a more direct route. focusing on mostly just the guild quests and the main story. That can be accomplished easily will little issues. 
  The difficulty and scaling doesn't really seem to be properly finished. When you enter a new region, the game will scale the enemies and loot mostly to your level. Even on hard difficulty the game just feels too easy. I'm no designer but i'm just guessing that the loot is a little OP. That doesn't detract all the fun however with the gameplay. The loot is always exciting to find and the movement and combos that you can dish out to enemies in the fighting sequences feels great. The loot looks fantastic!.
The Art in this game is amazing, the world looks fantastic. The music is really good and changes up nicely through most of the game. Leveling is another major piece to this game, if you've played some of the elder scroll games you will find some similarity from a much more simpler design here. it's really fun mixing around with plenty of options offered for you to explore and experiment.
In all I don't HIGHLY recommend Amalur but I do think if you got an open world fantasy itch Amalur can potentially be a good option for you to have a deep dive with.

66053772.review:
Right at 50 hours of playing the game, beating both the main story, the Legend of Dead Kel and Teeth of Naros DLC and obviously a decent amount of side quest, I can safely recommend this game to you. Is this game perfect? Absolutely not. But I would still say it is a must buy for any lover of anything RPG. Obviously everyone fawns over the combat in the game so I'll skip that.

The main story's premise is really cool, your character died (don't know how) has been brought back to life (also don't know how) And you've been resurrected with some new special powers that are fun to use in combat. But the real kicker is that because you've been brought back to life, you now no longer have a “fate” or “destiny.” Meaning you have achieved true “free will.” This is a super cool concept for a story especially since it means you can actually change the fate of others, since you have non of your own. Having said all that, I felt like the execution of this sweet idea was awful. I don't feel like we got to see this type of power play out to it's full extent. The whole point of being “fate-less” is that you are unpredictable. Buuuuut pretty much everything that happens turns out to be very predictable.

Main story I give a 6/10 I would have probably given it a 8 or even 9/10 but I mean no matter how unique and original your idea is, if you don't do anything with it, then it was meaningless.

The Legend of Dead Kel DLC is a solid expansion. I don't think they do anything crazy with the story, I was expecting some plot twist the way they were leading you, but nothing big is revealed. But the characters are fairly memorable for me, and the villain is “villainess” enough? It is pirate themed if that wasn't obvious, which I'm not a big fan of, but that's me. The castle you get in this expansion though was fantastic! I loved upgrading it and doing all of the small and big side quests and tasks associated with it. I wish more RPG's had upgradable homes, castle, keeps, forts etc. It was nailed in this DLC in my opinion.

Teeth of Naros DLC was BOMBASTIC! By far the better DLC between the two, and frankly I enjoyed it so much more than the main story too. You have a LOT of original ideas and cool plots and fascinating races, mainly the Kollossae. (pronounced Col-los-i) Tall, stone skinned, but flesh and blood inside, humanoids. They have a strong mix of Greek/Egyptian aesthetic to them, and I LOVE IT! There is a lot more I'm dying to say about this DLC but I'll just end with it's beautiful and you should definitely play this, even if you don't play the other DLC or can't finish the main story. At least play Teeth of Naros.

My overall score for the entire game would be a 7.5/10 with an award of “Must Buy”

65429773.review: This is a fantastic game. But after you have played it for several hours, totally smooth game play, it develops a bug where your player character begins to stutter...halt...move forward...stutter...then totally freeze until you release the movement key and hit the key again. And the process of stuttering and freezing continues though out from that point on. It's not a frame rate issue...everything around you is blowing in the wind and if you're frozen in the middle of combat your opponents continue to smoothly attack you...but you can't attack back...because your character is frozen. The game becomes unplayable. The research I did showed posts detailing this exact problem going back for 8 years...and neither Steam nor EA has taken steps to fix the bug. I have reported the issue again to EA. It is broken. But they have continued to sell it in this condition for 8 years after it having been reported. So you have paid for the game...but can't finish it.

65357540.review:
I can't believe I spent 90 hours in this game. And despite that I can only give it the most marginal of thumbs up. From a dollars per hour stand point this may be the value of the century and yet Amalur has a lot of issues that hold it back. 

Amalur is an over-the-shoulder action RPG in contrast to the isometric ones ie. Torchlight and Diablo. It focuses less on huge numbers of enemies like those games but you can still tackle many foes at once unlike most MMORPGs. It has very robust skill trees which fall into the classic 3 archetypes; Mage, Warrior, and Rogue. It rewards multiclassing by providing extra perks for having multiple point in different areas, and this makes any build viable.

And I mean that literally, anything will probably work in this game because it is quite easy. Even on Hard mode very little will challenge you save for 2-3 sections in the entire game. It may be the biggest fault of the game is you are going to get very used to using the same abilities for every combat. Enemies become a speed bump not a challenge as you navigate the absolutely massive world. I do mean massive, this game takes a long time to complete, even if you're just dogging it for the main quest line. But is it a game that's an inch deep and a mile wide like so many open world games? Not exactly. There are a ton of quests, and every word of dialogue is voice acted here. What a feat that must have been. Now this takes a page out of oblivion by having maybe 10 voice actors for the whole game, but at least it is quality voice acting, even if every second person sounds alike. And yet the quests do seem hollow. I eventually stopped reading the text and just started chasing pips on a minimap to get the quests done. 
The biggest tragedy in Amalur is what a near miss it is. Technically it runs well, the colors are vibrant, the monsters are well animated (but around a third of the way through you'll have seen every monster, they get palate swapped after that), but it it's borrowed so much from other RPGs it has nothing unique about it. 

But I still finished it, and as a relaxing RPG it fills that niche quite well. It's just not as satisfying as other RPGs that offer a greater challenge or unique features.

65030922.review:
Summary: Though this game does have a bit of heart via the massive amount of story and dialogue it contains, I can't even come close to recommending playing it for anyone looking for an RPG experience, an interesting Itemization experience, or a varied Action game experience. Honestly, you'd have a better experience than I did if you went and listen to the OST and downloaded some awesome HD wallpapers of the environments.


PROS
	* Environments (and the scope of them - the caves near the Codex of Destiny, jesus...) are absolutely mindblowing. Top 5 game environments
	* Top-tier fantasy music - very well themed and relaxing
	* Cinematic moments while exploring are really cool - monsters coming out of hiding spots and having them highlighted, or jumping from ledges changes up the flow of exploration nicely


MEH
	* Though the basic combat loop is pretty fun and moderately skill-based, the way that the talents work to bolster weapon strategies means that you're almost immediately forced into using one type of weapon in the first few levels, and then for the rest of the game
	* Experience gain seems to be really imbalanced due to the fact that 99% of your XP comes from combat, but it is a very story- and dialogue-heavy game
		* Ideally I'd smooth this out by adding more logic / puzzle based, or reading quests, similar to the quests inside the city where you have to talk to others to get info from them & make decisions based on that


CONS
	* The itemization complaint area
		* Item gain curve is ATROCIOUS. I'm not necessarily looking for Borderlands-style "new gear every encounter", but I had the same helm for my mage Selkie Veil for the first 17 hours of play because it was too good
		* Flat stat boosts are absurdly good for the first 40hrs of the game (until I quit), vs the % boosts that are often on items. I had 3 armor cloth gloves on for 15+ hours because it gave +20 Health and Mana, which was ~35+ of my base stats for that entire time
		* Items you gain are pretty much random item level, and 99.9% on the low side, so it's a vendor trash collect-a-thon. There are very few meaningful decisions when upgrading items
		* Unique items (Epics and Set Items) are completely random in drop rate. This may vary depending on certain key chests looted (e.g. the first mercenary stronghold leader's chest having the 6% exp ring), but out in the wild / dungeons / caves everything is random, as per a reloaded save has proved. The game design theory may be that a player would think "oh wow, I discovered a random Epic or Set Piece, super cool!", but since it is incredibly likely that the item is going to be hugely underleveled for your character, as well as not the right build (a might item for your finesse character, etc), that picking up a super rare item is just another uninteresting event.
		* Set item bonuses are nearly worthless, and doubly so when considering that the base items usually have next to no stats
		* Set items are vastly inferior to Epic items in terms of stats, which hurts Set items even more because you need 2 to 4 of them to enable the set bonus for them to be viable
		* Blacksmithing is WAY WAY too crucial. I was able to craft a pair of gloves with +65 Health & Mana on them (as well as shittons of other stats...) that couldn't be replaced for tens of hours. it also makes items that are vastly superior to any Epic or Set item.
		* Armor just doesn't look cool at all. Changing armor should at least give a visual changeup, but they all look almost exactly the same
			* Melee weapons are pretty cool, especially 2h swords and maces
	* Though Discover Hidden is pretty cool, having no mechanics or ingenuity used to discover these on your own without tons of points dumped into the DS skill isn't very fun
		* This leads to things like hidden doors or insanely hidden chests ending up as more frustrating Minimap-based discoveries at the end of the Discover Hidden skill tree rather than natural finds based on world design
	* Persuasion is almost worthless in a game functional sense, and truly worthless in an RPG sense. A couple of dialogue choices per hour, and even then it's just convincing the questgiver to let you keep the item they had you retrieve
	* "Shielding" in combat is pointless, and the shield item basically serves as a stat stick - the combat actions you perform that take the entire animation to resolve (spell casting in particular) can't be short-circuited by shielding, nor dodging, so dodging is by far the best solution to preventing negative combat outcomes in every situation
	* There are tons of books to read, but they only serve as character background or insights into world lore. They don't even grant new quests, open up new dialogue options, etc. Huge missed opportunity
	* Inventory management is constantly necessary and unrelenting. Throwing tons of loot at someone (most of which either has uses around selling or blacksmithing) and then punishing them for actually picking it up in a dungeon isn't fun at all
	* Lockpicking (a skill which is also worthless) is Elder Scrolls-esque, in that you have to position the lockpick in a range. Unforunately the range is smaller than any other game, so you start to understand the possible ranges an unlock segment can exist in, making every lock a trial and error issue that only takes one lockpick
		* Also lockpicks are unlimited, so there's no risk in failing
	* Spell damage does not scale with anything other than spell skill rank. This is great for power spikes while initially leveling the skill early and feeling like a hugely important decision, but as you progress through the game, monsters start to become massive damage sponges with no give & take, which makes it seem like your last N amount of hours was for absolutely nothing besides acquiring a new ability
	* Leveling slows down MASSIVELY ~20 hours in at approx level 20. Compounding this fact with the Spell Damage increase point above, this makes the game transition into a grind 1/3rd of the way through it's own story
	* Gold gaining methods become pointless ~15hrs into the game, and there are basically no 'gold dumps' of any meaningful significance, so it's just another pointless number going upwards

64880477.review:
This is not a perfect game, but I played it and it is fun, and much less annoying than others in the genre.  If you play it you probably want to do two things first:

1. Get Widescreen Fixer or something similar to adjust the camera location. The art is gorgeous and you won't see it on default settings. 

2. The inventory is bugged, so you'll end up with boatloads of stuff you can't get rid of. It's not a cheat, but a necessity to raise the max storage to 1,000 items or so. 

Lets get some of the basic cliches out of the way:

- Color coded loot
- Animals drop inappropriate items like pants and gold. 
- Incredibly easy to pull enemies from a group, an in fact it's so bugged it's a cheat. Very often after pulling a certain distance they'll ignore you completely, so just feel free to fire away. 

Of the genre, what this game does well is the close up combat and action sequences, but it's like college: You get what you put in.  I don't mean you can invest in armor and weapons, but that it's kind of hard to fail. If you want up close action death scenes you have to avoid pulling and bugging the NPCs to irrational behavior.  Jump in and slash or burn away. 

The crafting is easy and grind free. You get a skill point per level, and yo  may choose to allocate this to crafting. Before you infest a alot of time into black smithing you want to find a crafting guide, as the mechanics here are unique. You can re-craft components to build them up. For instance, you make a sword, with a gem, and then salvage it, over and over until you get the right rivets you want. That sort of thing requires patience to learn and do well. 

Of the crafting skills, I never found potion making important, you won't be able to get rid of them fast enough. Gem and black smithing is where you want to invest in. Not only will you be able to do more repairs with repair kits, but making your own armor and weapons (including sorcery gear) is actually as good or better than loot. 

The lore is also, well, tedious. It's all very wordy, and very elaborate, signifying nothing. At first you think the Fae are hot and you'd like to have a Fae harem, but soon you realize how much they talk. On and on and on. Lordy.

Old, but gold. While not perfect by any means and somewhat a game of the times it just functioned really well. It has most of the best RPG systems and every spec with a few variations is completely viable. Combat ranges from simple attack spam (if you want) to well timed ability setups. Also depends on your gear and level. Most enemies have different attack patterns and some are more difficult to dodge/block. Eventually you break through (and late game it's MUCH quicker) and the mob 'staggers' like all the other normal types.

I came back to this after an original playthrough at launch over on Origin. (Gro$$) The DLC wasn't out at the time, but here many years later I finished it in my massive backlog list on a whim. DLC was pretty good; I expected a really short experience on both but you'll get a solid 5-6 hours each and more if you are a packrat/OCD achievement-secret hunter.

Nets you a solid 30-50 hours with "some" wandering if you play most of the game. Easily can reach 90-120+ hours if you go for a completionist run. It's somewhat like a Solo MMO without all the daily/weekly treadmills and content updates. 

8/10, deserves a sequel one day..

Un clásico del género, muy entretenido, es como jugar cualquier MMO pero adaptado para un solo jugador, por si te da pereza tener que meterte en un MMO y derramar horas como un condenado.

PROS:
-Historia entretenida, no es la gran cosa, pero está bien.
-Jugabilidad bastante buena, no he tenido ningún problema en ningún momento.
-Gráficos digeribles y aceptables a día de hoy, que ya es decir para juegos de la época de este, aparte hay mods que mejoran un poco las texturas y los acabados, aconsejo echarles un vistazo.
-Un montonazo de misiones secundarias y secretos por descubrir, si lo que te gusta es completar todo lo posible, este juego te va a dar horas y horas, aunque si vas del tirón a por la historia, tiene una duración equilibrada para que no te parezca poco ni se te haga bola, así que tiene para todos los gustos.
-2 DLCs/expansiones (los cuales no he podido probar aún, pero me gustaría hacerlo) con muy buenas puntuaciones, lo que significa que si te ha gustado el juego base, vas a tener contenido extra, eso si, pasando por caja, pero si los pillas en oferta pueden salir bastante baratos.
-Personalización del personaje bastante decente incluso a día de hoy.

CONTRAS:
-Me he visto obligado a jugármelo en inglés, ya que en español carece de diálogos ni siquiera en inglés y se buguea de forma que no te deja continuar hasta que no lo cambias al inglés en algunos puntos (sin ir más lejos, la primera vez que me ocurrió fue saliendo del lugar de inicio, en un diálogo con un enano)*, en mi caso no he tenido problemas a la hora de jugármelo en inglés, así que para mí no ha resultado ser tan molesto, pero entiendo que para otros puede llegar a un punto clave.

*He de decir que esto ha sido en mi caso, puede que a otra gente no le haya pasado, tampoco es que me haya preocupado por investigar, pero por si acaso podéis hacerlo ustedes.

CONCLUSIÓN:
Recomiendo totalmente su compra si eres fan del género, tiene ya bastantes años, pero si no te importan los gráficos, vas a disfrutar de un gran juego, a ver si hay suerte y THQ Nordic nos trae una nueva entrega en el futuro, ya que compraron los derechos a 38 Studios allá por el 2018 si no recuerdo mal.

I bounced off this game hard. Which is sad, because it sounded like an amazing game from most of the reviews. I was excited to play it. This lasted...I don't know if it even lasted minutes. I think I knew from the opening cinematic? If you told me this game, as in the entire game - plot, characters, names, maps, enemies, skills, mechanics - was procedurally generated, I would believe you. This is paint by numbers game design. 64466178.review:
[Hour 50 Edit: I still love this game, but it is kind of a dumpster fire. Combat is just you getting juggled all the time, so figure out a way through that first, and if you already own this one don't buy the remake, its barely better and not enough to replay the whole game over just for better lighting. If you want to play this, then get the remake.]

[Hour 10]
Ellen was right.

I'll be damned. I'd been hearing about this game that I had no idea it existed back when it came out. I was up til 3am on my weekend for the first time in a hella fortnight because I'm enjoying this game /that/ much.

This is the fable game we should have had a long time ago. Combat and level up feels like the Fable games but evolved into something so much more thoughtful and fun to buy into while the rest of the game feels a bit like a bioware RPG. You don't get the full Mass Effect RP experience, but you get close. It feels more like KotOR than anything else. You don't need to ask every NPC their opinion on EVERYTHING, but sometimes you get fun little rewards.

The game shows its age sometimes. Big packs of enemies can dangerously juggle you a bit. The camera in dialogue sometimes pisses off somewhere else bot a line or two, nothing huge.

Fable had three experience paths, Amalur has three varied and adjustable skill trees. Mixing the trees earns you 'classes' that eventually alter your character. For example the finesse/sorcery hero can turn his or her dodge roll into a snazzy evasive Blink teleport. Much later levels add a poison effect.

Summary-
Looking for a western RPG singleplayer game? Come take a peek at KoA:R. Look past the 'not bad but not good' voice acting. Enjoy the colorful stylized environments, the original story, and the solo Build-a-Murder-Hobo style of gameplay. You don't get a billion  choices, but you do get a good handful to tinker with as you please. This game's only real crime is getting released right around the time Skyrim came out ensuring no one was playing it instead because we were all still eating butterfly wings and trying to find the dark brotherhood.

Thanks OX Team, for letting Ellen stand on that soapbox for so long about this game.

64211881.review:
So Kingdoms of Amalur : Reckoning. Where to start with this ?
In short : Single player MMO

In long:
GAMEPLAY
Standard RPG. Get quests,  do quests , progress in story till you kill the big baddy. 
Most of the time the quests are to kill enemies sometimes with a different objective like kill a boss, get a trinket or rescue an npc(they don't die thankfully)
The class system is nice. You can be a warrior, rogue or mage , mix two or all three. Doing so gets you bonuses. And from what i see each class has a way to deal with enemies.

GRAPHICS
Dated but decent. They do the job and are quite nice changing from area to area. The only problem is the camera which seems determined to give you a colonoscopy.

COMBAT
Combat is mediocre. Does the job but nothing special. Once you kill enough enemies you can go into reckoning mode which makes you superman for a bit. Enemies tend to come in groups and at times they can be frustrating when no matter how well you dodge or block an enemy stun locks you.
Friendly NPCs are useless in combat as they don't do more damage than a wet fart.
Also , enemies are fairly repetitive. They are all unique but it won't be long till you've seen all. DLC adds a few but they are not that interesting and some feel like reskins.

STORY
Interesting fantasy world with some lore and thought behind it. Some factions (house of Sorrows) have decent stories. Only a few of the characters stand out though the rest seem rather generic. With other RPGs i played , the NPCs tended to be more memorable and have a bit more personality.

Final thoughts
A bit grindy but a big world to run around and have fun in. OK-ish story to keep you engaged and some stuff to do on the sides (crafting , alchemy , stealing etc). Overall I had fun with it. 
It is a fairly consistent game - as in it is predictable. No matter the area i was in I expected to get a quest , kill some mobs, get a reward. A good and bad thing. Bad because nothing jumps out. Good because you know what to expect.
Final boss was a bit underwhelming - the DLC boss from Teeth of Naros was much better.
Given the age of this game I recommend getting it on sale if you don't mind games with some repetitive gameplay but a big sandbox to play in.

64180484.review:
A fantastic RPG with stellar combat that goes above its contemporaries. Combat isn't quite as deep as games like Devil May Cry or Bayonetta, but it still manages to have surprising depth, entertaining combos, and a quality mix of abilities that add just the right amount of spice. The story is neat, but the game is very much more about the world and your character's place in it rather than having a phenomenal central narrative. 

The game can be quite easy though, with side quests regularly overleveling the player, money being unnecessarily easy, and skills allowing you to get quality gear the moment you acquire a single piece of the newer tier of equipment. I highly recommend installing and configuring the
[url=https://www.pcgamingwiki.com/wiki/Kingdoms_of_Amalur:_Reckoning#YSA_Heartcore_Mod] YSA Heartcore mod [/url], which reduces exp gain, player damage output, money gain, etc. whilst raising enemy damage output and generally balancing the game to be a fair bit more challenging. If you are at all familiar with combat systems like Dark Souls, God of War, DMC, Bayonetta, or even Kingdom Hearts 2, I cannot understate how much I'd recommend installing this. If you're familiar with the Fallout/Elder Scrolls series and their economies, regularly breaking them and acquiring mass quantities of cash, then definitely install it at least for the gold rebalance.

At the end of the day, this game is absolutely worth a playthrough or two, but maybe not for full price at the moment. The DLCs greatly add to the experience, giving new areas, NPC races to interact with, stories to enjoy, etc. and they recently raised the price of the whole game package (from around $35 to $53), which is a bit shit, but oh well. Wait for a sale and get it cheap, it usually hits around $10 for the full thing.

64128415.review:
My balance of the game is positive. Is not a master piece, but is a good game, maybe even great game, that is worth playing at least once IMO.

The strong points of this game are, 
1. replayability (several weapons to use and many things to try, many "builds" options), 
2. Environments, they are beautiful. And the world is huge.
3. World building and setting. in the sense of the lore and background,  
4. Game mechanics and combat. Combat is fun and enjoyable (but see below in the "weakness" part for a caveat.) 
5. (See below, point 1) Some of the few characters that have "characterization" are great. The sad part is that they can probably be counted with one hand only.

The weak parts are, IMO
1. Characters in general: there are not many characters that stand out (but those that do, are good IMO.) In general, there are just too little of character development and there's just a few instances of characters that are well developed enough that you will grow attached to them, like other games have.
2. Combat is a bit too repetitive. It never bothered me too much the first times I played through it, but this last time since I made a complete playthrough in Hard for the achievements, I had to overcome the tediousness of fighting some enemies (there are many "statbags" with oodles of HP) and the limited selection of enemy move sets... combat gauntlets are normally repeated setups of the same enemy types over and over. Also, there are some enemies that are totally obnoxious to fight and you often have to fight them in hordes.
3. Main quest is good, and many of the side quests are good but not all of them, and the bulk of them are completely forgettable IMO. This is part of the "character" problem I mentioned above, and the fact that most side-quests are just fedex type of exchanges and there aren't many options or conversations to engage, either with the quest givers or other characters that you have to interact with for completing them.
4. There aren't enough options/choices that matter, and in fact, I'd say that AFAICR there are none.

Also, in a separate topic from the pro/con section, I'd say that most people would say this game is too easy, and that would be a con for them... I kinda don't consider that a con myself, as someone that often wants to just turn the brain off and enjoy some gameplay with not much hassle... but yeah, it is a bit too easy, even in Hard. Thing is, the game becomes tedious in Hard, not "Hard". Still, there are other games for scratching the "hard" itch for me, and this one is one of those you want for scratching the "want to play a badass character in a cool fantasy world and forget about our crappy real world" itch, and it manages it quite well :)

During this last playthrough on Hard there were some things I disliked combat-wise about the game, that I only realized now... but I'm still not sure they are important enough to mention here... it certainly has its flaws and quirks, but I don't think they can take you out of the game, so to speak.

Overall, IMO it's a 7.5 game, maybe even an 8 one, depending on taste and other subjective measures.

Older game, but good Skyrim type of knockoff. The good first: expansive world, freedom to choose various skills and make your character as you want, tons to do, not really any farming to do which I like, lots of factions, pretty fun combat, great dialogue and it's pretty engaging. I lost track of time playing this. 

Now the bad: way too much running around, backtracking through dungeons is very tedious after you've cleared  them. There's no mark/recall like in TES games, and not all the dungeons are designed with a quick exit afterwards. I found the constant running around to the same place multiple times kind of annoying, especailly after having just done a quest there, or missing something. The side-quests are severe overkill, there's hundreds and each is like "hey help me do xyz" and it gets very redundant, to the point I just skip all the dialogue to hurry it up,  There are also some MAJOR bugs, not the least was I had the best set item in the game for a mage and a bugged quest literally made it disappear from inventory to get replaced with the quest helm, I no way to recover it. By the time I noticed it was gone my option was either reload a game from hours back or just say F it and keep going.   Another bugged quest forced me to reload too which cost me 40 minutes of redoing things. So... save often don't just rely on auto save.

I give this game a 65% positive rating because of all that. If you enjoy good RPGS or elder scrolls, definitely get this one though. It is worth a playthrough.

63988973.review:
I have a love-hate relationship with this game. Fortunately, the pros outweighed the cons so I couldn't let myself give a bad review. In general, KOA is an 'okay' action RPG that failed to live up to its potentials.
The pros: 
+ Fantastic combat and perks system. The ability and moves are very unique and diverse. Players are urged to utilize all kinds of powers and character builds/fates, from sorcerer, warrior to assassin build. Chain attacks/combos and magic are super cool, fun and easy to learn. In comparison to Witcher or TES, KOA is on another level with regard to varieties of magical spells. 
+ QTEs (in fate mode) are exceptionally well-done compared to other games. Implementing QTEs as finishing moves is not a new thing in video game, but the way KOA executed the mechanics is effective and satisfying.
+ Incredibly well-written and original lore.
+ There are diversity and indescribably beauty in the world of KOA. Despite its outdated visuals, the game still looks fantastic at times due to the uniqueness of its world design.
+ The map is vast, packed with contents. To specific, I have completed around 110 quests, from primary, secondary, miscellaneous to guild quests - I haven't yet uncover half the map and I still discover more quests from NPCs. It's a good thing if you're looking for a huge sandbox experience to invest your time in. On the other hand, there is a big downside to this  which I'll get to in a moment.
+ Gears and equipment, such as armors and weapons are cool-looking and super badass. You can equip full gears to get extra stats or mix and match to fit your play styles.

Now, about the cons:
+ Quest design is terrible. This game is more about quantity instead of quality. The main story is shallow and generic (you will find yourself difficult to care at all), side quests are basically story-less chores and fetch tasks, and guild quests are poorly written and confusing.
+ Despite being an open world game, there are lots of invisible walls so you'll end up using long way to move around. And worst of all, you cannot jump.
+ Graphics are outdated. The camera angle is terrible. Bugs occasionally appear and sometimes game-breaking. Despite being released in 2012, It feels and plays like a 2007 game.
+ The voice-acting is mediocre and robotic. Although the lore are interesting and unique, the voice-acting (with the combination of poor facial animations)  is not captivating enough for players to actually follow or invest their emotions in.

Overall rate: 6/10 - this could have been greater and big enough to get a sequel. Unfortunately, due to its mediocre writing, visuals and quest design, KOA ended up being overshadowed by bigger fantasy RPG franchises such as Witcher and TES.

En YouTube busqué juegos similares a Dark Souls, Dragon's Dogma, Witcher, Oblivion, etc, que son de mis favoritos, y apareció el Kingdoms of Amalur, debido a que mi equipo no alcanza los requisitos para el Skyrim y en la rebaja del Black Friday de 2019 el KoA tenía un excelente precio, decidí apostar por él.

El juego tiene gráficos muy bonitos, un mapa de exploración enorme, muchas misiones secundarias y muy variadas, buena jugabilidad, un buen desarrollo del personaje, buena historia principal, varias habilidades progresivas para los combates, gran variedad de armas, la oportunidad de crear tus propias piedras de mejora, pociones, cambios después de lograr alguna misión, etc.
Lo recomiendo para pasar un rato bastante entretenido, lo califico con un 7/10, por el problema de idioma y algunos bugs de inventario que pueden ser molestos. Aún así en cuanto pueda voy a adquirir los DLC

63022509.review:
In my ongoing and likely futile effort to write a Steam review for every game in my library (#118 out of 555)... it's time for Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning.

I've spent a lot of time with this game, but honestly most of that time feels wasted. Kingdoms of Amalur has certain... pretensions. It thinks its combat is far more engaging than it is, so it gives you far too many enemies to fight; it thinks its writing is much more compelling than it is, so it inundates you with dialog. None of that is really a deal-breaker: these are common problems with open-world RPGs, as much as we might wish otherwise. What is the dealbreaker? The quest design is excruciatingly dull. In almost every case, you talk to an NPC and recieve an exposition dump, run a simple errand, and return for a reward of... more exposition. And nothing interesting or unusual or unexpected ever happens: they're just low-effort fetch quests gussied up with way, way too much text.

Ultimately the most interesting part of Kingdoms of Amalur is its real-world context. Read up on the development history sometime: it's hilarious.

62110479.review:
[h1]Mediocre[/h1]
The combat style and class system are the only good things this game has to offer. And even so, they get stale from the midgame onwards. The combat consists of combos with various weapons, giving you control over how to approach groups of enemies, while the class system allows mixing three skill-trees: Might (melee warrior with heavy armor), Finesse (archer/thief with light armor) and Sorcery (mage, with access to staves, sceptres and chakrams). When mixing them, you build your own playstyle and get rewarded with bonus stats and abilities (e.g. a Might/Sorcery build can replace dodge with a teleport function, improving mobility). 

Now for my major complaints:

[b]Terrible map design[/b]. Every open area and dungeon is composed of extensive winding corridors. That wouldn't have been so bad if they were shorter or if we could traverse them using any type of mounting. As it is, you'll spend half the game running around, you might even have to replace your Shift and W keys after a playthrough.

[b]Over-leveling[/b]. Too many quests, too much EXP. Regions are level-locked, so it's easy to level up above the region level and make the rest of the game boring. Worse even, there's a time in the main story where you have to choose which main quest to pursue, separated into two different regions. If you follow one and do some sidequests, you can become too OP to enjoy the other region when you're forced to go there. Basically, 1/5 of the game is made obsolete in any given playthrough because of that quest design.

Every other aspect of the game is just average. So this is a negative review since, despite enjoying the first 20 or 30 hours, it drags on for too long.

62003591.review:
After completing this game around 51 hours and with still plenty more to do, I can safely recommend this game. The combat, visuals which is like a cross between World of Warcraft and Fable and still looks pretty good or at least easy on the eyes, and class system are by far its strongest points. The combat plays like a hack n slash game, with a variety of weapons and abilities to use on your enemies. KOA introduces a fateshift mode which allows you to slow down time a kill enemies in a pretty bloody if cartoony way, and gives you bonus XP. Varying up your attacks and abilities will fill up the meter faster. When you Level up you can put your skill points into three different trees might,finesse,and magic or warrior, rogue,and mage. What makes this unique is the fact you are not suck with one class and can be a hybrid is you want, you can be a pure mage or mage/rogue or warrior/rogue or whatever. 

However while the game can be fun it has flaws, for one the story while it starts off interesting it doesn't payoff with its weak ending, the quest are plentiful but often play out in three ways, fetch quest, go over here and talk to this guy then talk to this other guy, then talk to the  guy you just talked too, or go into this samey looking dungeon and kill this one guy or monster. the characters while well voice acted are mostly forgettable other than your shadowy female dark elf friend who leaves very little to the imagination and the boat captain who takes you to Dead Kel's island in the DLC. 

Overall i would give this a 7.5 out of 10 it is fun, yet simple RPG that I would recommend you get at its $20 price point or wait for the game to go on sale for 5 bucks or 10 bucks for the complete edition

Note: I am not basing any of my recommendations on the graphical fidelity of the game, I am running it on a below-average laptop at the lowest graphical settings. At the very least, I can say that it runs well on my system. That's a plus.
While the combat begins by being very basic/lacking complexity or depth (which gets better as you level up, in my opinion) I believe the world building and environmental design more than make up for it. If you stop to appreciate the details, it really does feel as if the whole word is alive and interconnected. From the stories told by NPCs, to the books you can read, to the way the dungeons and world is laid out. It feels as if more thought has been put into this than most western RPGs.
I would also like to praise the skills system. In many RPGs, it feels as if there are some mandatory skills you must take, and some that are more for window dressing. In this game, it feels as if all the skills actually provide tangible uses and bonuses, and that you need to put points into all the skills.

61730608.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a fairly standard fantasy RPG with some things I liked and some that I disliked. Story wasn't really a strong point here and the questing reflects it. You'll encounter generic fantasy hero fluff with mostly interesting main quests and a few decently interesting faction quests. Side questing can best be described as mindless filler and I skipped the majority of it. 

It features an awesome combat system with some real weight to it though. You can expect each weapon to offer a unique combat style and it comes fully equipped with elemental affinities and status effects to boot. Classes can be tailored to specification so it's possible to swing a big sword and cast lightning to your hearts content. Big plus in my book.

I really enjoyed the environments as well. I found the various zones visually appealing and very vibrant with decent texturing given its age. I was rarely left bored while exploring as each new area felt refreshing to traverse. There was plenty of loot to be found around the world too. I should mention that crafting felt a bit hit and miss to me personally with bloated inventory as a result of components and no decent sorting method to filter with. 

To wrap things up, KOA has both strong and weak points that are balanced fairly well as a whole. Overall, I do feel that I can fully recommend this title purely based on the fact it was a fun, enjoyable experience for the most part. I grabbed this on a sale but I do think it's worth full price based on the content offered.

61430029.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a product of it's time. When it came out, it was by no means a bad game. In fact, it was innovative in a few ways, with Destiny being the main thing. You are not 'forced' into playing any one particular way, and the closest thing to a class system ensures there is an option for everything under the sun.

That being said, just because you CAN do everything doesn't mean you SHOULD. For one, equipment is not optimized to support the Destiny System. There are no True Hybrid armors, something is Might (Your typical strength/warrior build) Finesse (typical agility/rogue) or Sorcery (intelligence/wizard build) You CAN mix and match but you have very little incentive to do so (aside from certain catch-all skills like Hardy Constitution, Conservative Casting and Inoculation, however rare Poison is) Mixed Destinies are far worse than focusing except in niche cases (Basically any Might Destiny is good, but why play Might when Sage can just obliterate 1/2 of it's enemies with a Tempest and Meteor?) Combat is clunky at times (a tree roots itself in the ground and suddenly a METEOR is doing about as much damage as a Longsword swing by the world's smallest man, meanwhile the Fateless One will get interrupted by the slightest breeze which gets irritating after three enemies)

There are very few glitches, but when they happen, you will most certainly feel it. I am unable to complete the Traveler quest line due to being unable to talk to an important NPC who is unreachable. Killing him, leaving the area, exiting and re-entering the area, nothing works, so I'm just stuck in this part. You cannot play anything higher than 1980/1080 or else the menus will break (specifically, Quests won't show properly, and Destinies don't show up) and there are a considerable amount of Quest Items I am unable to remove from my inventory (at least 30 slots are just permanently unavailable due to poor flagging of quest completion) and there will never be a future patch as 38 Studios filed for bankruptcy long ago.

If you're here, you either have it and are debating the Remaster (It's not worth [i]another[/i] 40$) or are here when you should be on the Re-reckoning Page (Seriously, go buy the Remaster if you are thinking about it, this version of the game is [b]dead.[/b])

61229918.review:
My Background: 
I have played Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning on the Xbox 360 when it first came out and I loved the vibrant colours and mystical world setting. I saw it discounted on Steam and thought I would replay on here. This is the second game I own on Steam (the first being The Forest) so I am not used to the controls compared to Xbox but I found you quickly get used to all the buttons and can look rather professional when killing enemies.

The Game now... 

The World: 
This game is beautiful. It has vibrant colours and a great style. It is very open and you can go off and wander rather than following a quest line if you wish. This game is individual in itself but gathers great elements of open world action adventure games.

Character options: 
You can play as one of four races and have some control over appearance; not as much as 'The Elder Scrolls Skyrim' but still enough you feel the character is yours. There are various presets you can choose and then you may change hair colour styles and tattoos. 

You can choose to be 'good' or ''bad'. You can join thieves or go around stealing from houses/pickpocketing. You can join a proud group of warriors for hire and choose communication options that follow different results. 

Factions:
As mentioned above you can join factions, for example, Travelers or Warsworn.

Resolution Glitch: When playing on a high resolution I found that the games 'Quests' section did not show any writing but this was rectified by dropping the resolution which meant I lost about an inch on each side of the vertical screen and was not detrimental to game play experience. I googled this glitch and found the way to solve it online and was reassured that I was not the only one it happened to. 

Plot: 
The main missions are very interesting and send you on a mysterious adventure. I have not completed the game even on the XBox because it is so big and I am currently at 29 hours of gameplay on Steam and still have much to do.

The side missions are many and can immerse you in hours of gameplay. There are various different biome styles to explore in the Kingdoms of Amalur from the spider infested Webwood, trolls of Haxhi, the beautiful Cradle of Summer or desert areas.

The NPCs offer alot of information so if you are not a fan of this it can be avoided or skipped (it depends how much of the lore you want to learn). As you explore the world you discover lorestones that help with the history of the world with some amusing records.

Weapons and Armour:
The game offers a wide variety of weapons and armour which are colour coded so you know if you have a rare item that you might want to stash. Purple is unique, blue is rare and green/white are more common (green less so that white). You can easily see how strong a weapon is and whether it gives specific attack damage. 

Some of the DLC offers a cross over armour from Mass Effect which looks good.

There are some great weapon attacks and I specifically like using chakrams, staffs and magic but you can choose to use daggers, swords or hammers too.

Possible spoilers in the next bit - Games it is similar to:
When you meet a mysterious female character that you don't remember, it reminds me of 'Dungeon Siege III' briefly, while some of the sword action reminds you of 'Devil May Cry' or 'Bayonetta' with spam clicking a button for entering the special finish moves. Its animation reminds me of 'Fable II' and 'Fable III' in some places and possibly 'Darksiders' but has the vibrant colours of 'Ori' and 'Fable: The Journey' or maybe even 'Hungry Shark'. On the XBox it was a good looking game but on Steam, with the added resolution options you get from computer games, it really is even more beautiful. It sometimes reminds me of 'Zelda: Ocarina of Time' because of the various areas of the world going from Forest to Desert etc. You can blacksmith, make potions and join factions like in 'Skyrim'. It basically has some of my favourite things brought together from other similar games to make a new unique and beautiful game. If you like this style of animation and enjoy RPG, open world action adventures then this game is great.

Some Controls:
Mouse to position sight and direction of facing 
WASD as usual
Shift for Block
Ctrl for run
F for interacting
Block and Attack with a Staff at the same time releases a cool move to keep enemies together and deal damage.

61185182.review:
I only recently found out that this game existed, which is strange considering the fact that I love these kinds of games. It must be due to skyrim releasing in close proximity to it.

If I had to describe it, I'd call it generic fantasy, but in a good way that's oddly comforting. The gameplay feels like if you took the tight combat of fable and made a full on RPG of it.

A neat feature in this game is how the class/ability system is handled, allowing you to mix and match classes as you see fit. Want to blast lightening at your enemies while wielding a massive greatsword? Go ahead. Sneaky spellblade assassin? Knock yourself out. However, I'd suggest just sticking with the classic mage, warrior or rouge initially, and then respeccing once you have a decently large pool of skill points, lest your spread yourself too thin.

The selection of playable races is sadly disappointing, just two human races and two elf races, none of which are particularly interesting or unique from eachother. Similarly, character creation, while servicable, is also lacking in any form of fine tuning, and only allows you to pick a preset face and change a few other things.

Overall, the gameplay is pretty decent and allows a good amount of customisation when it comes to combat, and the world is chock full of content. If you've been pining for the xbox 360 era of fantasy RPGs, then this is the game for you.

61180557.review: I have long been a fan of this game since it initially came out. The takeaway of R.A. Salvatore doing the writing in this was the clincher. The protagonists journey is excellently played and it certainly has some twists and turns. While I didn't play much of the DLC, I think this game is still a valid and good addition to any fan of role playing games and I definitely recommend it. Finally, in terms of the visuals it has a unique style and it has aged quite well in the 7 years it has been out which is a testament to its quality.

60801728.review:
For the record, I also own Kingdoms of Amalur for the Xbox 360 and PS3 and have beat it five times. I have played as every class (warrior, mage, archer/stealth) and mixtures of the three. Although I was excited for this game before its release, Kingdoms of Amalur released in February 2012, mere months after Skyrim. I'd spent hundreds of hours in Skyrim by that point and loved it to pieces. I figured Kingdoms of Amalur would be a disappointment in comparison.

Other than being action RPGs, the two games aren't really comparable. I love Kingdoms of Amalur, but its issues are deep and teeter on the edge of game-breaking sometimes. This is the only game 38 Studios published before their bankruptcy kerfuffle. As a debut game, Kingdoms is fantastic, yet it also bears a lot of flaws that seasoned development teams often conquer in subsequent games.

In Kingdoms, you play as a character who died and is brought back to life. The story branches out from there, touching upon themes having to do heavily with fate, unraveling it, destinies, and so forth. To be honest, even though I've beaten the game multiple times, I have little memory of the story. It is forgettable, and as a person who doesn't believe in fate/destiny, it's simply uninteresting. Kingdoms has a problem with forgettable stories, lore, and characters. I saw another review comparing it to an MMO, and the comparison is fair. I'm someone who goes into an RPG hoping to get obsessed with lore; in Skyrim, for example, I keep libraries of in-game texts and I actually read them. Here? I tried, and I just can't get into it. Historical events, people, and wars are vaguely explained and low on detail, forcing you to only stick to the present. Nearly all NPCs in the game are lackluster. When I come across an NPC who manages to spark my interest, it surprises me.

So why in the world do I like this game enough to keep coming back? The gorgeous, unique fantasy world and ridiculously fun combat. Kingdoms of Amalur isn't the best-looking graphically; the character designs are often hideous (clunky animations in facial expressions often lead to unintentionally hilarious or creepy conversations), and if you walk closely to anything you might start to see its flaws. But on the whole, they did a fabulous job of creating a world that feels enormous despite its straightforward map-to-map pathways, and the locations are gorgeous. From gigantic forests where the trees assault the skies to rolling plains to the canyons of a desert, this game is a feast for the eyes and the world is simply fun to explore. Never before have I experienced a fantasy game like this that feels whimsical without being innocent (the enemy designs can sometimes be eerie, and blood spills frequently in combat). Amalur feels unique in this aspect; the world is so gorgeous and colorful that a lot of times I'll feel like playing just to look at it.

As for the combat, it's ridiculously easy. But you will look and feel like a badass no matter how you play. My least favorite play style was as a two-handed weapon warrior, because combat is slow and leaves you vulnerable to the ramming attacks of low-level enemies like wolves, brownies, etc. Still, the combat was fluid and beautiful. My favorite way to play is with faeblades and chakrams; seriously, at least try using chakrams once. These weapons are gorgeous, elementally-imbued, and sweep through enemies and the environment alike to where nothing can touch you. Even on hard difficulty, this game is a cakewalk. But at least it's a ton of fun as you play.

A few other tidbits: the quests and enemies are unfortunately low on variety. Even when you join the Travelers (a thieves' guild, essentially), you'll find yourself completing clear-out-a-dungeon-and-kill-a-boss type quests rather than stealing more often than not. It seems like the developers tried to emulate other games with factions (like Elder Scrolls) but just did it poorly; Amalur has varied factions, of which you can join them all, but their questlines are lackluster and all start to mimic one another. Enemy designs are pathetically few and far between; you might make it to a new area and think, "Oh! I'll start facing new enemies now!" Ehh, unlikely. Going from the forests to the deserts only netted me a few new elven enemy types; all the creature enemies stayed the same. And if you're heading toward a climax battle and think you'll get a unique enemy type, I have bad news for you: 9 times out of 10, it'll just be a human/elf who calls themselves a special name, and they won't be harder to beat than anyone else.

Kingdoms of Amalur also suffers from weird glitches and game-breaking bugs, one of which happened to me while playing the Dead Kel quests from the DLC on Steam. There's a mission where you have to run out of a collapsing cavern. I did so just to find my companion was stuck behind the rubble. There was no fast travel or way off the beach, so I reloaded just to come across the same thing. Lo and behold, the only way to fix the glitch was to restart the quest. The only other save I had was an autosave, so I lost 40 hours of gameplay progress. Basically, always keep at least two saves: one where you're in a safe place, and another for more recent gameplay. Amalur's glitches are rarely foreseeable, so you'll need a save when you least expect it.

All in all, I really like this game, but I want to love it. I wish 38 Studios had survived past Amalur and went on to grow from this experience, because underneath all the grime of rookie mistakes and uninteresting lore, there's a great game here. For a debut game, Amalur is an amazing effort. Had 38 Studios learned from its flaws and went on to create a sequel, I honestly could see their games going head-to-head with the Elder Scrolls installments and other mainstay RPGs. Unfortunately, their bankruptcy lost them this perfect opportunity, but we will always have Amalur. It's unique, it's troubled, it's sometimes frustrating, yet always beautiful. I'd give Kingdoms of Amalur a 6.5/10. At its best, it's higher; at its worst, it would be lower. Either way, it shouldn't be missed.

I love this game! Got it to scratch the World of Warcraft itch and it works for me. I highly recommend grabbing the game bundled with the DLC on sale. Plus, selling any weapons and armor you won't use from the DLC pack in a play through is a good way to make a lot of money quickly. (Yes, you get them again on a new play through.)

(Rast Brattigan from that DLC has some of the best lines in the game.) If you're willing to do the quests, then you're rewarded with a pretty awesome base of operations on that island. 

I'm very casual and have what's been called a "slow twitch reflex." So I don't think I can give a good assessment of controls or mechanics. The controls are highly customizable (I use a mouse and keyboard). 

You also get a lot of freedom as far as character builds go. Once you have enough in-game money you can refund your points and rebuild your character as many times as you can afford. 

The only negative for me is that you have to be online to play the game. But that's games nowadays. You'll need to make an account with EA. So I'm paranoid about them deciding to shut down the game's servers someday. Also, probably never getting a sequel. So I'm squeezing as much fun out of this game as I can.

60022816.review:
A very classic, old-school RPG which is exactly what I need. 

Graphics wise, this game looks beautiful for its time and it still looks quite nice now. They used the bloom and lightning very well. Some dungeons are very beautiful. Texture is ok until everything zoom in (dialog for example). This is a 2012 game so I'm ok for what it is. Would be perfect if this game has some kind of DOF.

Story wise, eh it is just a classic random dude are destinied to become the hero, defeat the dark lord and save the world. I haven't finished the main story yet but for now it is good enough to keep me playing.

Gameplay. Oh boi here we go. The combat is quite fun actually. There are many type of weapons and they have different moves as well. You will unlock more moves as you leveling up in each class (Might-Warrior/Finesse-Rogue/Sorcery-Mage). At first, I intented to play rough style but later on I got to the hybrid rough mage style and mostly mage. Why? Let me explain.
The combat is literally stun lock hell. A single hit from smallest trash mobs will stun you and interrupt your current action. Enemies mostly come with a group and they tend to swarm you. Your attack animation are slow, clunky, and guess what, once you press a button to do any action, you are locked and you can't dodge. This become very annoying when you are attacking one enemy, some other dudes attack you from other direction and you can't dodge because the your animations lock you from dodging. Same thing when you are trying to do a charge attack. This is why I lean toward the Mage style. 2 reasons, spell and chakram. Mage's spells are very powerful. They can deal with multiple enemies and they deal shit tons of damage. You can just keep a distance and cast spells, easy game. About chakram, they are one of mage weapons. You throw them at enemies and they can hit multiple enemies as well. The best part about this weapons is your attack animations is fast, fast enough so you can hit your enemies before they hit them. Once used chakrams it is hard to go back to any other weapons (except bows).
To "balance" the stun lock hell system, normal mobs don't hit very hard and using any potion are instant so you can instantly heal and keep fighting no problem. Things only get more interesting when you fight big enemies like golems or giants.
There is a special meter called "Fate". Killing enemies will refill this meter. You can active this Fate ability to slow time and deal much, much more damage. During Fate, you can beat enemies to near death, pick one near death enemies. A prompt will show up and you can quickly tap space to gain more exp from this enemy. Other nearby near death enemies will die after this. Note that Fate will end right after you kill one enemy so try to bring as much enemies to near death as possible. 
Inventory spacing is very frustrating as you have a very limited space and you won't get a stash early game. This will interrupt game flow because more often then not you will just finish one or two quest and then fast travel back to shop to sell/dismantle your loot. Speaking of quests, there are shit tons of quests for you to do and I really mean it. 

Yea, overall I think this is a good game and I'm having a good time. Definitely recommended.

Haven't encountered any bugs/glitches/crash yet.

59810590.review:
Lots of fun to be had in a large world with tons of options. While there isn't anything wildly unique or groundbreaking about Kingdoms of Amalur, it's the execution of some simple game design choice that make this game worth at least a try.

Amalur would draw natural comparisons to western RPGs that came out around the same time, most notably Skyrim. But the things that appeal to me about a game like Skyrim are very different from what is appealing about Amalur. Skyrim's largest appeal is the world itself, the sense of immersive adventure, of discovery. That the combat, quests, and plot are merely o.k. is covered over by the fact that the world is so compelling to be in. If you didn't buy into Skyrim's world as immersive, you probably wouldn't really enjoy the game as a whole.

I would contend that the world in Amalur is far less immersive, but that isn't the game's selling point. There are some impressive visuals: wide-ranging vistas abound and there are lush colors everywhere. But while there is a lot to see in the landscape, there isn't a lot to do, per se. The game won't let you fall off a cliff, but it also won't let you climb one either. There is no exploring to find another route around; no, what the map says are the outlines are what they are, and I spend as much time just looking at my map than I do the world itself. And while the world has the obligatory biomes (forest, desert, grasslands, swamp, etc), they don't bleed into one another at all in continuous gameplay. You'll be in the dense forest, walk up to a break in the hills, watch a loading screen, and poof, you're in the arid desert. In a game like Skyrim I would rarely use fast-travel because the world itself was just compelling to explore between objectives. In Amalur, I use fast-travel constantly because there's just not much to explore.

So I wouldn't recommend Amalur to someone looking for a compelling world to explore. But it's the combat and character building that make this game a blast. I've played the game mostly as a mage, so I couldn't comment on all the combat mechanics, but suffice to say that the combat is what sets this game apart. Played entirely from a third person perspective, combat is all about different moves and combos that your character will learn and develop. The animations are all quite flashy, and the more complex/powerful your moves get, the more over-the-top, almost comic-book style the animations get. Which is pretty cool if you're into that sort of thing. And that is where the appeal of the character building comes in. Most RPG have become more and more action-genre oriented, so you're character grows mainly by what sort of equipment or weapons they can use. In Amalur, the main joy in leveling up is not just seeing your stats get bigger but in increasing the variety and effectiveness of combat moves you can perform. In other words, increasing what you can actually witness your character DO. (Although skills like sneaking, persuasion, alchemy, etc are all present in the game, and do play a role depending on your character, I would argue that Amalur doesn't implement these skills any better than many other games. Although there's nothing wrong with that, I'm guessing that if someone didn't find Amalur's combat enjoyable, they're not going to enjoy the game terribly much as a whole.)

And I'll admit, the combat mechanics are not always perfect. In certain situations when you have enemies on every side, the camera will pan back to view the whole area. But then it becomes confusing to aim your attacks, as you can't seem to tell which way you're turned. (So I'd have enemies swarming in from three sides and for some reason I keep throwing lighting blasts off into nowhere.) But this was a rare occurrence, especially after just a little bit of practice.

The story in Amalur is alright; I never felt like I'm part of some epic tale, but I never thought it was corny either. There are a few, mildly interesting twists on some of the standard fantasy-genre tropes, but nothing to write home about, or that change the gameplay any. Although the further into the game, the more I find that I actually DO want to know where this story ends up. There is a fairly limited number of enemy types, and it does seem a bit odd that almost every enemy in the game can be found in every biome (the same spiders in the swamps are the same ones in the desert...hmmm). Voice acting is actually pretty decent, although the dialogue isn't anything memorable. I felt that some of the NPCs COULD have been memorable if utilized better. But there are only 3-4 NPCs that actually continue with you through the storyline, and you interact with them very little in the grand scheme of things. You'll play for 10 hours between meeting with certain ones, and you'll think "oh, right, you're in this game..." There is a lot to do in this game in terms of quests. I haven't looked up any sort of quest-count, but it just seems that there are tons and tons of side quest, faction plot lines, and so forth. And you really can't tell if this go-fetch-item quest is a one-and-done deal, or if it will turn into the next five hours of plot for you to follow.

So, overall, Kingdoms of Amalur is a lot of fun due to watching your character get stronger, learn new moves and abilities, and become a whole lot cooler to control during a fight. I would describe the game as the more simple, arcade-like of the western RPGs, not one that rests on an immersive environment or writing. For that reason, I would recommend the game to at least try out. If you find you like the combat and skills systems, then that will cover over the fact that the game's other elements are merely o.k., and you'll get many hours of fun out of this.

59709317.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning is a 3rd person fantasy action RPG that was released in 2012. It was notable for its expansive world & sheer volume of in game lore, editing character skills on the fly and gigantic quest list. It received mostly good, however flopped commercially.

The story is fairly involved, with you being dropped into the thick of things at the beginning. You play as an amnesic character who has been revived, and might help turn the tide against an immortal enemy. Before the process can be applied to others or the research notes shared, the lab is destroyed and the inventor goes into hiding. It’s up to you to speak to the worlds inhabitants to glean what is happening. A war has started between a subset of the winter court (immortal Fae that are reborn into new bodies when they die but typically relive the same events in their lives) and the mortal races (humans, gnomes and the more typical fantasy elves). All mortal races can have their fates read by fate weavers, but recently the results have all been the same -killed by the Fae. When the player character is found out to not only have an unreadable fate, but be able to change fate itself a plan is set in motion to discover their past and try and put an end to the war.

Gameplay is mixture of running through the world killing enemies or performing tasks, and clearing each area of quests. The world is split into different regions which prevent returning to them once you leave, however all main story missions need to be completed before you can move on. There are tons of quests in this game, and they can have you traveling all over the map collecting resources, slaying mobs or delivering items for minimal xp gains. Most times the quest log will be filled to the brim, and each area requires a few passes to finish all the quests if you don’t outright skip them. Each area has a set enemy level strength, they don’t scale with you, so progressing is more regulated by how quickly you level up. There are factions who have long chaining quests, and branching choices which leads to different fixed buffs for the rewards. These can be ignored, but the bonuses are worth it.

The player character levels up by investing upgrades into 3 skill trees -fighter, mage and rouge. Each focuses on a different style of combat, and the game recommends you experiment as the passive bonuses for each upgrade are quite good. KoAR’s system allows you to do this effortlessly by allowing you to respec on the fly, and as long as you haven’t started a quests you are free to changes your skills as needed. While it’s likely that you will max most of the skills trees by the end of the game, it’s good to be able to change how you play whenever you want, and was way ahead of its time. Power creep is a problem, as the difficulty doesn’t increase with your character level, so by end game if you have been busy the enemies are a cakewalk, even on the highest difficulty. There is a ton of loot to collect, and a good crafting system as well.

I found the environments and textures looked good and didn’t have any issues with them. While they weren’t the best quality for what was released at the time (it was originally designed to be a mmo and converted to single player RPG) the environments were large, and there was always plenty to do and fight. Each of the environments were diverse, and many had layers to them, making you explore for secrets. It might hurt your eyes now to play as it hasn’t aged well, but it was more than serviceable at the time.

The DLC that were released are all separate side stories that lead to better loot and new enemies to fight. Each of the new environments was distinctive, and fairly unique. The Legend of Dead Kel focused on a pirate island, and give you a giant manor to store your spare equipment, servants and a possible wife to marry. Teeth of Naros has you fighting type of enemies on a giant floating island.

If you are chasing 100% achievements then you will need to purchase the DLC and play the game on hard. It’s not difficult, but a substantial amount of time will need to be invested.

For more reviews please visit https://store.steampowered.com/curator/31327216/

59540414.review:
Kingdoms of Amalur plays like an offline MMORPG. I knew this going in, but I got the game as part of a bundle and decided to give it a try.

My biggest issue with the game is how generic the setting feels. Maybe it gets better if you tough it out, but the lore is so dull and shoved so fully in your face that it's hard to just ignore it. Nothing about the returned-from-the-dead protagonist setup or any of the characters I met made me want to play more. So, I started trying to get something out of the gameplay.

The big hook for Kingdom's gameplay is your ability to customize your character abilities. You've got access to 3 ability trees: Might (Fighter skills), Sorcery (Wizard skills), and Finesse (Rogue skills). In practice, this means you get to select exactly the sort of skills you'd imagine from each of these trees and combine them. 

Alongside your ability system are the weapons you can use in combat. Each weapon is effectively a movelist/function. You can switch weapons at any time, but doing so is so stilted and janky that you're better off picking 1 weapon per encounter and just using it throughout. The weapons tend to combine far easier with your abilities, allowing you to break up an attack string with an ability before resuming your attack string. Blocking is a matter of either holding a shield while moving really slowly (doing nothing, forever the least useful and fun option), or dodge-rolling.

Now, don't get me wrong; I haven't encountered any bugs or other issues in execution. Kingdoms is a competently put together game. It's just uninspired on seemingly every level, and the combat is so stiff it seems like it'd play better as a top-down action RPG with a lot less emphasis on story or character interactions. Like Torchlight.

Basically, I'd play this if action RPGs didn't exist, and I was trapped alone with this game on a desert island.

One final point: I got bored, as you may've guessed, and quickly discovered that you can kill NPCs when I tried stealing an item in a place called Shieldring Keep (inspired name, no?). Out of curiosity, I decided to see how far I could take the killing, and proceeded to slaughter every NPC in the keep (including the keep's quest-giver!). I know other RPGs have done this kind of thing, and I didn't find it to be much fun (thus why I'm not playing anymore), but it's a consideration psychos and serious role-players might find interesting.

59264561.review:
Man what a flawed masterpiece!
Despite all the issues this game has, it is worth a run or two. I have about 60 hours on one playthrough and that is with mainly doing a couple faction questlines, the main story, and one DLC. Hardly any side quests because they have a very MMO repetitive feel to them.
There is a ton of lore, a pretty good crafting system, and a dang interesting story. The decisions you make feel impactful and there is a lot of small details that may go missed if you dont pay attention.  A TON OF DIALOGUE. 
The combat is super fun and probably my favorite part of the game besides the great rpg elements. However, this is also where the biggest problems show that I find VERY  annoying.  Firstly the game is very easy, mostly towards the end of the game. I had to nerf myself to present any sort of challenge. I played on hard after the first few levels because it was such a joke. Im a terrible gamer so I know its a game issue. But on the other hand I have never played a game with a stun lock problem like this one. You often fight several enemies, and any damage will stun you if you dont block it. Fine, but it breaks up the combat so bad it becomes annoying, mostly facing ranged enemies because mages spells track to such an extent it is literally impossible to dodge them, so you have to block the spell and they SPAM them. Making it so you are constantly either blocking or on the ground. But even on hard the attacks hardly hurt you toward the end of the  game, they just knock you down over and over. Its a shame because otherwise it feels great, very god of war like. Slower weapons are also worthless because of the issue because by the time you swing a heavy weapon you are being hit again and get stunned! 
I still recommend the game, just play it on hard and play around with different classes and learn to block perfectly to avoid getting stunned as much.

59256808.review:
I'll be honest, I expected little from this game. I got it the same day as FFVII during a sale because I had encountered one or two loud voices who sung the game's praises. It doesn't look impressive nor can it promise a life-altering adventure that changes how you think about video games forever. What it CAN promise you is a fun 50-100 hours of hack and slash goodness with the always cathartic, if a bit predictable reward of looting and dungeon crawling.

The game is mind-numbingly easy on normal difficulty, but I don't think that's all in all a bad thing. In fact, I think the game's "Screw it, be what you want to be" attitude fits the difficulty nicely. No matter if you want to be a sneak-archer-mage or a full on offensive spellsword juggernaut, you'll always feel like a bad son of a gun exploring a world that is surprisingly rich and large. The crafting systems are well made and interesting, though making your own armor quickly outpaces the actual loot you ever get, even if you manage to get an entire special armor set. 

The writing isn't superb or entirely terrible in any particular place, and it seems content in doing its job and little else. This isn't meant to betray the effort that went into creating the world or characters or quests, which is also very apparent, but it isn't going to win any prizes for storytelling. It exists to set a time, place, and reason for your aforementioned Mean SOG to kill some baddies without being distracting.

The number one word to describe this game is FUN. It won't win awards and it might not be a game I regale to future generations, but it certainly is worth at least one playthrough, especially given the price.

As of now, I give this a 7/10. A buy on sale.

58499303.review:
While the game isn't bad, it isn't actually fun either. The combat, while flashy as all hell and really cool to look at, is ultimately unsatisfying because the enemies pose little to no threat and you can create very powerful weapons early on that will make you feel like you're murdering helpless critters instead of fighting fearsome monsters. The lore didn't really grab me either. Again, it isn't bad, but it's kind of long winded and not very engaging in my opinion. 

The whole thing kind of feels like an MMO that you play offline by yourself, which isn't too surprising to me since the idea they had was to make an MMO based in this world that they'd created, and it seems like they used a lot of those same design principles in this single player game, which falls flat for me. It's a shame because I really wanted to like the game as it does have some cool stuff going for it, but the lack of a challenge and mediocre storyline give me no reason to keep going. Every so often for a couple years after the game released I looked for some difficulty mods to make things a bit more interesting but could never find any that would make it worth playing. I haven't looked in a while so maybe those exist now, but the common consensus for a long time was to manually gimp yourself in game, which is a horrible solution. I want to feel like all my best laid plans are helping me overcome the challenges that the game poses, not like I have to handicap myself to get any kind of enjoyment out of the experience. If you can find a mod to make the game challenging, it would probably be a really great experience, but otherwise, if you're someone who likes to feel like you have to be good at a game to survive--especially if you're a fan of the souls games or other unforgiving RPGs, you'll probably feel like I do and get bored quickly. It's well made, otherwise though, and still worth picking up on sale.
