57523949.review:
I thought Kingdoms of Amalur: Reckoning was surprisingly good. The game itself has an interesting history, involving a star baseball player, poor business decisions, a famous author, bankruptcy and so on. The game itself is more or less an Elder Scrolls clone. It is a large scale open world fantasy action RPG. Yeah no commas. It's all those things with no short pause in between.  The graphics are very nice for a game that launched on XBox 360, and still holds up to many current day games. Music is decent, although I'm not a connoisseur of video game music. There is a leveling and ability system that is fairly well implemented as well. The story is ok. You are The Fateless One (read: Chosen One), the only person to be able to escape the bonds of fate. The world is being threatened by a rogue splinter of a race of magical beings known as Fae, and it is up to you to stop their evil machinations. For me, the best two aspects of the game are its gameplay, and it's deep lore. The combat is fast paced, with dodging, blocking, and intuitively mapped special moves and abilities. If this were measured up against an Elder Scrolls game, Kingdoms of Amalur would crush it in this category. The game was meant to be the first in a series, and to build a captivating world, 38 Studios hired famous fantasy author R.A. Salvatore to create the game's lore, dialogue and characters. He did an excellent job fleshing out the world and lore, except the 38 Studios went bankrupt and there won't be any sequels to build on his creation.
As for negatives, the quests get to be particularly monotonous. Most are fetch type quests, and the game holds your hand and tells you exactly where to go at all times via map markers. You could just skip all the dialogue by mashing the skip button and then follow the arrows, never bothering to learn what to do or figure anything out for yourself. The game is fully voice acted, but not particularly well. Some actors are actually good, but others try to do a Scottish accent, or maybe it's Irish I don't know except that it sounds corny. By the end of the game things get a bit tedious also. It's a pretty long game if you include side quests, and there isn't enough variation in the gameplay formula to keep my interest for as long as it is. One more thing, I like puzzles in these types of games and there weren't any. Overall Kingdoms of Amalur is still a pretty solid title.

56972756.review:
Disclaimer: I have also played this game on release, so i have quite a bit more experience with the game than on just steam.

Combat
If you enjoy combat focused RPGS, you will very likely enjoy this game; the game holds a vast open world and very fun combat. Classes come in 3 archetypes (Mage, Warrior, and Rogue), HOWEVER, these classes can be mixed for in a myriad of combinations, and you equip cards called "Destinies" which buff your choices. 
For example, say you want to do ALL 3 of them combined. SO you disperse your skills into all 3 skill trees. By doing so, you can choose the "Universalist" Destiny. This card or destiny,  gives you buffs accordingly, unlocking ALL weapon masteries and giving you buffs that helps with each part (gives a 20% damage bonus to ranged, magic, and melee damage and +3 to ALL skills). 
The combat has a ton of diversity and feels very fluid. I wouldn't call it soulslike, but it definitely has similarities; evading attacks and weaving in your own is essentially the combat of the game. Shields and Heavy Armor are also very useful though, so if you prefer facetanking that's entirely viable as well. 
Mages can do massive AOE damage, and stealth is very similar to Skyrim. Executions as a rogue are very satisfying. Weapon and character movement is very organic. 
One issue however many have and i will agree with is this:
The game, even on hard, is just easy. You get so powerful half way through the game. Mage in particular is almost ridiculously op. However, i will say that I personally adore difficult games but still found Amalur to be very, very entertaining.
Combat: 9/10 

World/Setting 
The world is huge, interesting, diverse, and simultaneously generic. Enemy variety is good, but could be improved slightly. Each region and city feels different and like a breath of fresh air. There are vast deserts and forests with towering trees. 
The pitfall of the settings is its generic. The game was made originally to be an MMO, and was instead refitted to compete with Skyrim. It's hard to explain, but the game doesn't really seem to have a unique identity at all. The fate system seemed to be an attempt at this but really just serves as a unique combat mechanic and nothing more. If you're looking for fantasy environment, this game has it. Sidequests are hit or miss. there are many boring and very cool sidequests.
World: 8/10

Story
The Story is interesting but contains little deviation from typical fantasy storylines. Don't expect anything mindblowing or emotional. There's not much to say here, it keeps you interested but also doesn't throw many surprises or any revolutionary ideas.
Story: 7/10 

Overall, I'd give the game an 8/10
Nothing is really new, but the combat and world are designed very well. This comes at a price of the game not being very unique; nothing in game hasn't been done before. The Story is cool but nevertheless falls flat.

56574860.review:
When I was considering buying this game, I saw a lot of reviews from people who had never actually finished it saying it was great (note that there are also plenty who have a lot of hours on record). This includes a friend from high school who went on about how underrated it was but to this day only has about 7 hours on record. This game takes very long to complete, and that might be why, but this pattern also suggests that this game is great at drawing you in but not so great at keeping you there, which is why I didn't buy it immediately and instead put it on my wish-list.

After first play-through, I found out for myself. It was great at first but just got tedious after a while. I write this review after having come back and made a second character, which I've now played for a while. Personally I would put this down to the combat and the travel/exploration, which form the majority of the moment-to-moment experience.

Combat is a mixed bag for me. Enemies slowly approach you, and take turns trying to smack or shoot at you. Occasionally they don't take turns, and it's much harder. Sometimes it's a lot of fun; it's a nice mix of tactical play and mechanical skill. At other times it feels frustratingly bogged down and sluggish. The combat is paced quite slowly, and a lot of attacks/abilities have a relatively long windup and recovery. You often end up swinging at enemies that are just out of reach, partly because the angle of the camera in combat isn't great for judging distance, and partly because some enemies just move away during the afore-mentioned windup. This is something that bothered me more the longer I played.

The world is enormous, with a lot of variation. Not all zones are different, but there is a good variety of environments to explore. The problem is that the actual act of navigating the world becomes unengaging after a while, and I found myself crossing zones just to get to my quest objectives rather than staying to explore. I'm not exactly sure why this is, but one thing I noticed is that, aside from towns and cities, once you've seen part of a zone, you've pretty much seen all of it. The zones are distinct, but lack features that really make them interesting, such as sweeping vistas, enormous waterfalls and cliffs, peculiar structures, or other such landmarks. The game also features various caves and dungeons, but these only have a few distinct themes.

I usually don't care much about the story in video games, it doesn't make or break a game for me. With Kingdoms of Amalur, I still don't, which means the main story is neither bad enough nor good enough to draw my interest. With that said, the meat of the content is the quests, and there are way more than enough of them to finish a playthrough with, and they're generally interesting and varied.

The character progression is well-designed, and is the main thing that makes me want to keep playing. Each level-up was exciting for me, especially when the next destiny was just around the corner. The destinies are almost build-defining and are a really nice touch on top of the ability trees. The abilities and therefore the potential builds are varied, which makes for more interesting characters as the game progresses. You can also refund your ability and skill points at any time by paying a modest fee to a fateweaver. The game does not punish you for doing this a lot. This is great for experimenting or adjusting your build as you reach higher levels.

Overall, I would definitely recommend this game. You might get hooked like some other people have, or you will have a brief but enjoyable experience and put the game down for a while to return again another day, like I did. I realize that my review conveys a mixed experience, while most other ones are shiningly positive. Clearly, your mileage may vary.

56466747.review: This game is basically a single-player WoW; if that sounds boring to you, it is...extremely so. I have so many hours played because I felt compelled to finish it since I spent money....I couldn't because the attempt was unbearable and now I wish I just would've gotten a refund. At least WoW has other people to play with and the talent trees are so, so, SO much better. Yes, that's right; a single player action RPG couldn't even get talents right as they're all boring, passive % damage talents in one form or another. The quests are repetitive and boring, fighting the monsters is repetitive and boring, the action is repetitive and boring, leveling is repetitive and boring, the environments are meh, finding and upgrading gear is repetitive and boring, and the world design and lore isn't special or anything you haven't seen before. The only thing I had fun doing was creating characters, that's it. I have no idea why I waited so damn long to review this game, and I have no idea why on earth this game has a positive overall score.
